context.speaker: G. Thomas Koester
context.text: --Unless one uses the plain and ordinary meaning of the words.

context.speaker: G. Thomas Koester
context.text: If the islands are less than 10 miles apart, they are very close to the shore, they enclose water that is protected from the storms and the other weather influences, safe harbor, if you will, for mariners, it is not in contact with the open sea because it is broken off from the open sea.

context.speaker: G. Thomas Koester
context.text: It is divided from the open sea by these islands, so under the... what we believe a plain language interpretation of this definition--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: No, but if you drew the... if you draw the arcs in the manner in which the Government suggests you do, you will have space between the mainland and these fringes of islands which by definition would be open sea, isn't that correct, and isn't that why your argument, your textual argument, as Justice Stevens suggested, begs the question?

context.speaker: G. Thomas Koester
context.text: --The history of the United States foreign policy until 1971 is--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, could you just... just based on the text.

context.speaker: G. Thomas Koester
context.text: --Unless one uses the plain and ordinary meaning of the words.

context.speaker: G. Thomas Koester
context.text: If the islands are less than 10 miles apart, they are very close to the shore, they enclose water that is protected from the storms and the other weather influences, safe harbor, if you will, for mariners, it is not in contact with the open sea because it is broken off from the open sea.

context.speaker: G. Thomas Koester
context.text: It is divided from the open sea by these islands, so under the... what we believe a plain language interpretation of this definition--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: No, but if you drew the... if you draw the arcs in the manner in which the Government suggests you do, you will have space between the mainland and these fringes of islands which by definition would be open sea, isn't that correct, and isn't that why your argument, your textual argument, as Justice Stevens suggested, begs the question?

context.speaker: G. Thomas Koester
context.text: --The history of the United States foreign policy until 1971 is--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, could you just... just based on the text.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Why isn't a valid basis for answering that discretion that I have no idea what the State courts think of these issues that you're raising, and they might have interpreted their State statute differently had they seen these issues, had they addressed them, and had they seen Federal constitutional problems?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Isn't that a good prudential reason for us not to jump into the mess?

context.speaker: Norman E. Waldrop, Jr.
context.text: --No, sir, because we felt that this issue was, in fact... we had been raising the opt-out from the very beginning.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I think Justice Scalia's question is, assuming that we were to decide that you did not properly raise it, and the question then is, is it jurisdictional so we must dismiss this petition, or is it prudential, and he says is it a good prudential reason that you did fail to raise the question before the supreme court of Alabama?

context.speaker: Norman E. Waldrop, Jr.
context.text: Well, we believe certainly that it is... it is not jurisdictional.

context.speaker: Norman E. Waldrop, Jr.
context.text: We believe that it was, in fact--

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Well, the State courts, of course, can always address the question in another case, the next case that comes along.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: I don't think this is quite... I think there's more flexibility in the Federal system.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: The Alabama supreme court is not an inferior court with respect to this Court, so that you could say, take a look at this a little more closely or something, as you may with respect to one of the Federal circuit courts.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I don't think you understood Justice Kennedy's point.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I think he's saying that our GVR practice assumes that we have jurisdiction when we remand for the State court to consider a Federal question that it didn't consider, but if this is a jurisdictional statute, the fact that the State court didn't consider it means that we don't have the case in front of us.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: We have no power to vacate the judgment of the State--

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: --And the State of Alabama can decide that we think it would be better to bring everybody together in one proceeding and--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Well, that's exactly the issue, whether it can.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: --and the question... this is a due process claim, not whether the settlement was fair, although we think it was fair, but the question is, were petitioners afforded due process before their claims were resolved in this manner.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, may I ask in that connection, going back to Justice Ginsburg's conclusion that it's the greatest good for greatest number analysis, what would have happened if Edith McAllister had not sued first and had in fact objected to a class certification covering her?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: What would the result have been?

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Her objection that she had received individual notice of the proposed settlement--

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: How did the district court abuse its discretion in saying, boy, it isn't up to me?

context.speaker: Walter E. Dellinger, III
context.text: You approach that exactly as you do a case in which you're up on a preliminary injunction but the question is a rule of law, and this Court has held that the abuse of power general standard, which is a discretionary standard for the orderly administration of justice, cannot force this Court into making an erroneous decision of law just because a district court on a preliminary injunction or in this context or in any other got it wrong as a matter of law.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: General Dellinger--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --Well, but the focus... the focus, it seems to me, of Justice O'Connor's question is, what do you tell the district judge... if you're the law clerk for the district judge, or the counselor to the district judge, one of the attorneys, what do you tell him he should do in this case?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: It seems a little strange to say he abused his discretion by following the law.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: On the other hand, we know that abuse of discretion is sometimes a too-onerous word to describe what the... phrase to describe what the judge has done.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: It's good.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: But in terms of the basic purposes of the Establishment Clause, he points out why that line is a helpful though sometimes irrational line, so I'm interested in what your response to that is.

context.speaker: Paul A. Crotty
context.text: The answer, very--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Basically it was along the lines that Justice Souter was saying earlier, but I don't want to characterize it if you're familiar with it.

context.speaker: Paul A. Crotty
context.text: --The answer, Your Honor, I believe is that under the teaching not reflected in Judge Friendly's decision, because it occurred subsequently and in this Court, in Zobrest, where you had a child who was handicapped, what the Court said was, when you have a broad program of benefits that are available to everyone, regardless of their religion, it can't be denied to that particular child because he happens to be going to a parochial school.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: All right, so it's quite clear that a handicapped child, one who is a particularly strong case for breaching the line about sending the public school teachers into the schools, but then once that line is breached, is it then logical that you could have science taught for the lower third in the class, math, et cetera?

context.speaker: Paul A. Crotty
context.text: They don't get enhanced reading courses.

context.speaker: Paul A. Crotty
context.text: They get remedial courses, and it's remedial English, and remedial math, and English as a second language, and they're not taught... unlike the Grand Rapids situation or the Meek situation, they are not taught by parochial teachers being funded by public funds.

context.speaker: Paul A. Crotty
context.text: They are taught by public school teachers.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Mr. Crotty, Justice Breyer suggests that there is a line between a physical handicap and a mental handicap, which is what these children are laboring under.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Do you agree that you can draw a line between those two?

context.speaker: Paul A. Crotty
context.text: Well, I don't agree with that at all, Your Honor, and I don't think that's a constitutionally significant--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Mr. Crotty, we're still looking for a limiting principle.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: You referred to the Zobrest situation.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: You could say in Zobrest that the particular child either had to get the services in the parochial school or the child simply could not go and learn in a parochial school because there was no... there could be no communication.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: So that at least is a possible limiting principle between, as Judge... Justice Breyer was saying, the concerns that Judge Friendly raised, and the claim that was being made in Zobrest, and in effect that was the only way to allow the child to have the education.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Is there any limiting principle here between what you are asking and a broader support for secular education in the schools, in the parochial schools?

context.speaker: Paul A. Crotty
context.text: The limitations, Your Honor, are contained in the regulations.

context.speaker: Stanley Geller
context.text: The statute may speak of nonpublic students.

context.speaker: Stanley Geller
context.text: Here's what happens, or happened within the title I program in New York City.

context.speaker: Stanley Geller
context.text: Ninety-nine point--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Can't you answer Justice Scalia?

context.speaker: Stanley Geller
context.text: --Oh, I'm sorry.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I didn't think you answered Justice Scalia's question.

context.speaker: Stanley Geller
context.text: Ninety-nine point--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Can't you answer Justice Scalia?

context.speaker: Stanley Geller
context.text: --Oh, I'm sorry.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I didn't think you answered Justice Scalia's question.

context.speaker: Stanley Geller
context.text: I'm sorry.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You have no problem in principle with making public funds available to public schools and to private schools.

context.speaker: Stanley Geller
context.text: I am not... I said that... yes, I must admit.

context.speaker: Stanley Geller
context.text: I think we all are--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Mr. Geller, I believe that was a question--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: --I think he's answering my question, Justice Ginsburg.

context.speaker: Stanley Geller
context.text: --Yes, I did answer that.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Gondack may have been an error on our part, but there was a case 20, 25 years ago where we did grant a rehearing out of time.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Accordingly, we find Aguilar as no longer good law.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: There has been a significant change in the law wanting Rule 60(b) relief.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: We furthermore conclude that the Board’s use of Rule 60(b)(5) is proper because it arises in the narrow context of the civil case where a party labors under a continuing injunction.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Justice Souter has filed a dissenting opinion in which Justices Stevens and Ginsburg join in full and in which Justice Breyer joins in part; Justice Ginsburg has filed a dissenting opinion in which Justices Stevens, Souter, and Breyer join.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Accordingly, we find Aguilar as no longer good law.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: There has been a significant change in the law wanting Rule 60(b) relief.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: We furthermore conclude that the Board’s use of Rule 60(b)(5) is proper because it arises in the narrow context of the civil case where a party labors under a continuing injunction.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Justice Souter has filed a dissenting opinion in which Justices Stevens and Ginsburg join in full and in which Justice Breyer joins in part; Justice Ginsburg has filed a dissenting opinion in which Justices Stevens, Souter, and Breyer join.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Accordingly, we find Aguilar as no longer good law.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: We furthermore conclude that the Board’s use of Rule 60(b)(5) is proper because it arises in the narrow context of the civil case where a party labors under a continuing injunction.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Justice Souter has filed a dissenting opinion in which Justices Stevens and Ginsburg join in full and in which Justice Breyer joins in part; Justice Ginsburg has filed a dissenting opinion in which Justices Stevens, Souter, and Breyer join.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Well--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: --Well, but the... I'm sorry.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: As I think most of the parties agree, the Third Circuit spoke too extremely when it said you can't take... nobody says you can't take settlement into account, you can't have a settlement class.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But what's key in this opinion, as I read it, is that... just what Justice Souter said, that 23(e) does not swallow up everything that went before.

context.speaker: Stephen M. Shapiro
context.text: --We completely agree with that, Justice Ginsburg, and when you look to these other factors and you consider the settlement, it makes them so much more meaningful and... as opposed to speculating in the abstract, as this Court said--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Well, but let me suggest one change in Judge Becker's opinion that I think would leave us right where we are, but perhaps I'm wrong.

context.speaker: Stephen M. Shapiro
context.text: He didn't look just to the settlement.

context.speaker: Stephen M. Shapiro
context.text: He looked to the alignment of the representatives; he looked at their incentives; he looked at the negotiation history to see if these conflicts were reality or just fiction, and in that sense the inquiry is really a much-improved inquiry.

context.speaker: Stephen M. Shapiro
context.text: If you just look at the complaint, you can't begin to tell if you're going to get adequate representation, or if you're going to get typicality, if you're going to get superiority.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: But you would in fact have a very different inquiry, as you yourself argue, if there were not already a settlement on the table and, in fact, there is a good argument, as Justice Ginsburg just suggested, for coming out quite differently depending on whether you were looking at it before the settlement and after the settlement.

context.speaker: Stephen M. Shapiro
context.text: Oh, absolutely--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And the question is one of degree, and it seems to me the suggestion in her question and the suggestion in mine is that the degree is so great that the only way to make sense, I think, of the certification which the district court made was by saying, the district court was treating the settlement as sufficient as opposed merely to one source of information.

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: Others haven't married into the class yet.

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: Many, as Justice Ginsburg pointed out, have no clue that they were exposed.

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: It's not as though you're having a tete-a-tete with particular individuals.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: How do those factors help answer the question put by Justice Breyer as to why this is different from the fire-fighters?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Is the difference... and I'm not sure of how to best articulate it, but--

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: Right.

Arizonans for Official English v. Arizon.speaker: Justice Breyer
Arizonans for Official English v. Arizon.case_name: Arizonans for Official English v. Arizona
Arizonans for Official English v. Arizon.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 04, 1996

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Exactly.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Whether there was ever a controversy.

context.speaker: Barnaby W. Zall
context.text: Your Honor, I think there's also a question--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: So could you go back... I mean, I'm quite interested in your response to Justice O'Connor's question.

context.speaker: Barnaby W. Zall
context.text: --As to whether there was ever a controversy in the district court, Your Honor?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Yes, because that would seem to be determinative, wouldn't it, about whether or not we vacated, assuming you lose all the other points, the district court decision or just vacated the court of appeals decision, so I think your response would be important on that.

Arizonans for Official English v. Arizon.speaker: Justice Souter
Arizonans for Official English v. Arizon.case_name: Arizonans for Official English v. Arizona
Arizonans for Official English v. Arizon.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 04, 1996

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: That's characteristic of all leading questions.

context.speaker: Barnaby W. Zall
context.text: --I think, given the context, my proper answer should be yes, but I think my answer's actually no, Your Honor, because I think what it was suggesting was that in the peculiar circumstances before the court at the time there were still legal rights between the parties before the court, which it had made parties, which could be determined by the court on the facts in front of it.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Yes, but there was no legal right to damages, was there?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I mean, the Ninth Circuit... apart from everything else that Justice Scalia recited, the Ninth Circuit was also wrong in suggesting that she would have a right to nominal damages, wasn't it?

context.speaker: Barnaby W. Zall
context.text: I think under the Eleventh Amendment that's correct, Your Honor.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: May I ask you what... in your judgment what we should do with the case?

Arizonans for Official English v. Arizon.speaker: Justice Kennedy
Arizonans for Official English v. Arizon.case_name: Arizonans for Official English v. Arizona
Arizonans for Official English v. Arizon.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 04, 1996

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: I guess we don't worry about Article III in State court actions.

context.speaker: Robert H. Pohlman
context.text: --You're right, in State court they could challenge it, and that challenge would still be viable today.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Exactly.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, but where the question is based on the Chief Justice's inquiry, followed by Justice O'Connor, is we're assuming the State officials do not enforce the act, and Justice O'Connor points out that the initiative does have a citizens suit provision allowing a citizen to enforce the act.

context.speaker: Robert H. Pohlman
context.text: That's accurate, Justice Kennedy.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But the citizens suit provision may come up against a barrier if there's previously been an action in the Federal court where the Governor and the Attorney General are enjoined from enforcing it, which went by default, so the Attorney General and the Governor would then have a perfectly good defense to the citizens suit provision of res judicata as a result of the Federal action.

Arizonans for Official English v. Arizon.speaker: Justice Souter
Arizonans for Official English v. Arizon.case_name: Arizonans for Official English v. Arizona
Arizonans for Official English v. Arizon.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 04, 1996

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: A declaratory judgment, right?

context.speaker: Robert H. Pohlman
context.text: --It was simply a declaratory judgment.

context.speaker: Robert H. Pohlman
context.text: There was no injunction, injunctive relief granted, Justice--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Mr. Pohlman, may I go back to Justice Ginsburg's question going to the issue of whether we should vacate the district court judgment?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Would this be a position that you would espouse, that at the conclusion of the district court action, neither of the parties before the district court appealed.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: It is quite true that there was then an intervention, and ultimately in the Ninth Circuit the State came in.

Arizonans for Official English v. Arizon.speaker: Justice Souter
Arizonans for Official English v. Arizon.case_name: Arizonans for Official English v. Arizona
Arizonans for Official English v. Arizon.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 04, 1996

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Ah, so that's why they're stuck.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Yes, okay.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Could... I have two questions briefly that I'd like to hear your answer to.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: The most important is, I'd like to hear clearly what your answer was to Justice O'Connor's initial question.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I take it in the district court there was a person, the plaintiff, and a defendant, the Governor, who had an argument.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: The plaintiff won, and the Governor didn't appeal.

context.speaker: Carter G. Phillips
context.text: That's correct.
That's your understanding?

context.speaker: Carter G. Phillips
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Mr. Phillips, let me ask, while I do not agree with Justice Breyer's suggestion that the valuation should be whatever it takes to enable the 13 to proceed, there is some textual basis for... for saying that.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: What meaning do you give to the... to the other portion?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You say both parties agree as to what the purpose of the valuation was.

context.speaker: John J. Durkay
context.text: This isn't a... a formula or a mathematics.

context.speaker: John J. Durkay
context.text: This is real business in the real world.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: But in... in that context, assuming, which I do think this statute is really opaque on this question, you can make excellent arguments on both sides.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: So... so if you think what Justice Kennedy said, which is that in many businesses, perhaps small businesses, the creditor doesn't really expect to repossess and sell?

context.speaker: John J. Durkay
context.text: Correct.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: He... this repossession is a threat?

context.speaker: John J. Durkay
context.text: Judge, take all the proper context into consideration before you make your determination.

context.speaker: John J. Durkay
context.text: Don't do any blind appraisals.

context.speaker: John J. Durkay
context.text: And if you do that, and when you do that, we will generally leave that alone.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Well, are you suggesting that in the hypothetical that Justice Kennedy gave, where you've got a laundromat and the forced sale would be almost zero, but the income-generating value of the property would be significant, that there you would use some kind of a... a cash flow valuation?

context.speaker: John J. Durkay
context.text: You might be able to do that.

context.speaker: John J. Durkay
context.text: Correct.

context.speaker: John J. Durkay
context.text: I mean you're going to have to have some good evidence on this, but that's at least theoretically possible.

context.speaker: John J. Durkay
context.text: In the case of a truck, there's no going-concern value for a truck.

context.speaker: John J. Durkay
context.text: The truck is a truck is a truck.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: And that's the only... the only situation in which you would... you would answer Justice Kennedy's hypothetical by saying, we would give it going-concern value... only if you could show that... that he could sell it to somebody else... the whole concern?

context.speaker: John J. Durkay
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: John J. Durkay
context.text: I can't say it's the only... but, yes.

Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Co.speaker: Justice Scalia
Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Co.case_name: Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation
Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Co.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 04, 1996

context.speaker: Ronald W. Stevens
context.text: --I understand that, but in 1821(k) Congress itself said, define gross negligence under applicable State law.

context.speaker: Ronald W. Stevens
context.text: Congress itself indicated it had no interest in having some Federal uniform standard apply here.

context.speaker: Ronald W. Stevens
context.text: And by the same token, it seems to me that the fact that the institution happens to have gotten its charter from the Federal Government is not sufficient to predicate the creation of an entire body of Federal common law, which would--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: That may be, but I think you still have to overcome Justice Ginsburg's assertion that if there is no Federal substantive law there is also no Federal choice of law, so you really can't say for sure that the law which governs is the law of principal place of business.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: It depends on what the State law of the forum is, doesn't it?

context.speaker: Ronald W. Stevens
context.text: --Correct.

Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Co.speaker: Justice Souter
Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Co.case_name: Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation
Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Co.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 04, 1996

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: --Mr. Stevens, maybe we have here what is... what conflict-of-laws mavens call "renvoi".

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: That is to say that the State law would look to the place of... to the State of incorporation, the state of incorporation here being the Federal Government, the Federal Government having no rule on the question refers it back to State law, and maybe that's how you get where you want to be.

context.speaker: Ronald W. Stevens
context.text: I think that's right, Your Honor.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Yes, but even on Justice Scalia's analysis, you've still got to have a basis for looking to some State law somewhere, and it seems to me that your answer to Justice Ginsburg boils down to this, that in addition to the O'Melveny standard, there's another source of Federal common law here, and the source is something like necessity.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: If there's got to be a basis for court dealing with a federally chartered institution, to say what law applies, there is of necessity a Federal common law to the extent of deriving a pointing rule, and you're saying, I think, the necessity here is that Federal laws say that you look to the State of principal place of business.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Isn't that--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: That is to say that the State law would look to the place of... to the State of incorporation, the state of incorporation here being the Federal Government, the Federal Government having no rule on the question refers it back to State law, and maybe that's how you get where you want to be.

context.speaker: Ronald W. Stevens

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Yes, but even on Justice Scalia's analysis, you've still got to have a basis for looking to some State law somewhere, and it seems to me that your answer to Justice Ginsburg boils down to this, that in addition to the O'Melveny standard, there's another source of Federal common law here, and the source is something like necessity.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: If there's got to be a basis for court dealing with a federally chartered institution, to say what law applies, there is of necessity a Federal common law to the extent of deriving a pointing rule, and you're saying, I think, the necessity here is that Federal laws say that you look to the State of principal place of business.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Isn't that--

Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Co.speaker: Justice Breyer
Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Co.case_name: Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation
Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Co.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 04, 1996

context.speaker: Ronald W. Stevens
context.text: It isn't... it doesn't render the language inoperable with respect to State-chartered institutions.

context.speaker: Ronald W. Stevens
context.text: It does with respect to federally chartered institutions if you assume the existence of a Federal common law simple negligence claim.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Yes, but it doesn't if what you just said is the case.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: That is, if Federal common law is, look to the State where the principal place of business exists, then it means just what Justice O'Connor said, and what we would do if the principal place of business is New Jersey, and if New Jersey has a statute of simple negligence, this statute would retain that cause of action.

context.speaker: Ronald W. Stevens
context.text: Absolutely correct.

context.speaker: Ronald W. Stevens
context.text: I... we do not contend that the savings clause precludes the Government from asserting a claim for simple negligence under applicable State law.

Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Co.speaker: Justice Ginsburg
Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Co.case_name: Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation
Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Co.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 04, 1996

context.speaker: Ronald W. Stevens
context.text: Here, the only phrase used is other applicable law, and we think that means Federal statutory law, State statutory law, State common law, which is the routine common law, but not the narrow, specific, rarely invoked Federal common law.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Mr. Stevens, I thought your position was that there was in effect nothing to save, because there never was any governing Federal common law.

context.speaker: Ronald W. Stevens
context.text: That is our position.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Which is quite different from... your answer to Justice Breyer seemed to imply there was Federal common law but there is no longer by virtue of the first sentence of 1821(k).

context.speaker: Ronald W. Stevens
context.text: I didn't mean to say that, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Ronald W. Stevens
context.text: Our position is there never was a Federal common law claim.

Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Co.speaker: Justice Souter
Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Co.case_name: Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation
Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Co.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 04, 1996

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: But your position is that there is no substantive Federal common law, no common law governing the substantive standard of liability.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: It is consistent with your argument that there might be a Federal pointer law telling you where you look, what State you look to.

context.speaker: Ronald W. Stevens
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And that's what Justice Breyer's question was assuming, and I would have supposed that the Milwaukee case did not deal with that.

context.speaker: Ronald W. Stevens
context.text: I think that's--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: --because the Milwaukee case was dealing with substantive law.

Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Co.speaker: Justice Scalia
Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Co.case_name: Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation
Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Co.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 04, 1996

context.speaker: Richard P. Bress
context.text: Your Honor, it's certainly true that in many areas this Court as a pointer rule will look to a State's law really as a convenient point of reference, and we think that that's a propriate in many instances.

context.speaker: Richard P. Bress
context.text: It is not appropriate, however, where analogous Federal law provides you with some idea of what Congress thought about the matter, and in this case, by providing under section 1818(i) and section 1818(e) that the Federal regulators can enforce breaches of fiduciary duties which at the time the statute was created clearly included the duty of ordinary care, Congress is telling us that for Federal purposes enforcement of the duty of ordinary care is an important interest.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But your argument goes well beyond that.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: It goes to the entire internal management of the corporation if the theory you're putting before us is correct, and I would go further than Justice Breyer.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: It seems to me that there's a lot more chance of some certainty in the law if we refer to State law than if we try to apply some nebulous Federal common law of internal operations of the corporation.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: It will take us, you know, 100 years to develop a Federal law of internal management of corporations.

Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Co.speaker: Justice Scalia
Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Co.case_name: Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation
Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Co.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 04, 1996

context.speaker: Richard P. Bress
context.text: This Court had not, but Congress doesn't... it doesn't just enact laws in recognition of what this Court's decisions are.

context.speaker: Richard P. Bress
context.text: Congress is presumed to know at least where there is a majority--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Well, but you just told us the opposite.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You just told us that the reason the... in response to Justice Ginsburg that the reason the first sentence makes sense even as applied to Federal institutions is that Congress didn't know what the law was.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: It might be applying State law, they might be applying Federal law.

Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Co.speaker: Justice Scalia
Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Co.case_name: Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation
Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Co.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 04, 1996

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You just told us that the reason the... in response to Justice Ginsburg that the reason the first sentence makes sense even as applied to Federal institutions is that Congress didn't know what the law was.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: It might be applying State law, they might be applying Federal law.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: That's what you told Justice Ginsburg.

context.speaker: Richard P. Bress
context.text: --Your Honor--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Now in response to this question you say Congress must have assumed that they... you know, since the vast majority of lower courts were applying Federal law, that this was a Federal law at issue.

Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Co.speaker: Justice Souter
Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Co.case_name: Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation
Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance Co.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 04, 1996

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: --Then how do you get a congressional policy for uniformity?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: You've just said Congress took no position as to what was the correct law.

context.speaker: Richard P. Bress
context.text: That's right, Your Honor.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: If that's correct, how do you conclude in answer to Justice Breyer's question and other questions that somehow there is a congressional indication somewhere, (e), (i), or anyway, that there is a need for a uniform standard?

context.speaker: Richard P. Bress
context.text: Your Honor, if that's gotten lost, I'm sorry.

context.speaker: Richard P. Bress
context.text: The uniformity comes from HOLA itself, the Homeowners Loan Act.

context.speaker: Michael T. Leibig
context.text: They found it... and they also found it in some other cases involving the AFG case, which is cited in the briefs, and currently the position in the Department of Labor... I'm sorry.

context.speaker: Michael T. Leibig
context.text: The position in the Federal Government is that the Office of Personnel Management often treats people as exempt even though they're not salaried, but the Court of Claims and the United States District... the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia have held that they should apply the salary test.

context.speaker: Michael T. Leibig
context.text: And when that has been a challenge... and the one place it's been challenged specifically is in the Uniform Division of the Secret Service and for employees that are exactly... do the exact work of the employees in this case, that is, sergeants and lieutenants in the Uniform Division, and the court ruled that the Department of Labor pay classification things have to be applied consistent with the salary basis.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But Justice O'Connor was not asking about court decisions, she was asking about the position being taken by the executive branch--

context.speaker: Michael T. Leibig
context.text: I believe the--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: --and in fact... and OPM takes a different--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: What about timber?

context.speaker: James A. Feldman
context.text: Well, and if it can be leased for timber harvest it might be more than a 5-year period that a lease would permit, but still--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well that's... I asked... you said it's mostly grazing and mineral.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Does the record support that, and not timber, because one of my concerns along the lines of Justice O'Connor's questioning under this statute is that timber harvesting typically is... oh, some parts of California at least once every 15 years.

context.speaker: James A. Feldman
context.text: --Right.

context.speaker: James A. Feldman
context.text: As our reading of the--

context.speaker: James A. Feldman
context.text: It wouldn't be solving any adverse problem that seems to be occurring, and I think in those cases there would be a problem under the Penn Central analysis.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: --You're saying property you don't care enough to will it to anybody goes back to the tribe.

context.speaker: James A. Feldman
context.text: Well, I... it's--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: We said in Hodel, Justice O'Connor's opinion said that it may be appropriate to minimize further compounding by abolishing the descent of such interest by rules of intestacy.

context.speaker: James A. Feldman
context.text: --Right, and it's possible--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Thereby forcing the owners to formally designate an heir--

context.speaker: Rene A. Martell
context.text: Not that I know of, Your Honors.

context.speaker: Rene A. Martell
context.text: Some tribes do have consolidation programs, but--

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Because, of course, with non-Indian property there are State and local taxes applicable, and if the owner doesn't pay them for a period of time, there are procedures that the State or county can go through to forfeit the property for nonpayment of taxes.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Mr. Martell, regarding Justice Breyer's question about changing the escheat law, or changing the inheritance laws, I suppose there's a difference, is there not, for purpose of takings law, as to whether you have a general State law or Federal law that is applicable to all property owners versus a law that simply picks out a few property owners, or one class of property.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: For example, I think we'd have a different question before us if on the one hand the State law said, property escheats in just 2 years instead of 8 throughout the State, versus a law that picks out a particular class of property owners and just says, we're going to make an exception from the normal State law for you, and your property shall escheat more quickly.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: There might be a takings issue in the latter case when there isn't in the former.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Mr. Martell, I'm surprised, because I thought you told me that you thought it would be a legitimate restriction for the Government to say to Mr. Youpee or anyone else, you can give each parcel that you have to one person, or to that many different people as you have parcels, but you cannot take that one parcel and turn that parcel into two.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: I thought in answer to my question you said, that's right, that would be the kind of restriction that we wouldn't attack as a taking.

context.speaker: Rene A. Martell
context.text: Correct, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: And then you seemed to give a different response to Justice O'Connor.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: I thought you accepted that you can freeze the size of the parcel as they now are.

context.speaker: Rene A. Martell
context.text: Okay.

context.speaker: Gregory K. Wilkinson
context.text: In fact, you assume that they are true I believe at the motion to dismiss.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, yes, for purposes of deciding any legal question raised by the motion to dismiss.

context.speaker: Gregory K. Wilkinson
context.text: Right.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I was wondering if you could get back to the hypothetical Justice Breyer posed.

context.speaker: Gregory K. Wilkinson
context.text: I wanted to do that, Justice Kennedy.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: You were interrupted.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And I'm not sure that we should accept the redundancy premise as appropriate.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: --Well, it's not just a question of redundancy.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: It's a question that Congress used different--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, redundancy plus violation, but I mean, your... one of your arguments is that on Justice O'Connor's suggested reading, you wouldn't need (c) there.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And it seems to me that this is an act in which redundancy doesn't cut much.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: --Well, it's not just the redundancy that... let me make several other points, if I may.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But Mr. Delaney, that hasn't been the approach when 1983 is there.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: This is not a Cort v. Ash case.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: This is a 1983.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Maine v. Thiboutot says there is a right to enforce laws of the United States, and in connection with the question that Justice O'Connor asked you, I think you responded that there would be a claim... suppose the State collected the money and simply didn't turn it over.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: You acknowledge there would be such a claim?

context.speaker: C. Tim Delaney
context.text: --We believe that there would be a claim under either State law grounds or constitutional grounds in the property interest.

context.speaker: C. Tim Delaney
context.text: These individuals do not have any enforceable rights.

context.speaker: C. Tim Delaney
context.text: Our contract is with the Federal Government.

context.speaker: C. Tim Delaney
context.text: Our obligations flow to the Secretary.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: I thought in answer to Justice O'Connor you said that if money was owing to a particular individual they could sue for it.

context.speaker: C. Tim Delaney
context.text: But that's different.

context.speaker: C. Tim Delaney
context.text: When there's money that we have actually received from a third party and we are holding that money, then--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Mr. Delaney, in comparing the two, the direct benefit to the IV-A money, isn't there something like for social security benefits that there's an administrative route that you have to go first, and then if you're turned down, then you have further judicial review?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Is there nothing like that for--

context.speaker: C. Tim Delaney
context.text: There is nothing in IV-D that--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: --And in IV-A... I'm trying to get back to Justice Souter's question, when he said well, what if you were entitled to AFDC benefits and the State didn't pay them, under the old regime.

context.speaker: C. Tim Delaney
context.text: --Again, that's different than what we--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: And it seems to me that most benefit systems like that you have to make an application, get turned down, go through the administrative mill, and then end up in court.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: What about the payments?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: What about the... perhaps the statute's changed so much that I don't know which version I'm dealing with, and so I might just be referring to an old statute, but this... the words I have in the red brief at the end seem to talk about IV-D.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And then there's something, 42 U.S.C. 64, that says a State plan for child and spousal support must, on page 9a it says, provide that amounts collected as support shall be distributed as provided in section 657, and then section 657, which wasn't actually in the brief, seems to have, like, eight paragraphs which say rather specifically who gets what money, and then it seems like 654(b) says the State disbursement unit shall distribute all amounts payable under 657(a) within 2 business days.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: So it seemed like there was a lot of rather specific requirements saying exactly how many dollars different people would receive, some of them being AFDC people and some of them being non-AFDC people, and I think Justice O'Connor's original question, which I thought Justice Stevens was getting at too, is doesn't at least that part of the statute create a private right, or create a 1983 action that would require the State to pay the money, the specific dollars that it must pay to the people who are entitled to those dollars?

context.speaker: C. Tim Delaney
context.text: --Your Honor, if we have actually received the moneys and we're holding the moneys and we don't distribute, then yes, we could be sued if we're wrongfully withholding it, but we could be sued not under title--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Well, I would be amazed if the Constitution says you have to pay within 2 business days, as this statute does.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: What about the payments?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: What about the... perhaps the statute's changed so much that I don't know which version I'm dealing with, and so I might just be referring to an old statute, but this... the words I have in the red brief at the end seem to talk about IV-D.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And then there's something, 42 U.S.C. 64, that says a State plan for child and spousal support must, on page 9a it says, provide that amounts collected as support shall be distributed as provided in section 657, and then section 657, which wasn't actually in the brief, seems to have, like, eight paragraphs which say rather specifically who gets what money, and then it seems like 654(b) says the State disbursement unit shall distribute all amounts payable under 657(a) within 2 business days.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: So it seemed like there was a lot of rather specific requirements saying exactly how many dollars different people would receive, some of them being AFDC people and some of them being non-AFDC people, and I think Justice O'Connor's original question, which I thought Justice Stevens was getting at too, is doesn't at least that part of the statute create a private right, or create a 1983 action that would require the State to pay the money, the specific dollars that it must pay to the people who are entitled to those dollars?

context.speaker: C. Tim Delaney
context.text: --Your Honor, if we have actually received the moneys and we're holding the moneys and we don't distribute, then yes, we could be sued if we're wrongfully withholding it, but we could be sued not under title--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Well, I would be amazed if the Constitution says you have to pay within 2 business days, as this statute does.

context.speaker: C. Tim Delaney
context.text: There are other provisions in the statute that talks about having to do certain things.

context.speaker: C. Tim Delaney
context.text: The Secretary has promulgated regulations and said that those time lines can be waived, those time lines can be treated differently if you collect the moneys within the audit period, and so the whole substantial compliance thing does come back in in terms of measuring whether there would be an individual right there or not, and--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Could I follow up on that for a minute?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Supposing you have the hypothetical situation Justice Breyer described.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: You've got some money collected there, and you're in substantial compliance with the statute.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: You have that money sitting there, and a plaintiff who wanted that money sued you in State court, said we want that money turned over to us.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Our cases have always analyzed the plaintiffs' asserted right in their most concrete specific form.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: We send this case back to the District Court to construe the complaint in the first instance to determine exactly what right, considered in their most concrete specific form the mothers are asserting.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: The opinion is unanimous.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Justice Scalia has filed a concurring opinion which is joined by Justice Kennedy.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Our cases have always analyzed the plaintiffs' asserted right in their most concrete specific form.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor

Board of Comm'rs of Bryan Cty. v. Brown.speaker: Justice Ginsburg

context.speaker: Wallace B. Jefferson
context.text: I would say no, and I give as an answer, Your Honor, Collins v. Harker Heights.

context.speaker: Wallace B. Jefferson
context.text: In that, you stated the Due Process Clause is not a guarantee against incorrect or ill-advised personnel decisions, and that's correct.

context.speaker: Wallace B. Jefferson
context.text: I mean, there are States that have lesser standards than Oklahoma's does, there are States that have more severe standards, but nothing about any of those standards in and of themselves shows that the standard is unconstitutional.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Mr. Jefferson, you put Pembaur in one box because that involved a direction by the prosecutor, go do it, so the causation problem that Justice O'Connor brought up here didn't exist there, but you also had in your brief something about a category of dangerous practices, and I was not clear on what would fit that category.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: It wasn't something, a direct command like shoot him, but--

context.speaker: Wallace B. Jefferson
context.text: I had--

Board of Comm'rs of Bryan Cty. v. Brown.speaker: Justice Souter
Board of Comm'rs of Bryan Cty. v. Brown.case_name: Board of Comm'rs of Bryan Cty. v. Brown
Board of Comm'rs of Bryan Cty. v. Brown.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 05, 1996

context.speaker: Wallace B. Jefferson
context.text: You do not, because I do believe that there would be an extreme case which we probably will never see where one instance would be enough, and that would be where someone like Bryan County had a report in front of them, the psychological examination... there's no question of Burns passed it here, but had a report in front of them that said this person had a psychopathic disorder.

context.speaker: Wallace B. Jefferson
context.text: He has... he is going to... by a psychiatrist.

context.speaker: Wallace B. Jefferson
context.text: He is going to commit excessive force, criminal acts.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: But that's like Justice Stevens' example, isn't it, and I thought your answer to Justice Stevens was, no, that wouldn't be enough.

context.speaker: Wallace B. Jefferson
context.text: Well, Justice Stevens was asking me whether someone with a felony record.

context.speaker: Wallace B. Jefferson
context.text: I think that's a very dangerous--

Board of Comm'rs of Bryan Cty. v. Brown.speaker: Justice Ginsburg
