context.speaker: Brian Serr
context.text: The majority in Pembaur actually reported several dictionary definitions of policy in a footnote, and those dictionary definitions of policy even refer to a single decision.

context.speaker: Brian Serr
context.text: When my dean goes out to collect money from alums and he has to make a decision as to, do we ask this guy for a million bucks now or do we wait a few years and ask him for 3 million bucks, he refers to that as a policy decision.

context.speaker: Brian Serr
context.text: I made a policy decision to ask for the million bucks now.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But let's go back to Justice Souter's question, because here there is a policy over a 6, 7 year period of being careful about who is hired to be a police officer.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: That's the policy, and we have one... does the deviation--

context.speaker: Brian Serr
context.text: In--

context.speaker: Marian M. Livaudais
context.text: She is--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: In a community property State, isn't his entitlement to the retirement benefits really an entitlement that's half hers, and that does continue, whether she dies or not.

context.speaker: Marian M. Livaudais
context.text: --She's entitled, as a... as the wife of the participant during retirement she would receive benefits and would enjoy the retirement benefits.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Justice Scalia is completely capable of protecting his own question, but it seems to me that he's asking you--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --Go, Tony, I--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --He thinks that he... I thought that he was asking the question as a matter of Louisiana community property law, and then you tell us what ERISA provides, but as a matter of Louisiana community property law, is Justice Scalia not correct that the wife has an interest in the pension fund which, I take it, would have to be valued if the community is dissolved by divorce and, under... although I was surprised to find this, I understand the premise of the case is that this is subject to bequest under Louisiana law.

context.speaker: Marian M. Livaudais
context.text: --She's entitled, as a... as the wife of the participant during retirement she would receive benefits and would enjoy the retirement benefits.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Justice Scalia is completely capable of protecting his own question, but it seems to me that he's asking you--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --Go, Tony, I--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --He thinks that he... I thought that he was asking the question as a matter of Louisiana community property law, and then you tell us what ERISA provides, but as a matter of Louisiana community property law, is Justice Scalia not correct that the wife has an interest in the pension fund which, I take it, would have to be valued if the community is dissolved by divorce and, under... although I was surprised to find this, I understand the premise of the case is that this is subject to bequest under Louisiana law.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: That's the premise that we take the case on, is it not?

context.speaker: Marian M. Livaudais
context.text: I think so, yes, but--

context.speaker: Marian M. Livaudais
context.text: Except that the results is that under that... under Judge Fletcher's construction she basically would have the surviving participant who has anticipated receiving these benefits and has contributed to them thinking that he is going to retire, he suddenly has to divide his benefits with people who are not retirees.

context.speaker: Marian M. Livaudais
context.text: Granted, they... and they're not necessarily his children.

context.speaker: Marian M. Livaudais
context.text: They could... it could be a charity to whom she may have left this money.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Ms. Livaudais, could I ask you, regarding Justice Breyer's question, do you acknowledge that the only effect of a community property law is to say how the husband's property goes when he dies, which seemed to me to be the hypothesis of Justice Breyer's question?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Doesn't the community property law make it her property immediately, before the husband dies, so it isn't a question of the husband getting all the money at the end and State law just saying where the husband's property goes.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Your contention is that it is... or the community property law says that it is her property.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: That doesn't seem to make any sense.

context.speaker: Edward J. Deano, Jr.
context.text: --No.

context.speaker: Edward J. Deano, Jr.
context.text: What Congress was looking for is that a plan will have to operate first in the context of State laws, but also with the power of its antialienation provisions to operate within State law, so that the antialienation provisions are the power with regard to State laws that deal with benefits.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Is the $1,000 annuity that Justice Breyer was asking you about, is that at issue here?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I thought that was not at issue.

context.speaker: Edward J. Deano, Jr.
context.text: That is a part of the claim--

context.speaker: Edward J. Deano, Jr.
context.text: The record... first of all, the record indicates in a stipulation of facts that the rights had vested, and I also wanted to point out that the issues of a taking was raised and argued in the district court level, argued in... also argued in the Fifth Circuit?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Had vested when?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: When?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Justice Stevens asked you when?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Does the record tell us when the husband's rights vested?

context.speaker: Edward J. Deano, Jr.
context.text: It's my understanding that he took the... they came into his ownership and then he rolled it over into an IRA.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Okay.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: One other question.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Let's say that Isaac, that his wife pre... she passed away in 1979, that he was quite grieved, and did not remarry, and assume that the gift that Justice O'Connor spoke about was made to the kids, or it was passed on as it was in this case, but Isaac did not remarry.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: What would the children get in those circumstances?

context.speaker: Edward J. Deano, Jr.
context.text: First they would have had... they would have received property--

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: But do you have a better argument for the lump sum than the annuity?

context.speaker: Edward J. Deano, Jr.
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Edward J. Deano, Jr.
context.text: The argument--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Justice Thomas is asking you to weigh the two arguments, which do you think is the better one, I believe.

context.speaker: Edward J. Deano, Jr.
context.text: --Oh, I would find that there are... there is equal authority from this Court for both of them.

context.speaker: Edward J. Deano, Jr.
context.text: Probably the occasion has risen more with regard to the antialienation protections following after the benefits leave the plan.

context.speaker: Gilbert H. Levy
context.text: --That is the inference.

context.speaker: Gilbert H. Levy
context.text: It seems to me this is the type of... certainly the magnitude of bribery that's involved with Judge Maloney is pretty much, in my estimation at least, analogous to a rudderless ship.

context.speaker: Gilbert H. Levy
context.text: You simply--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But what about Justice Kennedy's particular question?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: What if a judge has taken one bribe, and has sat there for 15 years?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: All of his cases go down the drain under due process?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Mr.... I'm sorry.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I didn't mean to cut off your sentence.

context.speaker: Gilbert H. Levy
context.text: That's fine, Justice Souter.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: There's one answer that you are not giving to Justice Breyer's questions that I thought you were going to give, and I had intended, actually, to raise this with opposing counsel, but let me raise it with you.

context.speaker: Gilbert H. Levy
context.text: Okay.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I would have thought that you would have argued that one way to narrow the category down was to look for evidence that raised a particular inference of bias at the time of the trial in question, at the time of... your client was tried, as opposed simply to a general shotgun corruption approach pervasive throughout the judge's entire tenure.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: --I mean, are you intending... you have a proposed discovery.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: You have proposed discovery.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Do you intend to ask people who know the judge, or perhaps the judge himself, whether he either said or thought one theory or the opposite theory, whether he either said or thought, I think I'll be a little tougher in some of these criminal cases.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: It's important to me to get a reputation for being tough, because I get more money that way, or some words that could give rise to that inference, or the opposite, which Justice Scalia suggests could well be the case.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Do you plan discovery to find out?

context.speaker: Gilbert H. Levy
context.text: Certainly, Justice Breyer, in keeping with the idea that this is a fact-specific determination, what we would do is, we would ask the witnesses what was his attitude, what was his demeanor, what was his--

context.speaker: Barbara A. Preiner
context.text: He didn't bring to the court that he had talked to the defendant's lawyer at trial.

context.speaker: Barbara A. Preiner
context.text: He hasn't talked to any other witnesses.

context.speaker: Barbara A. Preiner
context.text: He hasn't... he hasn't done anything to show that there might be some basis that will ultimately disclose that there was bias in this case.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, what about the argument which has at least been brooded about here this morning that if a trial in which there was no known bribery is sandwiched between trials in which there was bribery, or was conducted at a time when bribes were being solicited and arranged in other cases, there is good reason to believe, certainly in the elected system that Justice Stevens alluded to, that it would be in a judge's interest to look tough in a case in which he could be tough at no cost to himself without losing a bribe, and that that would be a reasonable basis for saying that discovery may uncover evidence that would substantiate the claim here.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Would that not be a reasonable basis for at least taking discovery to some step?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I don't know how far it might go, but discovery is structured.

context.speaker: Barbara A. Preiner
context.text: That's nothing more than--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, it's not speculation.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I mean, it seems to me that it's a statement of one reasonable possibility.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Another reasonable possibility is the one that Justice Scalia referred to, and that is, this fellow wouldn't want to call attention to the oddity of his rulings.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: He would want to look a little soft if he could.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: That would be a reasonable basis, too.

context.speaker: Barbara A. Preiner
context.text: You can speculate that the judge was more harsh in these cases.

context.speaker: Barbara A. Preiner
context.text: You can speculate that he was more lenient in these cases.

context.speaker: Barbara A. Preiner
context.text: You could speculate that if he was being unfair in one case, he balances that off by being extremely fair in another case.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: So you're saying that neither Justice Scalia's view nor the view that I've been suggesting is even reasonable.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Each is mere speculation, and could never be the basis for taking even a first step in discovery.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Is that your position?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Counsel, before you finish, would you comment at all on whether you think there's any significance to the amicus brief filed by not only some distinguished Illinois lawyers, but former prosecutors and former U.S. attorneys, suggesting discovery is appropriate in this case?

context.speaker: Barbara A. Preiner
context.text: I sympathize, and certainly the Attorney General sympathizes also with those lawyers and their perception that there is a taint on the judicial system in Illinois because of the scandal, of the Greylord scandal.

context.speaker: Barbara A. Preiner
context.text: However, that is not a sufficient basis to upset a valid legal conviction in this case involving a defendant who was clearly guilty--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: No, but just to bring back the point Justice O'Connor raised, we're really not... we don't really have to decide that.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: We just have to decide whether the situation is sufficiently serious that it demands the fullest possible investigation before we decide what kind of rule should be adopted in a case like this, because there... it's perfectly obvious that something might be learned by discovery that sheds light on the whole problem.

context.speaker: Barbara A. Preiner
context.text: --Well--

California Division of Labor Standards E.speaker: Justice Ginsburg
California Division of Labor Standards E.case_name: California Division of Labor Standards Enforcement v. Dillingham Construction, N.A.
California Division of Labor Standards E.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 05, 1996

context.speaker: John M. Rea
context.text: We set a prevail... like most, almost the majority of the States we set a prevailing wage for public works for various reasons, and if you misclassify or mispay someone, we will make you pay the difference in a small penalty.

context.speaker: John M. Rea
context.text: That is coercive, as here.

context.speaker: John M. Rea
context.text: The reason apprenticeship is involved is because when caught with this mispayment the contractor's response was, oh, these are apprentices, so meeting apprenticeship standards is voluntary, but when you get caught fooling us about who the apprentices are, we'll apply the prevailing wage law, as here.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: You are not... going back to Justice Kennedy's question you are not agreeing with the AFL-CIO position that the training program is different from the provision, the financial arrangement for gaining the training, so that the training program itself, as distinguished from how one pays for it, is not under ERISA.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: You seem not to... you and the Government both seem to reject that argument.

context.speaker: John M. Rea
context.text: That's correct, Justice Ginsburg.

California Division of Labor Standards E.speaker: Justice Souter
California Division of Labor Standards E.case_name: California Division of Labor Standards Enforcement v. Dillingham Construction, N.A.
California Division of Labor Standards E.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 05, 1996

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Well then, that's what... I'm struggling with this statute that lists them in a row, training programs, day-care centers, prepaid legal services, and at least it seems incredible to me to believe that you could set up a day-care center and escape all the State regulations, quality controls on that, if you put it under the head of ERISA, so why should it be different for training?

context.speaker: Richard N. Hill
context.text: Well, I guess one of the things that's different about apprenticeship is that we have this system, this voluntary system that the Federal Fitzgerald Act regulations set up the standards that one must meet in order to gain Federal approval, and I think it's that.

context.speaker: Richard N. Hill
context.text: It's the incentive of complying with that system that makes this case... makes apprenticeship unique among employee welfare benefit plans.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Why isn't it easier to make a different kind of classification and in effect respond to the problem that Justice Scalia raised that in theory you could oust any State regulation by forming an ERISA plan?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And the answer to the classification I have in mind is, if the ERISA plan is in fact funding what is a requirement of a traditional area of State regulation, which I dare say apprenticeship is, the regulation of day-care centers is, and so on, just as the regulation of hospital rates could be, then the fact that there is an ERISA plan does not so connect the plan to the area of regulation as to require preemption.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Why isn't that the answer here?

California Division of Labor Standards E.speaker: Justice Souter
California Division of Labor Standards E.case_name: California Division of Labor Standards Enforcement v. Dillingham Construction, N.A.
California Division of Labor Standards E.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 05, 1996

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Why isn't that the answer here?

context.speaker: Richard N. Hill
context.text: Well, I guess my response to that is that the connection in a case like this is that the employers have set up a plan and a program that... with a detailed set of standards and wage progressions, and what the State is attempting to do is to regulate that and tell the employers they may not comply with the plan that they have set up, and once that plan has been interfered with in that way, you are interfering with the congressional--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: No, but you're not interfering with the plan if the object of the plan is to fund whatever you are required or permitted to do by or consistent with the traditional State regulation.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: It seems to me that your argument is circular, and both Justice Ginsburg's question and my question are basically saying, there's got to be a limit to what is connected to or related, and that limit is established by looking for certain areas of traditional State regulation, and if the effect on the ERISA plan is incidental to that regulation, as it would be when a plan is set up simply to fund the regulation, then you don't have preemption.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Why isn't that the answer?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Why isn't that the key to this case?

California Division of Labor Standards E.speaker: Justice Souter
California Division of Labor Standards E.case_name: California Division of Labor Standards Enforcement v. Dillingham Construction, N.A.
California Division of Labor Standards E.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 05, 1996

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, how?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I mean, why wouldn't it be quite arbitrary on your theory to limit it to that?

context.speaker: Richard N. Hill
context.text: Why--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Just as it seems to me it would be equally arbitrary to... in answer to Justice Ginsburg to say that we'll draw the line before ERISA gets to the day-care centers.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: If we accept your theory, we... you know, we've got to go the whole hog.

context.speaker: Richard N. Hill
context.text: --And I think what I'm suggesting is that in this particular case it may not be necessary to draw that line.

California Division of Labor Standards E.speaker: Justice Souter
California Division of Labor Standards E.case_name: California Division of Labor Standards Enforcement v. Dillingham Construction, N.A.
California Division of Labor Standards E.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 05, 1996

context.speaker: Richard N. Hill
context.text: --And I think what I'm suggesting is that in this particular case it may not be necessary to draw that line.

context.speaker: Richard N. Hill
context.text: There may be a future case--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: No, but how?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: How do we do it, because it seems to me the answer to Justice Ginsburg's question on day-care centers is inevitable.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: As I understand you correctly, the answer to Justice Stevens' question, even when you get to the single employer schemes, is inevitable.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: How are we going to draw this line that you want us to draw?

California Division of Labor Standards E.speaker: Justice Souter
California Division of Labor Standards E.case_name: California Division of Labor Standards Enforcement v. Dillingham Construction, N.A.
California Division of Labor Standards E.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 05, 1996

context.speaker: Richard N. Hill
context.text: There may be a future case--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: No, but how?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: How do we do it, because it seems to me the answer to Justice Ginsburg's question on day-care centers is inevitable.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: As I understand you correctly, the answer to Justice Stevens' question, even when you get to the single employer schemes, is inevitable.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: How are we going to draw this line that you want us to draw?

context.speaker: Richard N. Hill
context.text: --I feel it's a difficult line because ERISA does not define that line, the regulations do not define that line, and my best response is that in this particular case virtually all the parties, save and except the AFL-CIO, have conceded that this particular apprenticeship program is governed by ERISA.

California Division of Labor Standards E.speaker: Justice Souter
California Division of Labor Standards E.case_name: California Division of Labor Standards Enforcement v. Dillingham Construction, N.A.
California Division of Labor Standards E.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 05, 1996

context.speaker: Richard N. Hill
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: All right.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Let's assume that you're right and we don't draw that distinction.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Let me then go to the last part of your answer to Justice O'Connor and say that it then follows that the preemption is going to occur.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Why does it follow that preemption is going to occur, whether we're talking about funded or unfunded plans?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Why does it follow that preemption is going to occur if we are nonetheless concededly in an area of traditional State regulation which we have already held it is assumed that Congress did not intend to obliterate under the guise of ERISA?

California Division of Labor Standards E.speaker: Justice Ginsburg
California Division of Labor Standards E.case_name: California Division of Labor Standards Enforcement v. Dillingham Construction, N.A.
California Division of Labor Standards E.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 05, 1996

context.speaker: Richard N. Hill
context.text: One is, where we have express preemption I don't think we need to get into the question of what is traditional State regulation.

context.speaker: Richard N. Hill
context.text: I think beyond that we need to look at the express language of the Fitzgerald Act regulations, because that goes to the question of--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But without leaving out the Fitzgerald Act, it's the related to.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: It was in your colloquy before with Justice Souter.

context.speaker: Richard N. Hill
context.text: --And--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: So let's forget about, it's a plan.

Camps Newfound/Owatonna, Inc. v. Town of.speaker: Justice Souter
Camps Newfound/Owatonna, Inc. v. Town of.case_name: Camps Newfound/Owatonna, Inc. v. Town of Harrison
Camps Newfound/Owatonna, Inc. v. Town of.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 09, 1996

context.speaker: William L. Plouffe
context.text: But the point of the general fund is the language in West Lynn Creamery seemed to be very interested in the fact that any subsidy had to come out of a general fund.

context.speaker: William L. Plouffe
context.text: This is a broad-based tax.

context.speaker: William L. Plouffe
context.text: All of the people in the Town of Harrison have to pay this tax.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Mr. Plouffe, could you... going back to Justice Stevens' hypothetical, could you explain to me why it is in the case of the two profit-making corporations as to which a distinction is made the discrimination would not have been facial?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: You said it would not have been.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: You said it would get the, as you put it, the flexible approach, and I don't see why.

context.speaker: Kenneth Steven Geller
context.text: --Well, not... it's not a question of penalizing anyone, Justice Ginsburg.

context.speaker: Kenneth Steven Geller
context.text: We're simply saying that that was a remedy available to Lewis that he didn't pursue.

context.speaker: Kenneth Steven Geller
context.text: Now--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: --Well, it's my... if 1292 was not something that any litigant must use... and it's my understanding that it is not... then, as Justice O'Connor pointed out, a timely objection was made and that objection is preserved for--

context.speaker: Kenneth Steven Geller
context.text: --Well--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: --appeal after final judgment.

context.speaker: Kenneth Steven Geller
context.text: I'm sorry.

context.speaker: Kenneth Steven Geller
context.text: We're not relying, as I suggested earlier, on the failure to take a 1292(b) appeal here except to suggest that, in answer to Justice Kennedy's question, these are the sorts of errors that should be resolved prior to trial.

context.speaker: Kenneth Steven Geller
context.text: This is one more way in which he could have resolved it prior to trial and he didn't pursue it.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: What you are assuming, it seems to me, and might have said to Justice Ginsburg is that although the statutory error in one sense exists forever, the only real interest that is at stake here is an Article III jurisdictional interest.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And if an Article III jurisdictional interest gets cured, then the statutory error becomes de minimis, and given the interests in economy and so on, it isn't worth reversing.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Isn't that the nub of what you're saying?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Not defective jurisdiction.

context.speaker: Kenneth Steven Geller
context.text: Right, exactly.

context.speaker: Kenneth Steven Geller
context.text: That's what the Court held in Newman-Green.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: It was the basis for Justice Kennedy's dissent, as a matter of fact, in Newman-Green, wasn't it?

context.speaker: Kenneth Steven Geller
context.text: Well, the debate, as I recollect, in Newman-Green between the majority and the dissent was--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: The dissent was since Congress felt it necessary to explicitly provide for amending even a defective allegation of jurisdiction, it would seem clear that defective jurisdiction cannot be amended, there being no statute providing for that.

context.speaker: Leonard J. Stayton
context.text: No, Your Honor.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But the rule 15 deals with our own treatment of a case, not with what the court of appeals may have said.

context.speaker: Leonard J. Stayton
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: And as you agree, I take it, if you don't raise something like that in a brief in opposition, we may be taking a case, as Justice Scalia says, which has something that will prevent us from reaching the issue that the petitioner presents.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: And it's your obligation to point that out to us.

context.speaker: Leonard J. Stayton
context.text: That's correct, Your Honor, but this Court also held in Hanson v. Denckla that in cases such as... or in arguments such as the petitioner has made, that if it fails to make that argument in the court below, it also waives that argument before this Court.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You answered to me that no, it wouldn't be a Fourth Amendment search, but I'd object, and now you tell Justice Scalia, yes, it's a search.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Now, which answer do you want to abide by here.

context.speaker: Walker L. Chandler
context.text: I'm sorry, Justice O'Connor, I'm not exactly sure of the contradiction that I've voiced here.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Mr. Chandler, going back to Justice Ginsburg's question, assuming that you had actually to disclose papers, produce papers as distinct simply from producing information, so that there really were... in the same sense that we're talking with here, there really were a search involved, I take it that your answer would... I take it that your answer to the question would not necessarily be the same as your position here, because the governmental interests involved are different.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: You might or might not think the Government had a sufficient interest in requiring that kind of production from its political candidates, but at least the Government's justification, what we would look to to decide whether it was reasonable or not would, I take it, in your view be different from the weight of the government's justification in this case.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Is that a fair way to characterize your position?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Then the voters make their choice without any requirement of a--

context.speaker: Walker L. Chandler
context.text: I would object to that because, Justice Ginsburg, there's no showing that there is a problem.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: --Well then, how does that differ from in between the time that you're on the ballot and the time that you're elected?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: What is the difference in my situation, in the question that I pose and the one that Justice Scalia posed?

context.speaker: Walker L. Chandler
context.text: I believe this Court has held, at least since the Carroll case in 1925, that blanket searches are intolerable, and that that would just be a blanket search.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And would that be the same if every employee was required to get a physical examination once a year?

context.speaker: Patricia Guilday
context.text: The district court--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I can't imagine why he would have amended his complaint, no one having raised this issue.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: And Justice Scalia will correct me on this if I am mis-citing 1653, but it does say that defective allegations of jurisdiction may be amended in a trial or appellate court, so--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: --Thank you for the law, Justice Ginsburg.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Ms. Guilday, may I ask you whether there is any place in the record in this case where we might find evidence of some particular or special need in Georgia for a suspicionless general search program for candidates for office in Georgia?

context.speaker: Patricia Guilday
context.text: And so no, that would not be a restriction that impinges the Constitution in any way.

context.speaker: Patricia Guilday
context.text: However, the financial disclosure statements, because of the privacy interest that that intrudes, yes, does touch upon constitutional issues, and at that point this Court has called... has made limits on what information can be revealed.

context.speaker: Patricia Guilday
context.text: It's not an across-the-board, open all your papers up to the--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Can you... have you finished your answer to Justice O'Connor?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Can you... can I get you back to the Fourth Amendment?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: That's the part of this case that I'm most interested in, because it does raise a Fourth Amendment issue.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: ...against Miller will be announced by Justice Ginsburg.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: We review and reverse in this case, a judgment of the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: In 1990, Georgia enacted a law requiring candidates for certain state offices to certify that they have taken a urinalysis drug test and that the test result was negative.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: They had something they were looking at, anecdotal events, where they thought courts in general were not giving sufficient attention to laws by States and others that might impinge on the Free Exercise Clause.

context.speaker: Marci A. Hamilton
context.text: Well, Justice O'Connor, the difference between the Religious Freedom Restoration Act and all of this Court's section 5 jurisprudence will turn on the meaning of the word appropriate legislation, which section 5 says.

context.speaker: Marci A. Hamilton
context.text: There must be some kind of proportional fit between the means and the end to be appropriate.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, given that, could we go back to Justice O'Connor's original question, which I think was, in effect, why isn't there an obvious analogy between the situation in the Voting Rights Act, section 2, section 5, and the case that we have before us?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Why... assuming that the voting rights cases were correctly decided, why doesn't this case follow them?

context.speaker: Marci A. Hamilton
context.text: Because Congress in the Religious Freedom Restoration Act was not aiming to ensure constitutional guarantees under the Free Exercise Clause.

context.speaker: Douglas Laycock
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: Douglas Laycock
context.text: But yes, you still have a lot of running room, and this Court interprets RFRA and retains its independence as it interprets RFRA.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I'd like to hear your response--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --One... if I can, just one moment, Justice Breyer, Congress does... this Court doesn't have independence if it's construing a statute which has imported into its terms a term of art that had fairly specific meaning, i.e., compelling interest.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: It was watered down considerably, but that's the statutory standard we must follow, is it not?

context.speaker: Douglas Laycock
context.text: That's the statutory standard you must follow, but you have the same independence in interpreting that statute that you have in interpreting any other statute, which isn't to say unconstrained freedom.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Where that would... once we have RFRA, where that doctrine would ever come into play?

context.speaker: Douglas Laycock
context.text: --It is always in the litigant's interest to show that the law is not of general applicability, that in fact it discriminates, because that undermines the Government's compelling interest argument, undermines the Government's credibility.

context.speaker: Douglas Laycock
context.text: There are a number of lower court cases that say there's not a substantial burden here, so RFRA doesn't apply, but there's discrimination so Smith does apply.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Are you answering Justice Ginsburg's question?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I don't think so.

context.speaker: Douglas Laycock
context.text: I thought I was.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The opinion of the Court in No. 95-2074, City of Boerne versus Flores will be announced by Justice Kennedy.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The Saint Peter Catholic Church in Boerne, Texas was built in 1923 and it is said that replicate the mission style of that region’s earlier history that actually proved to be a problem for the Church.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The Archbishop had given approval for a remodeling plan with cause alterations to the structure to increase the size of the Church.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: When the political branches of the government act against a background of a judicial interpretation of the constitutional already issued, it must be understood that in later cases and controversies, the court will treat its precedents with the respect due them under settled principles including stare decisis.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Contrary expectations must be disappointed.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: RFRA was designed to control cases and controversies such as the one before us, but as the provisions of the federal statute here invoked are beyond congressional authority, it is this Court’s president and not RFRA which must control.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Justice Stevens has filed a concurring opinion; Justice Scalia has filed an opinion concurring in part joined by Justice Stevens; Justice O’Connor has filed a dissenting opinion joined in part by Justice Breyer; Justices Souter and Breyer have filed dissenting opinion.

context.text: But it seems to me what you're saying is that the inherent nature of the President's office requires that the States be constrained in this way.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But that's not separation of powers.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Then it's Federal sovereignty.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: But I... I agree with the concerns expressed in the question by Justice Kennedy that it's if it were a suit in State court.

context.speaker: Gilbert K. Davis

context.text: No, I am defending--

context.speaker: Gilbert K. Davis
context.text: --No, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: But if the President comes in and says, look, I want to keep track of this stuff, I need to meet with my lawyer, and I want to see what's going on here, it's interfering with my duties, what is the lower court to do?

context.speaker: Gilbert K. Davis
context.text: --Well, I think the lower court has its function and its duty to decide whether that is a good faith claim.

I thought you were saying it goes to the good faith of the claim of interference, and that is a different thing, I think, that you are allowing thereby from an inquiry into the degree of interference and whether the interference is serious enough to warrant the stay or what-not.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg

context.text: Mr. Bennett I found to be very accommodating, but this Court is going to be enunciating a constitutional doctrine.

context.text: Well, I'm not so sure about that, because even in the Fitzgerald case Justice Powell had a footnote where he suggested that Congress might pass a law authorizing such a claim against the President.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Now, if Congress could pass a law, then it can't be a constitutional matter, can it?

context.text: That is the remedy that the President... that the President could seek if he fears this interference.

context.speaker: Gilbert K. Davis
context.text: That is the remedy that the President... that the President could seek if he fears this interference.

context.speaker: Gilbert K. Davis
context.text: I think if there's--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: In the Fitzgerald case Justice Powell said that he was leaving over the... leaving open the possibility that Congress could do away with the absolute immunity--

context.speaker: Gilbert K. Davis
context.text: --Oh, I think--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: That's what seems unfair about it.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: --We'll resume there at 1 o'clock, Mr. Jones.

context.text: Isn't what the effect of the Government's position saying is that when I go determine who bears these administrative expenses as between my wife and my children on a different... a marital bequest and a non-marital bequest, State law governs.

context.speaker: David D. Aughtry
context.text: But when I go to allocate expenses as between my wife and my children in a life estate in a remainder context, somehow State law does not obtain.

context.speaker: David D. Aughtry
context.text: And so, we say there's no basis, no material difference for altering the control of State law in those circumstances.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Is this a fluke case?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg

context.text: I would also note that although the primary perhaps concern with the Treasury Amendment related to the large banks, that was not the only concern.

context.speaker: Gary D. Stumpp
context.text: The Treasury Department noted that it was also to affect the traders and investors that were dealing in this off-exchange market.

context.speaker: Gary D. Stumpp
context.text: So, I will not deny that the majority of the traders were the major banks, but they are not the only traders who are dealing in this market either then or now.

context.speaker: Gary D. Stumpp

context.speaker: Gary D. Stumpp
context.text: Yes, it was, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Because it was introduced by the Treasury Department.

context.speaker: Gary D. Stumpp
context.text: Specifically by... or specifically enacted as they proposed it.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But if I may just vary Justice Breyer's question, yes, these agencies right now do not seem to be in agreement, but if this Court made a decision that would say what the law is, then does it follow that there are going to be this tight regulation then that would drive everyone to the London or other markets instead of reasonable exemptions being made?

context.speaker: Gary D. Stumpp
context.text: I think that that's... obviously, it's a hypothetical because it hasn't happened, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Gary D. Stumpp
context.text: I think that in the number of years the dispute has existed, if it were possible to reach some kind of agreement without a direction from this Court, I think it would have happened by this time.

context.speaker: Jeffrey P. Minear
context.text: And in fact, that is how the CEA actually characterizes it, and it's one of the reasons why we have concerns with treating a transaction in foreign currency as a transaction in foreign currency options.

context.speaker: Jeffrey P. Minear
context.text: Petitioners argue--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: May I clarify one thing at the outset, Mr. Minear?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens

context.speaker: Jeffrey P. Minear
context.text: It either mentioned them by name or it used the transactions involving terminology.

context.speaker: Jeffrey P. Minear
context.text: That same language is found also in section 2(a) of the CEA.

context.speaker: Jeffrey P. Minear
context.text: And we think that that is very significant in determining what Congress meant when it used the more restrictive phrase transactions in foreign currency.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: To go back to Justice Scalia's question for a minute--

context.speaker: Jeffrey P. Minear
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: --I'm... it may well be that the language determines this in your favor, but if it does not and if it really is open and if Congress did in fact regulate... exempt the foreign transactions for the reasons set out in the Treasury letter, then is there any reason why, in a world where options transactions now serve the same purposes and are used to the same extent as futures transactions, the result should differ?

Dunn v. Commodity Futures Trading Commis.speaker: Justice Breyer

context.speaker: Jeffrey P. Minear
context.text: We think the problem with that position is it runs into the difficulty with the board of trade proviso that was discussed earlier.

context.speaker: Jeffrey P. Minear
context.text: It's clear that Congress did want futures transactions to be... that were conducted on a board of trade to be subject to CFTC regulation.

context.speaker: Jeffrey P. Minear
context.text: So, we think that that's a textual problem of taking that approach.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Could you refer me to something just in respect to your answer to Justice Kennedy?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I had assumed throughout this we weren't discussing no regulation of fraud.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I thought the issue was who would regulate: CFTC on the one hand or SEC and Treasury on the other.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The opinion of the Court in No. 95-1181, Dunn versus Commodity Futures Trading Commission will be announced by Justice Stevens.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: The question presented by this case is whether Congress has authorized the Commodity Futures Trading Commission to regulate so-called off exchange trading in options to buy or sell foreign currency.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: In 1974, Congress enacted a series of amendments to the Commodity Exchange Act that created the Commission and gave it authority to regulate trading in a number of non-agricultural commodities.

Dunn v. Commodity Futures Trading Commis.speaker: Justice Stevens

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: The reasons stated in opinion filed with the Clerk, we hold, that they are included within the exemption.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: We, therefore, reverse the judgment of the Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Our judgment is unanimous.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Justice Scalia has filed an opinion concurring in part and concurring in the judgment.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: --As I understand your theory, what you do have to say on your theory is that those who are not at the superior level by virtue of their military appointments as such suddenly become superior officers by virtue of this assignment to sit on a court.

context.speaker: Alan B. Morrison
context.text: That is correct, Your Honor, and that is... but that is constitutionally acceptable, as this Court held in Weiss, because they were appointed as principal officers along the way.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: We didn't hold that in Weiss.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: We left open the... as I recall, Justice Souter wrote that that question was involved, but as I recall the opinion for the Court never addressed it.

context.speaker: Alan B. Morrison
context.text: It said as I... we're talking about civilian--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I'm talking about the problem of having a requirement for the appointment of superior... of principal officers which can be evaded by simply having an inferior officer reassigned to a task that is the task of a principal officer, never appointing that inferior officer by the method set forth in the Constitution.

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: And to return to the point I was making earlier, in some respects the court of criminal appeals' review of court martial decisions is more limited than that which would occur in an Article III court in the criminal context.

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: That is, under the Sentencing Reform Act, a court of appeals within the Federal system may hear a Government appeal from a district court sentencing determination and may determine that the sentence was not harsh enough.

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: In the military justice system, by contrast, Article 66 makes it clear that the review of the court of criminal appeals is limited to the sentence as entered by the court martial and approved by the convening authority.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Now, are you essentially adopting the position that Justice Souter did in his separate concurring opinion in Weiss?

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: Well, we conceded in... the Government conceded in Weiss at oral argument and we would concede here that if judges on the Coast Guard Court of Criminal Appeals were principal officers, there would be a substantial constitutional question as to the status not only of the civilian judges but as... but of the military judges as well.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Well, couldn't you give me an easier, shorter answer?

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Now, are you essentially adopting the position that Justice Souter did in his separate concurring opinion in Weiss?

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: Well, we conceded in... the Government conceded in Weiss at oral argument and we would concede here that if judges on the Coast Guard Court of Criminal Appeals were principal officers, there would be a substantial constitutional question as to the status not only of the civilian judges but as... but of the military judges as well.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Well, couldn't you give me an easier, shorter answer?

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Do you agree with Justice Souter's concurrence in Weiss, yes or no?

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: We are not prepared to concede that the appointment would necessarily be invalid.

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: That is, if this Court were to hold that judges on the Coast Guard Court of Criminal Appeals--

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: We are not prepared to concede that the appointment would necessarily be invalid.

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: That is, if this Court were to hold that judges on the Coast Guard Court of Criminal Appeals--

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Excuse me.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: I thought Justice Souter took the position they were inferior officers.

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: --Oh, yes, we definitely agree with that.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: And you agree with that?

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: It says the Judge Advocate General can establish a court of criminal appeals, refers to judges assigned to that court, but there's no plain language that would suggest that the Judge Advocate General makes appointments at all, let alone that he is the sole appointing authority.

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: With respect to one point made by the petitioners, in our view the legislative history makes clear and this Court's opinion in Weiss makes clear that the point of vesting this authority in the Judge Advocate General was to remove the matter from the influence of the commanding officer who convened the court martial, not to remove the decision from the control of the Secretary of Transportation and, indeed, if Congress' purpose were to make it impossible for the Secretary of Transportation to influence the assignment process, it would have been bizarre to give assignment authority to--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: But is it true... but I take it that nobody ever thought about this problem at all in Congress, so we're not... it's just totally imaginary to think what they were thinking.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: They weren't thinking anything, and the... on this point, and so I think the argument is that just as you responded to Justice Kennedy you said, well, look, the Secretary under this clause doesn't appoint officers of the Coast Guard, does he?

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: --No, that's--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: No, because there's another provision for that.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Then there's nothing inevitable in this case.

context.speaker: Kathleen D. Mix
context.text: But just looking at the allegations of the complaint as stated, our position is that some due process violation, some allegations that alleged serious deviations from the rule of standards, will inevitably lead to the restoration of good time.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Yes, but you've just said... excuse me.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Have you not just said in answer to Justice Scalia that we in fact cannot tell at this stage whether this is one of those cases?

context.speaker: Kathleen D. Mix
context.text: We think this is one of those cases, but the State of Washington--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: You know what the witnesses are going to say.

context.speaker: Thomas H. Speedy Rice
context.text: I'm ultimately saying that this Court needs to determine under 1983 whether or not proper prison procedures were followed.

context.speaker: Thomas H. Speedy Rice
context.text: In Wolff v. McDonnell, in Superintendent v. Hill, this Court said that there are four basic, bottom line rights to a fair hearing in prison.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Yes, but procedural rights don't exist in the air.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: They have to be, as Justice Scalia just pointed out, for the purpose of protecting something.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: And here it seems to me what they're protecting is the man's liberty.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Right?

context.speaker: Timothy B. Dyk
context.text: Even this Court's decision in East Ohio recognized that the tax doctrines really didn't have much to do with this and it was addressing itself only to regulatory issues.

context.speaker: Timothy B. Dyk
context.text: But I think the most significant thing is not that Congress in the fifties authorized this kind of discrimination, but that Congress in the seventies and 1980's has taken a very strong position that it wishes to have a competitive natural gas market, that it has taken actions again and again and again to create a competitive natural gas market in this country, and it has recognized that natural gas is a commodity which should be treated separate from transportation... in other words, this is the unbundling aspect of it... and it has said that it wants all the competitors who were selling natural gas to have an equal opportunity, and if there's any Federal policy here, we respectfully suggest, it is a Federal policy that everybody should be treated the same and--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Mr. Dyk, can I interrupt you for just a second?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: In response to Justice Kennedy, you said that the record indicated that about 20 percent of the utility sales were industrial sales, but you don't know how much of those were un... pursuant to volume discount tariffs, and how much were unregulated.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Assume they were all pursuant to volume discount tariffs.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Would you win or lose this case?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: We're talking about pay for the 2 or 3 days that's necessary in order to give the fellow a chance to tell his side of the story.

context.speaker: Ann Hubbard
context.text: That's absolutely correct, but we do believe that if this is a Mallen Barchi case and the government was justified in suspending him without a hearing, even during that period between the suspension and the hearing, if the suspension was lawful in that he was given all the process he was due, the employer is not constitutionally required to pay him.

context.speaker: Ann Hubbard
context.text: The nature of the property right at issue here is the right to continue to work and to earn a living.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Ms. Hubbard, you went through a lot of ifs, and I... following up Justice Stevens' question, if the employee is arguing all I want is a chance to tell my side of the story, all that's involved... all that's at stake for the government is a couple of days, at most, of my pay, why doesn't any balance work in favor of the employee?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: The government can take him out of the job, and the only question is the pay for a couple of days.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Why doesn't the employee win on that kind of balance?

context.speaker: James V. Fareri
context.text: --That if you're arrested then you would be suspended.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Okay.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But you just answered that you say that would be unconstitutional.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: In your colloquy with Justice Scalia--

context.speaker: James V. Fareri
context.text: I believe so.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: --I believe you said that it would be unconstitutional, that that would be the rule, but in response to Justice Souter's question as well I suppose you'd have to say, no, it's not enough.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But you just answered that you say that would be unconstitutional.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: In your colloquy with Justice Scalia--

context.speaker: James V. Fareri
context.text: I believe so.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: --I believe you said that it would be unconstitutional, that that would be the rule, but in response to Justice Souter's question as well I suppose you'd have to say, no, it's not enough.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: It would satisfy the rule, but it wouldn't satisfy the Constitution.

context.speaker: James V. Fareri
context.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

Glickman v. Wileman Brothers & Elliott,.case_name: Glickman v. Wileman Brothers & Elliott, Inc.
Glickman v. Wileman Brothers & Elliott,.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 02, 1996

context.speaker: Alan Jenkins
context.text: That's correct, and let me--

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Have any of the growers asked for a vote on peaches and nectarines in California?

context.speaker: Alan Jenkins
context.text: --Well, in fact, Your Honor, there are periodic referenda, I believe every 4 years, and in the last referenda there was overwhelming support for this program, I believe between 75 and 83 percent.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia

context.text: Red Jim, I'm sorry.

Glickman v. Wileman Brothers & Elliott,.speaker: Justice Scalia
Glickman v. Wileman Brothers & Elliott,.case_name: Glickman v. Wileman Brothers & Elliott, Inc.
Glickman v. Wileman Brothers & Elliott,.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 02, 1996

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: The United States doesn't contend in this case that these are Government expenditures, does it?

context.speaker: Thomas E. Campagne
context.text: --No.

context.speaker: Thomas E. Campagne
context.text: In their footnote, Your Honor, they admit this is not Government speech, although one of their--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: So it's not Government speech, which would pose a different issue, so we can get rid of a whole lot of those regulatory programs that Justice Breyer was referring to, and only limit ourselves to those in which a privately run organization spends money that is assessed against competitors.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Namely, all of the programs.

context.speaker: Thomas E. Campagne
context.text: --But the point I was trying to make, Your Honor, here we have absolutely no studies whatsoever.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: It all is the same thing.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: What he did is, he went through bankruptcy and he wasn't entitled to.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I mean, I take it if I have a fraudulent scheme to get $100,000 from the bank, that might hurt the bank, that might hurt some depositors, that might hurt some shareholders.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: How is it two actions, and how is the trustee... to go back to Justice Scalia's question, how is the trustee in bankruptcy hurt by this RICO proceeding?

context.speaker: Richard Sauber
context.text: --I think that the Ninth Circuit concluded that in May of 1989 both Joanne and the trustee were injured by the recognition that Vincent had filed a fraudulent bankruptcy.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: It hurt their feelings?

context.speaker: Richard Sauber
context.text: --had diminished in value and they entered into a settlement of a certain amount of money which came into the estate, some of which went to Joanne personally, because she personally settled with the partners at that point also.

context.speaker: Richard Sauber
context.text: The racketeering scheme, the pattern that's alleged--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Could you answer... sorry.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Could you... I was... I... what was your answer to Justice O'Connor's question?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I never got one.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: How much money did the trustee lose as a result of this scheme?

context.speaker: Richard Sauber
context.text: --I'm sorry.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: She doesn't have to understand what all would be considered as part of the pattern.

context.speaker: Richard Sauber
context.text: No, but I do think that it was... it's only fair to suggest that she would have a difficult time proving continuity and relationship and threat of continued activity if it was just a dispute between her and her husband.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Then it seems to me that you should go back and say what I thought you did not say before, and that is, Justice O'Connor, your suggestion is not well-taken.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: There was no pattern, and there was no pattern until the second victim came into the picture, but that's not what you said.

context.speaker: Richard Sauber
context.text: Well--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Then it seems to me that you should go back and say what I thought you did not say before, and that is, Justice O'Connor, your suggestion is not well-taken.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: There was no pattern, and there was no pattern until the second victim came into the picture, but that's not what you said.

context.speaker: Richard Sauber
context.text: Well--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And I think you've got to choose what your pattern view is, because if you accept Justice O'Connor's suggestion and my suggestion, I guess, then it seems to me you're out, even on the more favorable rule.

context.speaker: Richard Sauber
context.text: --Well, I don't want to say that under no circumstances could a single scheme with multiple predicate acts constitute a pattern.

context.speaker: Richard Sauber
context.text: That's what you decided in H.J.--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: But that's not dispositive, we agree.

context.speaker: Richard Sauber
context.text: I understand.

context.speaker: Richard Sauber
context.text: That is not dispositive, but there was one victim for a short period of time, and basically what it was was a dispute growing out of a divorce case in which the husband tried to get out of his obligations.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: But what this seems to boil down to is what Justice O'Connor was suggesting a moment ago.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: She simply didn't recognize it fast enough.

context.speaker: Richard Sauber
context.text: Well, I--

context.speaker: Richard Sauber
context.text: --Well--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I don't understand why seven complicated acts which lead to the sale of the Brooklyn Bridge comprise two predicates, and I don't understand, if they don't, why the fact that three people buy the Brooklyn Bridge rather than one makes a difference for RICO purposes.

context.speaker: Richard Sauber
context.text: --Well, I think that it's the issue that this Court dealt with in H.J., that the... a single scheme, even if there are a number of predicate acts within a short period of time, where really in essence it's a dispute between a husband and wife, doesn't constitute the kind of continued criminal activity that this Court contemplated when it defined a pattern.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: So you're saying, I think, in answer to Justice Breyer it's when they sell the bridge twice, not when they sell it once to five people.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: That's when it becomes clear.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Is that it?

context.speaker: Eric Danoff
context.text: Namely, when the Court has said repeatedly that the two acts are mutually exclusive, if somebody gets an award under the Jones Act, for instance, first, is that mutually exclusive of the Longshore Act.

context.speaker: Eric Danoff
context.text: In the case of this case, where the first action is under the Longshore Act, the statute itself says the employer's liability is exclusive in law or at admiralty.

context.speaker: Eric Danoff
context.text: I don't know what that could mean, other than there's no Jones Act remedy allowed to follow.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Well, Justice Souter is not contiadicting that.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: He's just saying that you're never going to have the assurance of only one determination either under the Longshoreman Act or in the district court, because to be sure, if you are found in the first action to be either a seaman or a longshore worker, the other one is precluded and the case is over, but if in the first action you are found not to be a harbor worker, or not to be a seaman, you're still going to have a second action.

context.speaker: Eric Danoff
context.text: That may be--

Harbor Tug & Barge Company v. Papai.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - JANUARY 13, 1997

context.speaker: Thomas J. Boyle
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Thomas J. Boyle
context.text: Unseaworthiness is absolute liability, like products liability.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: That's why I'm asking.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Why doesn't... Justice Stevens put to you the case, isn't it possible that you can be a seaman but there's no negligence.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: So then I say, don't you still have a cause of action for unseaworthiness--

context.speaker: Thomas J. Boyle
context.text: Oh, yes, you do.

Harbor Tug & Barge Company v. Papai.case_name: Harbor Tug & Barge Company v. Papai
Harbor Tug & Barge Company v. Papai.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - JANUARY 13, 1997

context.speaker: David C. Frederick
context.text: --As this Court pointed out in footnote 3 of Gizoni, that means if the person is covered by the Longshore Act.

context.speaker: David C. Frederick
context.text: It doesn't say who decides that, and our position is that the district court jury in the Jones Act suit would have the opportunity to decide whether the worker is a member of the crew.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: I'm still confused.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: I know you're at the end of the time, but I've had no opportunity to ask about it, to clarify, please, the point you tried to address previously for Justice Breyer.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Apparently you think that an employer could be equitably estopped for asserting contrary positions in one or the other forum... fora, but the employee never would be equitably estopped and can take inconsistent positions.

context.speaker: David C. Frederick
context.text: The question is one--

context.text: I really don't understand why the presumption in the Montana case is any different from the general presumption that State action conforms with the Constitution.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: That's where I'm not sure I follow your argument.

context.speaker: Clive J. Strong
context.text: --I understand, Your Honor.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, isn't your... isn't the essence of your argument, I guess, and your best answer to Justice Stevens, if I understood you earlier, that Ex parte Young is concerned with a situation in which the plaintiff claims under Federal law, and the officers sued are claiming under State law, and here you're saying both parties are claiming under Federal law, and that's why Young doesn't apply.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Is that your argument?

context.speaker: Clive J. Strong

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I thought the--

context.speaker: Cornelia T. L. Pillard
context.text: Given that--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --Justice Kennedy I think has a question for you.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I thought your answer to Justice Stevens at the outset that if for sheer cost standpoints, because welfare benefits were expensive, these employees were terminated, the work was sent elsewhere, that that would not be a violation, and I want to know what is the test that you have that leads you to give him that answer.

context.speaker: Cornelia T. L. Pillard
context.text: --Our test is that the purpose has to be a purpose to interfere with the attainment of benefits in the sense that the action has to be taken not just in spite of its impact on benefits but because of the impact on benefits.

context.text: It has to be a specific focus on benefits.

context.speaker: Cornelia T. L. Pillard
context.text: --Our test is that the purpose has to be a purpose to interfere with the attainment of benefits in the sense that the action has to be taken not just in spite of its impact on benefits but because of the impact on benefits.

context.speaker: Cornelia T. L. Pillard
context.text: It has to be a specific focus on benefits.

context.speaker: Cornelia T. L. Pillard
context.text: Now, let me focus on this case.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, but that, it seemed to me Justice Stevens' case covered that.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Sure, that's the whole purpose, yes.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: In my hypothetical that was the whole purpose.

context.speaker: Cornelia T. L. Pillard
context.text: --Right, and--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And they look at these benefits and say, we can't afford these things.

context.speaker: Cornelia T. L. Pillard
context.text: --That's right, and there's a general desire to save costs, and where the incidental effect of that, where the employer is indifferent as between saving those costs out of benefits or saving those costs in other ways, through greater efficiency or through diminution in salary, or what have you, there's--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: No, but that's changing Justice Stevens' hypo.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: He... Justice Stevens' hypo as I understood it was, the only reason is to save these costs.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: He may not wish his employees ill, perhaps, but his only reason is to save the costs.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But I don't see how this squares with your attainment argument.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: You began by saying attain means that you're about to reach something.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: This is the Black's Law Dictionary.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But then you said, now of course this doesn't apply to... you had a wisdom tooth hypothetical, or Justice O'Connor's hypothetical of a very expensive particular case.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Suppose that that employee was receiving benefits.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: He or she had attained the right in that sense, and the employer terminates in order to avoid the coverage.

context.speaker: James D. Holzhauer
context.text: --Often... more often they get exactly what the plan gives.

context.speaker: James D. Holzhauer
context.text: The most common COBRA benefits is exactly the health insurance that they get.

context.speaker: James D. Holzhauer
context.text: They don't get the other kinds of benefits, but they would get the health insurance.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Mr. Holzhauer, given your response to Justice O'Connor's question, of what use is the application of the attainment clause to plans other than pension plans?

context.speaker: James D. Holzhauer
context.text: Justice Scalia, earlier you asked whether it was ever... whether it was common to have plans that allow you to get health insurance after being there for a year, or after passing a probationary period, which might be 90 days.

context.speaker: James D. Holzhauer
context.text: It's very common.
