context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: --90 days, firing people after 89 days?

context.speaker: James D. Holzhauer
context.text: --I think Congress was concerned about vesting pension benefits, but Congress talked about employee benefit plans, and I think there could be analogous circumstances under which section 510's attainment clause would apply to welfare benefits as well, and that's one very analogous circumstance.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But you insist it applies only to eligibility.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But then why, in answer to Justice O'Connor, did you get into the question of circumvention?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You've either attained or you haven't attained.

context.speaker: James D. Holzhauer
context.text: I was talking about circumventing the exercise clause.

context.speaker: Michael S. Gilmore
context.text: It's Rule 12(a) of the Idaho supreme court, and the Idaho supreme court decision of Todd v. Budell states that that was modeled upon 1292.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But the source of it is the Idaho supreme court, not the Idaho legislature?

context.speaker: Michael S. Gilmore
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: What was your answer to Justice Souter?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I mean, I take it quite specifically, why are the States filing amicus briefs?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: It's up to the States.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: If we don't take a case, how are you going to get here?

context.speaker: W. B. Latta, Jr.
context.text: --In... it is not likely that I would be the one who needed to get here.

context.speaker: W. B. Latta, Jr.
context.text: It would be the State.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, just focusing on the Idaho court based on your comments to Justice Ginsburg I assume no one could tell the Idaho court that it has to take... has to exercise its discretion to take the appeal.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Let's assume that we think that it's very, very important that there be an interlocutory appeal.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I was asking whether or not that could be accommodated within the existing Idaho structure, and suggested that maybe it would be an abuse of discretion for Idaho supreme court not to take the appeal, and then Justice Ginsburg points out, well, the whole point of this is so they can have complete control over their docket.

context.speaker: W. B. Latta, Jr.
context.text: It would be the State.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, just focusing on the Idaho court based on your comments to Justice Ginsburg I assume no one could tell the Idaho court that it has to take... has to exercise its discretion to take the appeal.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Let's assume that we think that it's very, very important that there be an interlocutory appeal.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I was asking whether or not that could be accommodated within the existing Idaho structure, and suggested that maybe it would be an abuse of discretion for Idaho supreme court not to take the appeal, and then Justice Ginsburg points out, well, the whole point of this is so they can have complete control over their docket.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: They're not answerable to anybody.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And so it does seem to me that there is then a problem if we agree with the petitioner's case that this is such a significant right that it has to be enforced in the State courts.

context.speaker: William J. Sheppard
context.text: It's clear.

context.speaker: William J. Sheppard
context.text: So you have a two-step analysis here, or two-step deprivation here, not only the omission of the knowing, but I'm going to tell you, ladies and gentlemen of the jury, that he knew it.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Yes, but your client--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: --But Mr. Sheppard, supposing in Justice Scalia's example, the judge did just that and said, don't you worry about the knowing.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: I'm going to tell you the evidence is strong enough to establish that point.

context.speaker: William J. Sheppard
context.text: I think it's a total denial of the right to a jury trial.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: --But Mr. Sheppard, supposing in Justice Scalia's example, the judge did just that and said, don't you worry about the knowing.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: I'm going to tell you the evidence is strong enough to establish that point.

context.speaker: William J. Sheppard
context.text: I think it's a total denial of the right to a jury trial.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Well, then you should answer no to Justice Scalia on that one, I think.

context.speaker: William J. Sheppard
context.text: And I appreciate your correction, Your Honor.

context.speaker: William J. Sheppard
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: She did not object.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: Therefore, she did not preserve her error.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: Therefore, Rule 52(b) is the essential source for reviewing her claim.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Well, but structural errors that we discussed in Fulminante... we did not find that that was structural error... might well be something that's just different than plain error, as Justice Souter has suggested.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: I think this Court has already crossed that bridge, Justice Kennedy.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: The Court has held that discrimination in the selection of a grand jury is a structural error, and that's Vasquez v. Hillery, but the Court has twice held, both in the Shotwell case and in the Davis case, that if a party fails to make a contemporaneous objection to the racial composition of the jury, that party may well forfeit any opportunity to get relief from such a claim, so--

context.speaker: Carla J. Stovall
context.text: Justice Ginsburg, that's exactly right, and that's what the State of Kansas would ask us... ask you to do, so long as we still have a mental justification, a medical justification for commitment and we show dangerousness.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, I take it that even the DSM says that these categories have no real operational consistency, and that you look to the diagnosis or the prognosis on a case-by-case basis after clinical evaluation.

context.speaker: Carla J. Stovall
context.text: That's true, Justice Kennedy, and in fact the DSM in the beginning of the introduction part says that this was not created for legal use or for forensic meaning, but it's to aid the psychiatric profession in making some diagnosis that they then can apply to this definition in the Kansas statute of mental abnormality.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: You begin by saying, and this was part of Justice O'Connor's line of questioning, too, that this is a hybrid between a criminal statute and a civil statute.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I should think, and correct me if I'm wrong, that--

context.speaker: Carla J. Stovall
context.text: It's a hybrid... I'm sorry.

context.speaker: Carla J. Stovall
context.text: In fact, the sexually violent predators are extended the same bill of rights that the mentally ill patients have.

context.speaker: Carla J. Stovall
context.text: That's not the case, though, when you look at Department of Correction inmates and the way that they are treated versus our sexually violent predators.

context.speaker: Carla J. Stovall
context.text: There is distinct differences in their clothing, their personal property, their telephone and visitation privileges and the like, and so there's a tremendous difference there as well.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: If you have a minute, could you go back to Justice Stevens' question?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: In Addington, I take it the Court held that you must have... you must say, based on clear and convincing evidence, does Frank Addington require hospitalization in a mental hospital for the protection of others?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: How does the Kansas statute meet that requirement in respect to requiring hospitalization for the protection of others?

context.speaker: Thomas J. Weilert
context.text: In order to do that, Your Honor, we would have to be talking about a preventive detention--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I'm being facetious, Mr. Weilert.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I'm puzzled about your response to Justice O'Connor.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You said that they could put all these other restraints on the individual.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: On a preponderance of the evidence that somebody's likely to commit a rime, can you put all these restraints on people, they can't go near schoolyards, and so forth, or are you talking about as part of a sentence after being convicted of a crime?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But what's the reason for--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --Why limit it to that?

context.speaker: Thomas J. Weilert
context.text: If we do not limit it to that, I believe we then... there's no logical stopping place where we can say that a commitment for dangerousness alone would not be sufficient, and--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, what about Justice Breyer's example of someone who's said by every psychiatrist who has seen him, if he's at large he's going to murder people?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Now, do you say that person can or cannot be civilly committed?

context.speaker: Thomas J. Weilert
context.text: --Well, as I understand the ALI definition--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: No, but even on the traditional rule, isn't it your position also that because one of the elements is fraud, and because fraud at least will normally be accorded a discovery rule, that therefore you have until the point of reasonable discovery, even under the traditional rule, or a traditional analysis, without regard to the peculiarity of RICO itself.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Isn't that your position?

context.speaker: Charles A. Bird
context.text: Well, I think part of our position... that is part of our position, but understand, the rule we're advocating, which is the criminal last predicate act--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Oh, I quite realize that, but if you take the hypothetical that Justice Scalia gave you, and you substitute for the intentional versus negligent act a fraudulent act, I take it your position would be that even though so far as the element of failure to supply what they offered or any conventional tort, as to that the statute might run immediately.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Nonetheless, as to the fraudulent element I thought it was your position that the statute would not run until the moment of reasonable discovery.

context.speaker: Charles A. Bird
context.text: --That is true, as... and that--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Surely it has to have some meaning.

context.speaker: Charles A. Bird
context.text: Yes, it does.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: And it has no meaning if in Justice Breyer's hypo the thing can be rejuvenated every 5 years, every time there's a new predicate act.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Even though the 4-year statute has already passed since the last predicate act, as soon as there's a new predicate act 1 year later the whole thing comes to life again.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia

context.text: And I think under this Court's decision in Cabana v. Bullock, when you said a case which you had to determine at what point there had to be a finding of Enmund under a felony murder situation for the death penalty to be imposed, you said that finding could be made by the appellate court.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: No, but your... it seems to me that your argument and your response to Justice Stevens is to say that if there is sufficiency of the evidence to support the proper construction, the error was harmless, but we've rejected that.

context.speaker: Matthew C. Lawry
context.text: Well, I would read Sochar and the cases cited in Sochar, because there are numerous kinds of jury error that the Florida supreme court has reviewed in death penalty cases... jury instruction error, improper evidence, improper argument.

context.text: In none of those cases has the court said, oh, well, the jury has... there was error in front of the jury, but the judge did it, okay, so we don't have to concern ourselves with the jury.

context.text: Mr. Lawry, can I come back to your response to Justice O'Connor?

context.text: If it was a question of State law we have the last word of the supreme court of Florida, which says that this claim is procedurally barred.

context.text: The opinion of the Court in No. 95-2024, Lawyer versus Department of Justice will be announced by Justice Souter.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: This case comes to us on an appeal from the three-judge panel of the District Court for the Middle District of Florida.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: The appellant and other residents of Florida, State Senate District 21, brought suit against the State of Florida and the United States Department of Justice claiming that the District 21 was unconstitutional under the principle set forth ensuring Reno and Miller and Johnson.

context.text: The elimination of District 21 is originally drawn.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: The appellant may not stand in the State's shoes to demand an adjudication that the State could have demanded but instead waived.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Finally, on the facts of this case, the District Court's finding that District 21 has redrawn did not subordinate traditional districting principles to raise is not clearly erroneous.

context.text: It is in that sense, but it is not backward-looking in the sense of tort action, in that the remedy to a person or the liability to a person, you're not... the State is not going to pay in the sense of damages.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: The person was either properly convicted or not properly convicted, so in that sense it is backward-looking.

context.text: Suppose Lindh had won in the district court.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Here he lost, and so he was up on appeal, but in line with Justice Breyer's question, what happens when he wins and the warden is appealing and it gets to the Seventh Circuit and everything else is the same, the new law passes.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Does that... well, you tell me what happens.

context.speaker: Sally L. Wellman
context.text: --The Seventh Circuit would have to apply new 2254(d), because that's governing that court's decision whether to grant or deny habeas, and the reason for that is a little bit unlike a normal appeal, because the habeas law has always recognized that the Court of Appeals of the Seventh Circuit is not just reviewing what the district court did and whether it did it right, but it is independently determining whether to grant a habeas writ.

context.speaker: Sally L. Wellman
context.text: We're discussing what this Court does under Landgraf when Congress--
No--

context.speaker: Sally L. Wellman
context.text: --is silent as to 2254(d).

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: --But what concerns Justice Breyer is that if we accept your conclusion on this matter you're going to have to decide each case by applying to it the Landgraf standards, and that's very complicated, whereas if we agree with your opponent in this case it's all very simple and we don't have to get into that complexity.

context.speaker: Sally L. Wellman
context.text: Well, it seems to me that... two things.

context.speaker: Sally L. Wellman
context.text: 1) I don't think it's that complicated because we're taking out all of the problems of what happened up till now.

context.speaker: Sally L. Wellman
context.text: And I think that in Landgraf what we wanted to do was to get to the heart of the matter, and the heart of the matter is, Congress, if you've thought this through and you've done the balancing of interests, and you know what you want, tell us and that's what we'll do.

context.speaker: Sally L. Wellman
context.text: If you haven't, we're going to look at this statute, what does it do, what is the change, what is the degree of connection between the change and the conduct regulated, and if that has a retroactive effect impairing a vested right, attaching new liabilities, we won't apply it, so at least someone is doing that balancing process, and Congress may do it.

context.speaker: Sally L. Wellman
context.text: You can encourage Congress to do it, but whereas here if they don't do it, then you... the Court should be doing that balancing process, and if you just do your generalized statutory maximums about intent and negative inference, you're never going to get to that point.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, as Justice Breyer has pointed out, we might say, well, we're going to have a very Procrustean rule on a Landgraf model saying you've got to be express in this abundantly obvious way or we're not going to recognize it, and the argument for that would be, well, it keeps the analysis simple.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: But Justice Breyer's question shows that if in fact we took that position we would then land ourselves in this particular case, or land all of the Federal courts that have to pass on these things, in a situation in which a lot of very complicated case-by-case analysis is going to have to go on, so maybe it would be better to sort of confront intent at the front end under our normal rules, assuming there's a textual basis in the statute for the application of some interpretive rule, and have a simpler result in applying the statute in individual cases.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Wouldn't that be a good argument?

context.speaker: Sally L. Wellman
context.text: If you haven't, we're going to look at this statute, what does it do, what is the change, what is the degree of connection between the change and the conduct regulated, and if that has a retroactive effect impairing a vested right, attaching new liabilities, we won't apply it, so at least someone is doing that balancing process, and Congress may do it.

context.speaker: Sally L. Wellman
context.text: You can encourage Congress to do it, but whereas here if they don't do it, then you... the Court should be doing that balancing process, and if you just do your generalized statutory maximums about intent and negative inference, you're never going to get to that point.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, as Justice Breyer has pointed out, we might say, well, we're going to have a very Procrustean rule on a Landgraf model saying you've got to be express in this abundantly obvious way or we're not going to recognize it, and the argument for that would be, well, it keeps the analysis simple.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: But Justice Breyer's question shows that if in fact we took that position we would then land ourselves in this particular case, or land all of the Federal courts that have to pass on these things, in a situation in which a lot of very complicated case-by-case analysis is going to have to go on, so maybe it would be better to sort of confront intent at the front end under our normal rules, assuming there's a textual basis in the statute for the application of some interpretive rule, and have a simpler result in applying the statute in individual cases.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Wouldn't that be a good argument?

context.speaker: Sally L. Wellman
context.text: No.

context.speaker: Joaquin G. Avila
context.text: Yes, it was, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: So that... that's quite a significant factor as to whether a realistic option is to let those terms continue.

context.speaker: Joaquin G. Avila
context.text: Well, there was ample opportunity that was provided to the district court in order to resolve and address that question.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: But your case, as I understand it, does not depend upon our so assuming, because all you want, in theory, and all... as I understand it, all that it would take for us to resolve this case, and all that it would have taken for the district court to resolve the case was to order, just as Justice Breyer suggested a moment ago, no election under this plan.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: What happens next may be a very serious State problem, but that's not what you require the district court to get into.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: All you are asking from the district court is, enjoin the election.

context.speaker: Daniel G. Stone
context.text: --That is irrelevant, Your Honor.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: That's irrelevant.

context.speaker: Daniel G. Stone
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: May I get clear on, I guess, a further point there that is raised both by your answer to Justice Stevens and your answer to Justice Breyer?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: In an action like this, in which the issue is whether preclearance is required and whether, if so, it has been obtained, and the court concludes that it is required and it hasn't been obtained, is it your position that the Court can enjoin the... an election under the unprecleared plan?

context.speaker: Daniel G. Stone
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Daniel G. Stone
context.text: --That is irrelevant, Your Honor.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: That's irrelevant.

context.speaker: Daniel G. Stone
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: May I get clear on, I guess, a further point there that is raised both by your answer to Justice Stevens and your answer to Justice Breyer?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: In an action like this, in which the issue is whether preclearance is required and whether, if so, it has been obtained, and the court concludes that it is required and it hasn't been obtained, is it your position that the Court can enjoin the... an election under the unprecleared plan?

context.speaker: Daniel G. Stone
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Daniel G. Stone
context.text: But the court--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Oh, because of the court's extension.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: All right.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well then, isn't Justice Stevens correct in his suggestion that all you have to do, if the case goes back in that posture, is to file an appropriate pleading saying this status quo ante is unconstitutional, and you should vacate any order of the court that establishes it?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: You... that's open to you, isn't it?

context.speaker: Daniel G. Stone
context.text: --Well, when the Court held its hearing on Miller, that was the question it wanted to address--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well then, isn't Justice Stevens correct in his suggestion that all you have to do, if the case goes back in that posture, is to file an appropriate pleading saying this status quo ante is unconstitutional, and you should vacate any order of the court that establishes it?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: You... that's open to you, isn't it?

context.speaker: Daniel G. Stone
context.text: --Well, when the Court held its hearing on Miller, that was the question it wanted to address--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Yes, and that's the question... and that's the question that you can litigate if it goes back in the posture that Justice Stevens and I are suggesting.

context.speaker: Daniel G. Stone
context.text: --Well, that's true, Your Honor, although in the meantime the results of that unconstitutional--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: That is yet another issue.

context.speaker: Joel T. Remland
context.text: The contention or speculative nature of these credits doesn't really impact the fact that the effect of the '92 act totally and retroactively increased the measure of punishment.

context.speaker: Joel T. Remland
context.text: It stiffened the measure of punishment.

context.speaker: Joel T. Remland
context.text: It increased the measure of punishment over the statutory formula under 921, the sentencing guidelines law that was in effect at the time of the offense that provided a provisional and mandatory release date.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: But may... on that point, may I ask you a variant of Justice Ginsburg's question?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I've gone over the statute as you've provided it to us in the lodging, the statute that was in effect at the time of the offense, and it's not clear to me from reading that statute whether any reduction that did not result in the release of a particular prisoner would have survived the termination of the emergency.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: It is not clear to me from the statute, for example, that if your client got a 30-day reduction at some point because there was an emergency during his incarceration, but he was not released as a result of it because the reduction didn't get him down to that point, it's not clear to me from the statute that the reduction would have sort of remained on the books, if you will, as a permanent reduction in his sentence once the population had dropped down and that emergency was passed.

context.speaker: Joel T. Remland
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: The emergency was over, you still retain the credits.

context.speaker: Joel T. Remland
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: So you were saying to me the statute we've got is not the kind of statute that Justice Ginsburg was asking you the hypothetical about.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And you said the reason for the permanence of the credits was 921.001, subsections 8 or 10.

context.speaker: Joel T. Remland
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.text: Oh.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: You distinguish in response to Justice O'Connor the custody case from the deprivation permanently of parental status on the basis of the permanence of the latter.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Well, what about establishing parental relationship?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: What about paternity proceedings?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Can I go back--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: --Can I ask you--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: --Please.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: --just a sort of variation of Justice Kennedy's question.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: In the Lassiter case, the Court refused to hold that a person like your client is entitled in all cases to counsel, but did indicate on a case-by-case basis counsel might be required in some situations.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Supposing in this case, instead of a one-line order rejecting your claim, the trial judge had made detailed findings of fact saying that he relied on the testimony of so-and-so to the effect of blah, blah, blah, and he gave a very careful opinion and analysis of the reasons, and you could tell what the basis of the decision was and what the evidentiary support for it was.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: It may be... what did the Court... why did the Court say that as a matter of the Federal Constitution, in order to deprive a parent of parental status, the proof standard that the... that must be met is clear and convincing?

context.speaker: Rickey T. Moore
context.text: --I assume that the interest were considered somewhat more than the normal.

context.speaker: Rickey T. Moore
context.text: I don't remember specifically from the case whether or not it specifically deals with that.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Well, if the Court said that because there is a fundamental interest at stake, that is, the parent-child relationship is a fundamental interest... let's assume that's what the Court said, as I think it did... then the parent's loss at the trial level doesn't mean the interest is changed, as Justice O'Connor suggested.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: The interest remains the same.

context.speaker: Rickey T. Moore
context.text: Well, again, my argument is based on those line of cases that talk about the biological connection alone is not sufficient to raise any interest, and the parent's conduct determines that, so when you have a trial court determining that the conduct of the parent is such that the parental right should be terminated, then it would seem like at that point the presumption of a fundamental right might be lessened, at least.

M. L. B. v. S. L. J..speaker: Justice Rehnquist

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The opinion of the Court in No. 95-853, M.L.B. versus S.L.J. will be announced by Justice Ginsburg.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: This case concerns a poor person’s opportunity to challenge on appeal a court decree ending her status as a parent.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: The petitioner, M.L.B. had two children, a boy born in 1985, a girl in 1987.

M. L. B. v. S. L. J..speaker: Justice Ginsburg
M. L. B. v. S. L. J..case_name: M. L. B. v. S. L. J.
M. L. B. v. S. L. J..title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - DECEMBER 16, 1996

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Parental termination decrees, our prior decision acknowledged work a unique kind of deprivation unlike custody decrees, they totally destroy all legal recognition of a parent-child relationship.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: We therefore distinguish M.L.B.’s case from the mind run of civil actions including other domestic relations matters and align it for appeal access purposes with criminal and petty offense cases.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: The accusatory state action M.L.B. seeks defend off, we explain, should not be obscured by the label civil action where parental unfitness judications are barely distinguishable from criminal condemnation in view of the magnitude and permanence of the laws at state.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Justice Kennedy has filed an opinion concurring in the judgment; Justice Thomas has filed a dissenting opinion joined by Justice Scalia; the Chief Justice has filed a dissenting opinion joining all but part two of Justice Thomas’ dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I am so glad to get out of this car.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Let me catch the nearest cab and go--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: --You can see what Justice Scalia's passengers tend to feel like.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Assuming that Justice Scalia is the one who has been stopped and it's his passenger--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: --who is then free to go, would the bright line rule simply allowing the officer to say, get out, give the officer any greater authority than the officer has in the case of sort of the public arrest, in which people are congregating around and the officer says, stay back, or get away, or something like that?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Let me catch the nearest cab and go--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: --You can see what Justice Scalia's passengers tend to feel like.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Assuming that Justice Scalia is the one who has been stopped and it's his passenger--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: --who is then free to go, would the bright line rule simply allowing the officer to say, get out, give the officer any greater authority than the officer has in the case of sort of the public arrest, in which people are congregating around and the officer says, stay back, or get away, or something like that?

context.speaker: Byron L. Warnken
context.text: Justice Souter, I think the answer is that the bright line should not be drawn there.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: That person can go back the 12 feet or whatever and say, I don't want to stay here any longer, and walk away, but at least within a certain zone in which the officer is operating, the officer can control people who come along, and those people who come along are no more or less innocent, I suppose, than the passenger, so why shouldn't the passenger be in the same boat with the bystander?

context.speaker: Byron L. Warnken
context.text: --Justice Souter, on first blush it may appear that those situations are similar.

context.speaker: Byron L. Warnken
context.text: I think the reason they are different is that the passenger, once being made to get out, if Your Honors draw the bright line there, as has been pointed out before, the police will push that limit and, in fact, once you have the valid stop of that vehicle, United States v. Sharpe and numerous other cases from this Court would probably permit about a half-an-hour, case-by-case basis, on how long you could detain, which means, Your Honor, that making the passenger get out would have the functional equivalent, particularly if there was a bright line and the police could do anything in any case, allowing the passenger to be detained, even though it started as--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, the passenger will be detained during the stop unless under Justice Souter's hypothesis the passenger is free to walk away, but it's a voluntary thing.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: It may not be too voluntary if you're out on the desert somewhere, but if you're in an airport, if you're being driven to the airport by somebody and you have a chance to catch a plane if you get a cab it might make quite a bit of difference.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But I don't see why it would necessarily follow that the passenger is detained for 30 minutes if the driver is detained for 30 minutes, under the hypothesis Justice Souter proposes.

context.speaker: Byron L. Warnken
context.text: I think the reason they are different is that the passenger, once being made to get out, if Your Honors draw the bright line there, as has been pointed out before, the police will push that limit and, in fact, once you have the valid stop of that vehicle, United States v. Sharpe and numerous other cases from this Court would probably permit about a half-an-hour, case-by-case basis, on how long you could detain, which means, Your Honor, that making the passenger get out would have the functional equivalent, particularly if there was a bright line and the police could do anything in any case, allowing the passenger to be detained, even though it started as--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, the passenger will be detained during the stop unless under Justice Souter's hypothesis the passenger is free to walk away, but it's a voluntary thing.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: It may not be too voluntary if you're out on the desert somewhere, but if you're in an airport, if you're being driven to the airport by somebody and you have a chance to catch a plane if you get a cab it might make quite a bit of difference.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But I don't see why it would necessarily follow that the passenger is detained for 30 minutes if the driver is detained for 30 minutes, under the hypothesis Justice Souter proposes.

context.speaker: Byron L. Warnken
context.text: --If this Court were to draw a bright line, Mr. Chief Justice, wherein the only authority that law enforcement had as to the passenger when there is no evidence of officer safety issues and no wrongdoing on the passengers, if the bright line were only to require that individual to get out of the car momentarily, that would perhaps be permissible.

context.speaker: Byron L. Warnken
context.text: But, Your Honor, once we've got the stop, as Your Honor points out, in most cases the individual would not have the opportunity to walk away.

context.speaker: Byron L. Warnken
context.text: Mr. Chief Justice, that's correct, but the reason Mimms is a bright line rule is a combination of officer safety and the valid underlying stop of the driver.

context.speaker: Byron L. Warnken
context.text: Mimms really requires the both of them in order to work.

context.speaker: Byron L. Warnken
context.text: This, Your Honors, would be I believe the first time this Court would ever draw this type of bright line.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, it might be the first time that we did it, but I'm not sure that it would be much of an innovation, if at all, because it seems to me that the argument you're making, and in particular in your response to Justice Breyer's last question, you're saying in effect that an officer who stops a car on a highway has less capacity to control the people around him who might hurt him or interfere with what he is validly doing than he does if he makes an arrest in a public shopping mall.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And if I'm wrong, tell me, but it seems to me you said he couldn't make him stay in the car, he couldn't make the passenger get out of the car, the passenger basically would have total freedom... in the absence of a Terry suspicion, articulable suspicion, the passenger would have total freedom to decide what to do.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: If I'm walking down the street outside this Court and an arrest is going on, I presume I don't have complete autonomy to decide whether to walk up to the officer or between the officer and the person who's getting arrested and circle the scene, so why isn't it the case that on your answer the officer is in a worse position if he stops a car on the highway than if he makes an arrest on the sidewalk?

context.speaker: Byron L. Warnken
context.text: We don't have the officer that walks the beat.

context.speaker: Byron L. Warnken
context.text: We don't have the constable in the way we once did, and most of us, when we next meet a law enforcement officer when that individual is in the line of duty, it will be when we are driver or a passenger in a vehicle.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: May I ask if... I just don't remember your brief well enough.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Do you discuss the hypothetical that Justice Souter gave you about maintaining order near an arrest scene?

context.speaker: Byron L. Warnken
context.text: No, Justice Stevens.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Isn't the proper distinction there... and I'd just like you to comment on it, because I've trying to think it through as he raised the question... that in that situation nobody's seized?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: In your situation, the passenger is seized.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: He's told to stay where he is, which is a very... at least analytically a different concept.

context.speaker: Byron L. Warnken
context.text: Justice Stevens, that's correct.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I had not understood Justice Souter's hypothesis... I thought his hypothesis you can be told to get out of the car but you can't be detained.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Once you're out of the... once you've complied with that request, you're free to leave, unless there's... there is some Terry suspicion.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I didn't express that when I put the hypo to you as distinct, I think, from the way I put it to Ms. Reno, but that's what I was assuming, that the passenger could go if he wanted to.

context.speaker: Bryan A. Stevenson
context.text: The sheriff is not anyone.

context.speaker: Bryan A. Stevenson
context.text: He is a government official.

context.speaker: Bryan A. Stevenson
context.text: He has been elected and empowered by the local government to do the conduct that we're complaining about, and under those facts and circumstances--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But as Justice Breyer pointed out in his question the supreme court of Alabama has said he is not a county official for tort purposes.

context.speaker: Bryan A. Stevenson
context.text: --For tort purposes, that's correct, Your Honor.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, this is a constitutional tort that you're suing for, isn't it?

context.speaker: Bryan A. Stevenson
context.text: That's true, Your Honor, but with regard to whether the State law immunities bind this Court, it is certainly our position that that's not true.

context.speaker: Bryan A. Stevenson
context.text: This Court has always held that Federal law cannot be decided on the way in which a State may choose to limit remedies under these kinds of actions.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, suppose it were the other way around.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Supposing the Alabama supreme court in the case that Justice Breyer has discussed said that the county is liable for what the sheriff... it seems to me that you would certainly cite that, and you would have an open and shut case.

context.speaker: Bryan A. Stevenson
context.text: Well--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: So why doesn't it work the other way around?

context.speaker: Bryan A. Stevenson
context.text: When there's a question about the discretion that the county commission has to not make payments for law enforcement functions, the sheriff is a county official that then has legal authority to make the county commission give him or her the resources to do those... do that kind of conduct.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Mr. Stevenson, I want to know who we bracket the sheriff with, and so I'd like to go back to the coroner and the tax assessor to see.

context.speaker: Bryan A. Stevenson
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Is the same... is the answer to Justice Breyer's question about respondeat superior the same thing with respect to those officers, or is the county liable for their common law torts?

context.speaker: Bryan A. Stevenson
context.text: The county is liable for the coroner's conduct.

context.speaker: Bryan A. Stevenson
context.text: I'm not aware of any State law that deals with the tax assessor in that context.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: All right, so if he's a final--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: --So if you don't... I'm sorry.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Go ahead.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Going back to Justice Souter's question before, if that's the test of the... if the question is who can control him, I suppose the people who have the greatest power, just as Justice Souter mentioned before, to control the actions of the sheriff are the county voters, because if he doesn't do the right thing they won't elect him again.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And so if that's the test, why isn't he then a county official?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Indeed, any State official who is elected on a county basis would become for Monell purposes a county official.

context.speaker: Paul M. Smith
context.text: Well, under the rule of local election I suppose they would be.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: They would be.

context.speaker: Paul M. Smith
context.text: But clearly one needs to look beyond that.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: I thought Justice Breyer said it was at least pay, local election and local pay which would distinguish your district attorney, a State judge, and your legislature, right?

context.speaker: Paul M. Smith
context.text: Your Honor, it wouldn't distinguish the local district attorney and the local district judge.

context.speaker: Paul M. Smith
context.text: They are elected locally, they work in a building that is paid for and operated by the county commission--

Metro-North Commuter Railroad Company v..speaker: Justice Souter
Metro-North Commuter Railroad Company v..case_name: Metro-North Commuter Railroad Company v. Buckley
Metro-North Commuter Railroad Company v..title: ORAL ARGUMENT - FEBRUARY 18, 1997

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And that... you're not arguing that?

context.speaker: Sheila L. Birnbaum
context.text: No.

context.speaker: Sheila L. Birnbaum
context.text: There--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: But why isn't there, then, an economic injury, just as Justice Stevens says?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: If the... if the doctor says the exposure is such that you would be crazy not to have an examination every 6 months, why... and presumably you are not crazy, so that you're going to act reasonably and you're going to have the exam... why doesn't the reasonable necessity of expending the money for the examinations every 6 months constitute an economic injury to you?

context.speaker: Sheila L. Birnbaum
context.text: --It... it maybe a damage to you, but before you can get to a damage for medical monitoring... for future medical monitoring, the courts... the common law courts have been very clear... you first have to have an injury.

Metro-North Commuter Railroad Company v..speaker: Justice Ginsburg
Metro-North Commuter Railroad Company v..case_name: Metro-North Commuter Railroad Company v. Buckley
Metro-North Commuter Railroad Company v..title: ORAL ARGUMENT - FEBRUARY 18, 1997

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: That's the argument you're making now.

context.speaker: Sheila L. Birnbaum
context.text: --I... that is the second argument.

context.speaker: Sheila L. Birnbaum
context.text: I would go back to the first argument, and except for the small number of cases in the water situation, not an asbestos exposure, where there has been no physical injury, the courts have not jumped in to provide a medical monitoring kind of--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Ms. Birnbaum, if we... if we just took the one-on-one case that Justice Stevens gave... I really don't follow your argument.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Because something happened to this person.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: No illness is manifested yet.

Metro-North Commuter Railroad Company v..speaker: Justice Rehnquist
Metro-North Commuter Railroad Company v..case_name: Metro-North Commuter Railroad Company v. Buckley
Metro-North Commuter Railroad Company v..title: ORAL ARGUMENT - FEBRUARY 18, 1997

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But... but... just a minute.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: What does that mean to say it has to be interpreted in a remedial and humanitarian fashion?

context.speaker: Charles C. Goetsch
context.text: --Okay--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: This Court used language like that, as Justice Ginsburg pointed out, years ago.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But recently we have backed off of that, to have a more neutral approach.

context.speaker: Charles C. Goetsch
context.text: --Well, what I meant, Mr. Chief Justice, was that the essential remedial purpose of the FELA is to promote safe operating conditions on the Nation's railroads by allowing recovery for... for harms and injuries that occur to... to employees--

Metro-North Commuter Railroad Company v..speaker: Justice Rehnquist
Metro-North Commuter Railroad Company v..case_name: Metro-North Commuter Railroad Company v. Buckley
Metro-North Commuter Railroad Company v..title: ORAL ARGUMENT - FEBRUARY 18, 1997

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But recently we have backed off of that, to have a more neutral approach.

context.speaker: Charles C. Goetsch
context.text: --Well, what I meant, Mr. Chief Justice, was that the essential remedial purpose of the FELA is to promote safe operating conditions on the Nation's railroads by allowing recovery for... for harms and injuries that occur to... to employees--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Okay.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I didn't... I interrupted you while you were answering Justice Breyer's question.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Why don't you return to that.

context.speaker: Charles C. Goetsch
context.text: --Okay.

Metro-North Commuter Railroad Company v..speaker: Justice Kennedy
Metro-North Commuter Railroad Company v..case_name: Metro-North Commuter Railroad Company v. Buckley
Metro-North Commuter Railroad Company v..title: ORAL ARGUMENT - FEBRUARY 18, 1997

context.speaker: Charles C. Goetsch
context.text: That is the Gottshall test.

context.speaker: Charles C. Goetsch
context.text: The plaintiffs here satisfy that test.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Mr. Goetsch, let's... let's assume they do, at least as a threshold matter.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Let me ask a question which, in a way perhaps, is somewhat similar to Justice... or gets to the same point that Justice Breyer's would.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: We heard from your opposing counsel this morning that when the exposure reaches some measurable level... and I'm not quite sure how it was measured... that OSHA would kick in with a medical monitoring remedy.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I want you to, if you will, comment on two things.

Metro-North Commuter Railroad Company v..speaker: Justice Breyer
Metro-North Commuter Railroad Company v..case_name: Metro-North Commuter Railroad Company v. Buckley
Metro-North Commuter Railroad Company v..title: ORAL ARGUMENT - FEBRUARY 18, 1997

context.speaker: Charles C. Goetsch
context.text: --Well, in--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: So what... I mean--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: --And what I'm worried about very much is what Justice Ginsburg pointed out.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I mean, to what extent, by allowing a universal cause of action for the medical, will we... for the medical testing... will we in fact interfere with the people who are undoubtedly hurt... that is, who have the disease... from getting recovery.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Is the answer to that zero?

context.speaker: Robert E. Babcock
context.text: The numerator is the wage, the denominator is the earning capacity that exists post injury.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Well, let's take a case that's not hypothetical so we won't be talking about this in the abstract.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Somebody is physically injured, a severe back and leg injury, as in this case, is promoted from the line job that he can no longer do to a manager's office, and the ALJ thinks there's a good chance, better than not chance that this guy just won't make it, and within 2, 3 years he'll be out of work.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: From the answer you've given to Justice O'Connor and Justice Scalia, I take it you would say tough luck.

context.speaker: Robert E. Babcock
context.text: No.

context.speaker: Robert E. Babcock
context.text: I would say that you may find a disability but you have to have more to give the award of compensation.

context.speaker: Robert E. Babcock
context.text: The numerator is the wage, the denominator is the earning capacity that exists post injury.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Well, let's take a case that's not hypothetical so we won't be talking about this in the abstract.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Somebody is physically injured, a severe back and leg injury, as in this case, is promoted from the line job that he can no longer do to a manager's office, and the ALJ thinks there's a good chance, better than not chance that this guy just won't make it, and within 2, 3 years he'll be out of work.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: From the answer you've given to Justice O'Connor and Justice Scalia, I take it you would say tough luck.

context.speaker: Robert E. Babcock
context.text: No.

context.speaker: Robert E. Babcock
context.text: I would say that you may find a disability but you have to have more to give the award of compensation.

context.speaker: Robert E. Babcock
context.text: As I'm sure we're all aware now, every circuit that has considered the nominal award concept has in varying degrees, ranging from that proffered by the Solicitor to the extreme version adopted by the Ninth Circuit, approved the concept as a reasonable means of assuring protections against possible harm greater than Congress built into--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: And the benefits review board hasn't rejected the concept?

context.speaker: Robert E. Babcock
context.text: --The benefits review board has historically rejected the concept as an impermissible intrusion upon the 1-year limitation.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, could you go back to Justice Breyer's question under section 22?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: What is it in the language of... let's assume that there's a significant probability that there will be a loss of earnings in the future.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: He doesn't have the earnings loss now.

context.speaker: Robert E. Babcock
context.text: Nothing in 22 prevents a nominal award, other than it sets the standard for the period of time Congress thought protection against possible harm appropriate.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But that period of time is 1 year after the last payment is made, and if a nominal award continues to be paid, then that is satisfied, correct?

context.speaker: Robert E. Babcock
context.text: No question, a nominal award gives greater protection against the future than Congress provides in section 22.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But under your theory, and Justice Kennedy's facts, you say no nominal award could be made but an award of money damages not nominal could be made.

context.speaker: Robert E. Babcock
context.text: I think not under that hypothetical.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, there's some situations in which you would agree that even though there's no present loss of earning power on appropriate evidence an award for the future could be made.

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: The ALJ can enter a nominal award, the nominal award will preserve the claimant's right to seek modification down the road, and at the same time it will avoid the risk of overcompensation that would occur if the claimant got--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Where did this come from?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Is this something the... I mean, his objection, I think, your opponent's, to this system is it's a kind of gimmick that's been hoked up here in order to create this thing, nominal awards.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: The statute says do it just the way Justice Scalia comes up with saying, and it will come to the same result in virtually every case, so why are we going through this?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: The response would be, that's how the board wants to do it, but where does it come from?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Is this something that is recent?

context.speaker: Thomas J. Pierry, III
context.text: That's true, Your Honor.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I mean, you agree that the burden in this case is on the employer, and what the employer has to show is that it's less likely than not that there will be a future impairment.

context.speaker: Thomas J. Pierry, III
context.text: Yes, Your Honor, I do.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Maybe I'm repeating a point Justice Scalia has made before, but the burden of the... in the particular proceeding seeking modification that was had in this case was one in which the employer assumed the burden of proving that there should be a complete termination of benefits, and the ALJ found that that burden of proof had been sustained.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: If that's true, that would even rule out the nominal award.

context.speaker: Thomas J. Pierry, III
context.text: Your Honor, I believe that what the ALJ... the Ninth Circuit said about the ALJ's decision was that the ALJ's decision did not take into account certain specified factors, and therefore that his decision was not supported by substantial evidence on the record considered as a whole, and I believe that the Ninth Circuit, when faced with the evidence that was presented, which really was only the increase in earnings, they decided that--

context.speaker: Thomas J. Pierry, III
context.text: However, what I would point to in this record is that the nature of the injury and the degree of physical impairment everyone concedes have remained the same as when Rambo was first awarded the disability award of 22-1/2 percent.

context.speaker: Thomas J. Pierry, III
context.text: In addition, there is testimony, as was pointed out, that he didn't know how long this higher-paying crane job would last, and--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You're relying on the fact that this is a proceeding to alter the original award.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I think Justice Ginsburg's question goes to the original award.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: What is your position as to whether an original nominal award can be made?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: What do you need to show, a probability that your wages will be lowered in the future?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Isn't that your position?

context.speaker: Thomas J. Pierry, III
context.text: No, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Thomas J. Pierry, III
context.text: I would say that our position is that since the usual employment is a specific factor that's listed in section 908(h), that really is the key determination, whether or not his injury affects or impairs his ability to perform his usual employment, his usual pre-injury employment, and here there's no argument that it did.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: No, but that will... I guess that takes me back to Justice Ginsburg's question.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Except for the employee who in fact fully recovers, your theory will always support a nominal award.

context.speaker: Thomas J. Pierry, III
context.text: I don't believe so, Your Honor, because I believe that in this case the usual employment is a broad category term, and he was a longshoreman before this accident.

context.speaker: Robert S. Smith
context.text: Justice Marshall and Justice Brenna I believe both wrote separately.

context.speaker: Robert S. Smith
context.text: Justice Brennan's decision is styled a concurrence and Justice Marshall's a dissent, but on this issue they say the same thing.

context.speaker: Robert S. Smith
context.text: They say we agree with the plurality opinion on the due process issue.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: When, in answer to Justice Stevens, you said you base your argument here in part on the prosecutor's representations, I take it your point there is that they were, in fact, misrepresentations.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Perhaps not malicious lies, but they in fact had the effect of misrepresenting the law.

context.speaker: Robert S. Smith
context.text: I would say the facts, Justice Souter, but yes.

context.speaker: Stephen R. McAllister
context.text: It would have been extraordinarily easy for Congress to have said, as compensation, which it did with the rest of that statute when it first enacted it.

context.speaker: Stephen R. McAllister
context.text: So that yes, the companions around that provision perhaps do suggest a narrower focus, but certainly in the original provision, and the substantive language itself has not changed, a broader construction is suggested.

context.speaker: Stephen R. McAllister
context.text: And again, without going back through the history, when you simply look at these provisions today, that one sits in the middle of all these other what appear to be purely compensatory provisions, but our view is, you cannot fully understand that provision or give full effect to its language without looking back to the history of it and following through how it has come through the first codification, the recodification, and how it ended up where it is today.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: So you think the history has more significance than just the contrast in the language reading the statute, as Justice Scalia would, as a whole today?

context.speaker: Stephen R. McAllister
context.text: I think both are important in the sense that the history is certainly relevant, but to the extent that provision indicates a different scope than the others, this Court should give effect to that different scope, because--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Mr. McAllister, what about the ground rule in interpreting this dense tax code?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I don't have the text right in front of me.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Is it in your brief at some point?

context.speaker: Kent L. Jones
context.text: --Yes, I'm sure that it is.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: The way Justice Blackmun described it in Burke was that the enactment allowed exclusion of punitive damages only in cases involving physical injury or physical sickness.

context.speaker: Kent L. Jones
context.text: What... at page 30 of our brief, Justice Scalia--
Okay.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Did he have any that was less?

context.speaker: Daniel Donovan
context.text: --No, none less.

context.speaker: Daniel Donovan
context.text: There were just two to pick from, basically.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Mr. Donovan, I want to get clear on what happened in this case, because in responding to Justice Stevens' question about the general rule, I think you're talking about a case which as you described it was different from what you described to me earlier.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I take it in this case you said we are prepared to stipulate.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: The Government said no, we won't stipulate.

context.speaker: Miguel A. Estrada
context.text: That flows not from a case from this Court, Justice Ginsburg, but from a recognition that the Advisory Committee note indicates that the availability of alternative means of proof is a factor that should be considered by a court in ruling on the admissibility of evidence under Rule 403, and conceivably, the existence of a stipulation that acts as an alternative means of proof, if it is, in fact, such, should be considered in keeping with what the Advisory Committee said.

context.speaker: Miguel A. Estrada
context.text: That is not to say that unless we're entering 20 judgments of conviction, or we're doing other things of the type that Rule 403 contemplates, that we're not entitled to prove our case in our own way.

context.speaker: Miguel A. Estrada
context.text: There is a vast difference in saying that the judge can keep the case moving along after considering all relevant facts and saying that we're going to have for the first time as a rule of law the proposition that the criminal defendant can dictate how the Government's case is tried, because acceptance of the latter proposition is what we're fighting here.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Let me go back... can I ask you to answer Justice O'Connor's question for a second, because I had thought that it was... you said on the question of unfair prejudice the reason that I think... and at the heart of Tavares, frankly, I think is that issue, and what we thought was the unfair prejudice was this.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Even if you assume it is relevant to show it isn't an antitrust violation, which is I guess the only way in which it's relevant, that it isn't a business violation... there was an argument in the court about that.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: We did think that there was tremendously unfair prejudice, and the reason that it was unfair prejudice was because there would be concern, as the policy of Rule 404 suggests, that a jury uncertain about whether the person committed the crime in front of them... in front of them.

context.speaker: Stephen P. Halbrook
context.text: --All available State and local records.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: May I ask you a question?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: I want to be sure I understand your position now, prompted by Justice Kennedy's question.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Supposing they amended the statute to say that all the investigations shall be done by Federal employees, FBI agents or something, but that the chief law enforcement officer of each community must make available to the Federal officer any records that will help him find out this information, would that be constitutional?

context.speaker: Stephen P. Halbrook
context.text: No, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Stephen P. Halbrook
context.text: There's always been the sharing of information voluntarily.

context.speaker: Stephen P. Halbrook
context.text: It's not a problem.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: No, but you're saying it would be unconstitutional to require that challenge.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Wasn't that your answer to Justice Stevens?

context.speaker: Stephen P. Halbrook
context.text: Yes Your Honor.

context.speaker: Stephen P. Halbrook
context.text: I don't know what the constitutional--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: That option was available in New York, and we nonetheless held that it was bad.

context.speaker: Walter E. Dellinger, III
context.text: --What Congress has done here is, I think, Justice O'Connor, not a smaller version of that large program, because they have been careful to take responsibility for the policy choices and then for the administrative policy choices.

context.speaker: Walter E. Dellinger, III
context.text: This act is administered by the Departments of Justice and Treasury, by the ATF, the FBI, by Assistant U.S. Attorneys, by the Bureau of--

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Well, I think Justice Scalia has addressed that point in exploring whether taking away the policy choices saves it.

context.speaker: Walter E. Dellinger, III
context.text: --Yes.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: The notion that the Federal Government can just commandeer State and local government totally to administer some federally enacted program, all the details of which are spelled out, is the question.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: If you are right that it's an unconstitutional delegation, there is no problem whatever.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: The whole thing boils down to the constitutional doubt of whether the cancellation provision is valid.

context.speaker: Alan B. Morrison
context.text: It can also affect bills that the President may choose, for whatever reason, not to exercise his power of cancellation over.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: No, but... but isn't Justice Scalia correct in the way he states your position?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I... I want to understand this.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Isn't it your position and your client's position that there is now a cloud, a sword of Damocles, hanging over the legislation, that the dynamic is altered because of this constitutional... constitutionally questionable procedure, and that is what gives them the standing now to come in?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Could... would there be any problem about that being constitutional for... for Congress to restrain itself by doing, either through rules or perhaps a statute, saying that there can be no riders attached to an appropriation bill?

context.speaker: Alan B. Morrison
context.text: I don't know how that could be enforced.

context.speaker: Alan B. Morrison
context.text: But... and without having thought about it more, I... I think it would probably be... what would concern me was that somehow you're restricting the rights of members... members to... to put in the bills what... what they choose.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Morrison, let's go back for a minute to Justice Scalia's question about there being no injury here if in fact the... that would really do away with all of our declaratory judgment jurisprudence, would it not, to accept that, if you... you can't bring a declaratory judgment, because if the statute you're attacking is unconstitutional, they can't do anything to you anyway?

context.speaker: Alan B. Morrison
context.text: I had not thought of that, but it certainly seems that it would... would put a big dent in it, Mr. Chief Justice.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: May... may I go back to another point?

context.speaker: Alan B. Morrison
context.text: Surely, Adam Clayton Powell's exclusion from the House of Representatives was not simply about money.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Well, but a total exclusion of a member, that deprives him of the emoluments of the office... can't get paid, can't take a seat... that may well be different.

context.speaker: Alan B. Morrison
context.text: I don't believe that... the Powell case would have come out differently if the House of Representatives had continued to pay him his salary during the time that they excluded him.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: There is also a difference, Mr. Morrison, as Justice Ginsburg was suggesting, between a provision adopted by the whole body that affects only an individual member and a provision adopted by the body, such as a rule change, such as this law, which affects all the members of the House and all the members of the... of the Senate equal.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Isn't that a distinction that can be taken into account in determining whether there is standing?

context.speaker: Alan B. Morrison
context.text: It may be... it may have some... some bearing on it.

Regents of University of California v. D.speaker: Justice Scalia
Regents of University of California v. D.case_name: Regents of University of California v. Doe
Regents of University of California v. D.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 02, 1996

context.speaker: Richard Gayer
context.text: There's too much risk.

context.speaker: Richard Gayer
context.text: It's not worth the risk.

context.speaker: Richard Gayer
context.text: The Department of Energy wants to use the good and prestigious name of the University of California to attract talented scientists, technical professionals to work on Government projects, and the DOE has determined that it's to its advantage to get a prestigious name, and the DOE is willing to pay for it.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Aside from the fact that the university would pay for a private insurance policy, is there any other feature that would distinguish Justice O'Connor's question from the case before us?

context.speaker: Richard Gayer
context.text: Thank you, Justice Scalia, yes, there's an important distinction here, I think, that in general an indemnitor such as an insurance company is quite separate from the contract, say, between the Government and the Regents corporation.

context.speaker: Richard Gayer
context.text: It would be some outside insurance company that would be agreeing to indemnify.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: It would not be at all unreasonable or unlawful for the Park Service to say, you have got to screen for age.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: You have got to require people to show adult ID.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: You have got to cover the--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But that's in the commercial context, and Justice Breyer's question and my following question pertained to people that don't have counsel, that aren't broadcasters or regular Net users which understand what the concepts of decency or indecency are in any institutional sense, and conversations between two minors, between a minor and an adult, between two adults on public streets and public places would all be prohibited, it seems to me, under your analysis in this case.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: --It's... I think the analogy here really is to Renton and Young.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: This is really a zoning issue.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: This is really a zoning issue.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: Let me give you an example.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: Let's assume on the Mall--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: May I suggest... before... it seems to me that the case that Justice Kennedy poses is a more difficult case, but isn't the reason that... I don't think people throughout the country are worried about their kids hanging around conversations going on on the public street.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Isn't the scope of the risk involved very much related to what the Government can do by way of avoiding that risk?

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: --I don't think there's any question about it.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: The notion in those laws... this is my second point... of what is offensive was I think subject to a very serious vagueness challenge.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: What we have here is a definition of patently offensive material that is not vague, that has been held by this Court and the FCC and the lower courts not to be constitutionally vague, and we have set out at page 17 of our reply brief pretty much in haec verba what a jury would have to be instructed in determining whether something was patently offensive under their prevailing community standards.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: And added onto that we also have now, in light of Miller, and Jenkins, and Hamling, and Ferber, this Court's unequivocal statement that in the area of patently offensive, where First... where there is a First Amendment implication on where the floor is drawn, the Court will and must draw a constitutional floor below which juries and legislatures can't go, so we have a standard here that has been accepted, and can be refined by this or other courts.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Mr. Waxman, let me ask you another question more or less along the lines, I guess, of Justice Breyer's, who spoke of the high school students who might go to prison.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: If we combine the display section and the knowingly permit section, I take it that a parent who allowed his computer, the computer that the parent owned, to be used by his child in viewing offensive material, indecent material, the parent would also go to prison, I take it.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: I don't see why that would... maybe I'm missing something--

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: --It wouldn't any more be grabbing it out of--
Exclude parents--

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: --Let me just say, it wouldn't, because there's a very clear record before Congress that what Congress was concerned about was not protecting children from their parents, but protecting children and their parents from the children getting access to material that the children--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: --I could view this but Justice Scalia couldn't.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: --No, I think Justice--

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The opinion of the Court in No. 96-511, Reno versus American Civil Liberty Union will be announced by Justice Stevens.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: This case comes to us by way of appeal from a three-judge District Court in the Eastern District of Pennsylvania which held a federal statute unconstitutional.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: The statute is the Communications Decency Act of 1996 which reported to preclude indecent and sexually offensive material off of the internet to the extent that they would be available to minors.

Reno v. Bossier Parish School Board.speaker: Justice Kennedy
Reno v. Bossier Parish School Board.case_name: Reno v. Bossier Parish School Board
Reno v. Bossier Parish School Board.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 09, 1996

context.speaker: Deval L. Patrick
context.text: --process.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: --Are you certain that the district court here meant to exclude evidence that he called relevant to the section 2, meant to... was he saying, I'm not even going to consider that when I think about whether section 5 is violated, or is he saying, you can't build a section 5 case out of only that?

context.speaker: Deval L. Patrick
