context.text: Well, we're certainly not contending that you can build a section 5 out of only... section 5 case out of only that, but frankly there is no way to understand the district court's opinion by saying that it won't consider for section 5 purposes evidence that's relevant to section 2 on a record where all of the evidence is relevant both to section 2 and section 5, as other than... meaning the purpose prong of section 5 as other than--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: What is the evidence... and this was what Justice Scalia asked at the very first, and--

context.speaker: Deval L. Patrick
context.text: --Yes.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --I wasn't sure that you completed your answer, and it's relevant to what you're discussing now with Justice Breyer.

Reno v. Bossier Parish School Board.speaker: Justice Kennedy
Reno v. Bossier Parish School Board.case_name: Reno v. Bossier Parish School Board
Reno v. Bossier Parish School Board.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 09, 1996

context.speaker: Deval L. Patrick
context.text: Well, we're certainly not contending that you can build a section 5 out of only... section 5 case out of only that, but frankly there is no way to understand the district court's opinion by saying that it won't consider for section 5 purposes evidence that's relevant to section 2 on a record where all of the evidence is relevant both to section 2 and section 5, as other than... meaning the purpose prong of section 5 as other than--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: What is the evidence... and this was what Justice Scalia asked at the very first, and--

context.speaker: Deval L. Patrick
context.text: --Yes.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --I wasn't sure that you completed your answer, and it's relevant to what you're discussing now with Justice Breyer.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: What is the evidence, other than bloc voting, that should have been considered and that was not?

context.speaker: Deval L. Patrick
context.text: That no black person had ever been elected to the school board.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Is that statute, those two statutes constitutional, where the magistrate relieves the officer of the decision to be made on the spot by authorizing in the warrant a no-knock search if these conditions... if the magistrate finds these conditions present, that the property sought can be quickly destroyed, or that there's danger to life and limb of the officer or another?

context.speaker: David R. Karpe
context.text: Justice Ginsburg, I think if there's a specific indication that there is danger to the officer, that would be acceptable.

context.speaker: David R. Karpe
context.text: To say it can be easily destroyed I think goes too far and leads to procrustean application, because we can't deny that many drugs, particularly in small quantities, can easily be destroyed.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And yet that is a standard reason for applying the exigent circumstances doctrine, and if exigent circumstances may be applied, why can't the kind of pre-warrant determination that the statute refers to and that Justice Ginsburg refers to?

context.speaker: David R. Karpe
context.text: Justice Souter, I think that it leads to a danger in application--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, there's a danger in application, I suppose, to exigent circumstances, because it depends upon a judgment made on the spot.

context.speaker: Allen M. Lenchek
context.text: --Well, he could threaten not to give any reference--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Yeah, but can you speak for the... can you speak for the Respondent on that issue?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: The Respondent's literal, plain language argument, it seems to me, applies there as well as here.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: How... how do you know the Respondent will agree with Justice Kennedy's suggestion?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: I don't think you have authority to say that.

context.speaker: Allen M. Lenchek
context.text: --No, I... I'd like to reserve the balance of my time.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Very well.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Very well, Mr. Lenchek.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: You'll let Justice Stevens and Justice Kennedy fight that out between themselves is what you mean?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Wolfson.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We'll hear from you Mr. Wolfson.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Very well.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Very well, Mr. Lenchek.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: You'll let Justice Stevens and Justice Kennedy fight that out between themselves is what you mean?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Wolfson.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We'll hear from you Mr. Wolfson.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: There has been--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: --How do you resolve the... excuse me--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: --Go ahead.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: How do you resolve the debate between Justice Kennedy and me?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Is an... is a retired employee who's getting a pension still an employee?

context.speaker: Lawrence C. Butler
context.text: No.

context.speaker: Lawrence C. Butler
context.text: But I do think that it... it's a strained argument to suggest that "employee" means different things in different places within the Act.

context.speaker: Lawrence C. Butler
context.text: And to... for the EEOC to insist--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Yeah, but you've just admitted that.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I mean, in response to Justice Scalia's attempt to help you out, you said, Well, yeah, that's right; I'd accept that argument.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: You're... you're not going to... you're not going to kick him now, are you?

context.speaker: Lawrence C. Butler
context.text: They'd either issue no references, all good references, or all bad references.

context.speaker: Lawrence C. Butler
context.text: Because if they do anything else, they're setting themselves up for a claim of retaliation by anyone who had previously filed a charge, valid or not.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: That's true.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But as... as... as Justice Ginsburg points out, that problem isn't... isn't entirely solved by how we come out on this case.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Because you do have the problem of references for current employees.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: And... and you do subject yourself--

Saratoga Fishing Company v. J. M. Martin.speaker: Justice Scalia
Saratoga Fishing Company v. J. M. Martin.case_name: Saratoga Fishing Company v. J. M. Martinac & Company
Saratoga Fishing Company v. J. M. Martin.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - FEBRUARY 18, 1997

context.speaker: Keith Zakarin
context.text: That's the Shipco case out of the Fifth Circuit.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: That would be the case where the engine manufacturer produces his own screws.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I guess that is unusual.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I think Justice Breyer was giving you the case where there are screws in the engine, but the engine manufacturer gets the screw from, you know--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: --Yes.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: --Screws Unlimited or something, the screw manufacturer.

Saratoga Fishing Company v. J. M. Martin.speaker: Justice Souter
Saratoga Fishing Company v. J. M. Martin.case_name: Saratoga Fishing Company v. J. M. Martinac & Company
Saratoga Fishing Company v. J. M. Martin.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - FEBRUARY 18, 1997

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: The screw was not sold to an ultimate user, since it was sold to a manufacturer of an engine.

context.speaker: Keith Zakarin
context.text: You're quite correct, Justice Scalia.

context.speaker: Keith Zakarin
context.text: In fact, as I referred to the Shipco case, here was an attempt out of the Fifth Circuit which is illustrative, an attempt to get the component manufacturer for a part that they had put in the engine, and that was a specific end around, as it were, the East River, and the Fifth Circuit stopped it cold and said no, it is the negotiated, final, complete product that left that particular shipyard which is the product itself, and there was no property in that particular case outside of that.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: So I guess you're saying in answer to Justice Scalia's first question way back earlier on in the argument... I think you're saying that the capacity of the end user to contract is basically irrelevant.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: There's simply got to be a conventional line, and the conventional line which would work as well as any other is the one that we've already given at least some lip service to, and that's the 402A line.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: So it's not a... it doesn't turn on the power to contract.

Saratoga Fishing Company v. J. M. Martin.speaker: Justice Kennedy
Saratoga Fishing Company v. J. M. Martin.case_name: Saratoga Fishing Company v. J. M. Martinac & Company
Saratoga Fishing Company v. J. M. Martin.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - FEBRUARY 18, 1997

context.speaker: Keith Zakarin
context.text: Then that's correct.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: --Do you see the... I'm looking for a line.

context.speaker: Keith Zakarin
context.text: If I'm understanding your question--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Is your answer to Justice Breyer's question that Madruga is not in the business of making engines and machines, and he's not even in the business of reselling boats.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: He happened to sell this one boat.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Is that the answer?

Saratoga Fishing Company v. J. M. Martin.speaker: Justice Ginsburg
Saratoga Fishing Company v. J. M. Martin.case_name: Saratoga Fishing Company v. J. M. Martinac & Company
Saratoga Fishing Company v. J. M. Martin.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - FEBRUARY 18, 1997

context.speaker: Daniel B. MacLeod
context.text: That is absolutely correct.

context.speaker: Daniel B. MacLeod
context.text: There was also a balancing test suggested in the products liability cases in the consumer context to the extent that a manufacturer can, with very slight price increases, protect himself against that through the purchase of insurance, and I suggest that that's not economically available in the context of a manufacturer of a vessel where, if the price were increased to accommodate additional insurance the shipyard would become--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But your--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: --Mr. Macleod, I didn't understand your answer to Justice Scalia, because I didn't understand you to be contesting that if Vargas, the second purchaser, bought all new equipment, a new seine, a new boat, that would be other property, would it not, for which the manufacturer would be liable?

context.speaker: Daniel B. MacLeod
context.text: --I would... no, Your Honor.
No?

Saratoga Fishing Company v. J. M. Martin.speaker: Justice Rehnquist
Saratoga Fishing Company v. J. M. Martin.case_name: Saratoga Fishing Company v. J. M. Martinac & Company
Saratoga Fishing Company v. J. M. Martin.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - FEBRUARY 18, 1997

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I don't think you can by contract restrict tort liability for people who aren't parties to the contract.

context.speaker: Daniel B. MacLeod
context.text: I... that's not my position, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Daniel B. MacLeod
context.text: I think your statement is exactly correct, and exactly why we should be looking at the benefit of the bargain to what the purchaser acquired.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But I thought you had said in answer to Justice Scalia's question that the purchaser could... the manufacturer could protect himself from liability, tort liability simply by contracting with the purchaser.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: You don't mean--

context.speaker: Daniel B. MacLeod
context.text: In the hands of the first purchaser.

Saratoga Fishing Company v. J. M. Martin.speaker: Justice Ginsburg
Saratoga Fishing Company v. J. M. Martin.case_name: Saratoga Fishing Company v. J. M. Martinac & Company
Saratoga Fishing Company v. J. M. Martin.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - FEBRUARY 18, 1997

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: The product then includes the second skiff, and there wouldn't be product liability vis-a-vis the original manufacturer.

context.speaker: Daniel B. MacLeod
context.text: Yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Okay.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Mr. Macleod, is the response you gave to Justice Stevens before, is that settled law, that if there is a contract running between Madruga and Vargas, a warranty, and Madruga pays, that Madruga could not go back against the manufacturer for the... what would have been other property in Madruga's ownership period?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Is that settled?

context.speaker: Daniel B. MacLeod
context.text: I think it is, and I think it's a matter of contract law.

Saratoga Fishing Company v. J. M. Martin.speaker: Justice Scalia
Saratoga Fishing Company v. J. M. Martin.case_name: Saratoga Fishing Company v. J. M. Martinac & Company
Saratoga Fishing Company v. J. M. Martin.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - FEBRUARY 18, 1997

context.speaker: Daniel B. MacLeod
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Yes, okay.

context.speaker: Daniel B. MacLeod
context.text: And I would foreclose recovery for the loss of that thing, whatever it is, that's the object of the bargain and the economic losses that flow from the loss of the benefit of the bargain or the destruction of that thing.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: And you acknowledge that the recovery for the skiff and the recovery for the personal injury in the hypothetical that Justice Souter just gave you would be tort recovery and not contract recovery.

context.speaker: Daniel B. MacLeod
context.text: Yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Well, that contradicts what you said earlier.

Schenck v. Pro-Choice Network of Western.speaker: Justice Rehnquist
Schenck v. Pro-Choice Network of Western.case_name: Schenck v. Pro-Choice Network of Western New York
Schenck v. Pro-Choice Network of Western.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 16, 1996

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Oh, I doubt it.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: Lucinda M. Finley
context.text: That discussion was... yes, Your Honor, that discussion was linked to the noise provision, but the same interest pertains when people are having others screaming in their face.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, what about a situation such as Justice Kennedy posits, where you walk through a picket line to go to work, and you've got a very important assignment that day, and you feel you're subjected to a great deal of stress, you're not going to be able to do that work.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Now, is that kind of a separate governmental interest that has to be taken into consideration, too?

context.speaker: Lucinda M. Finley
context.text: Whether the protest conduct disrupts the safe and normal functioning of the place is a basic governmental interest that this Court has recognized many times in Grayned v. Rockford on, so I think yes, whether--

Schenck v. Pro-Choice Network of Western.speaker: Justice Stevens
Schenck v. Pro-Choice Network of Western.case_name: Schenck v. Pro-Choice Network of Western New York
Schenck v. Pro-Choice Network of Western.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 16, 1996

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: They could have four each, 15 feet apart.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: It would take care of a four-lane highway.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: I don't know why Justice Kennedy limits it to two.

context.speaker: Lucinda M. Finley
context.text: --I think you're alluding to the notion of the floating bubble, and I want to remind this Court that judges under a Federal statute, 18 U.S.C. 1507, have what amounts to a floating bubble around any building or residence you use or occupy.

context.speaker: Lucinda M. Finley
context.text: People can't go near--

Schenck v. Pro-Choice Network of Western.speaker: Justice Breyer
Schenck v. Pro-Choice Network of Western.case_name: Schenck v. Pro-Choice Network of Western New York
Schenck v. Pro-Choice Network of Western.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 16, 1996

context.speaker: Walter E. Dellinger, III
context.text: The actual controversy itself, the actual proceedings were continuous and, of course, they were under, as several justices noted, under a TRO, so that, you know, ideally they're... they... there shouldn't have been any.

context.speaker: Walter E. Dellinger, III
context.text: What the judge did in this case, faced with this situation and trying to give some kind of guidance that would be useful to the parties, to the police, is to set what Justice Ginsburg called a keep-your-distance rule.

context.speaker: Walter E. Dellinger, III
context.text: Basically--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: In answer to Justice Kennedy and Justice O'Connor, and I wonder, I'm just asking this, is it relevant to consider this is not labor picketing or civil rights picketing because the people by and large are pregnant women who are undergoing a serious medical procedure.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: You haven't brought that up, and I wonder the extent to which that is constitutionally relevant.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I would think it might be.

Schenck v. Pro-Choice Network of Western.speaker: Justice Breyer
Schenck v. Pro-Choice Network of Western.case_name: Schenck v. Pro-Choice Network of Western New York
Schenck v. Pro-Choice Network of Western.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 16, 1996

context.speaker: Walter E. Dellinger, III
context.text: The actual controversy itself, the actual proceedings were continuous and, of course, they were under, as several justices noted, under a TRO, so that, you know, ideally they're... they... there shouldn't have been any.

context.speaker: Walter E. Dellinger, III
context.text: What the judge did in this case, faced with this situation and trying to give some kind of guidance that would be useful to the parties, to the police, is to set what Justice Ginsburg called a keep-your-distance rule.

context.speaker: Walter E. Dellinger, III
context.text: Basically--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: In answer to Justice Kennedy and Justice O'Connor, and I wonder, I'm just asking this, is it relevant to consider this is not labor picketing or civil rights picketing because the people by and large are pregnant women who are undergoing a serious medical procedure.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: You haven't brought that up, and I wonder the extent to which that is constitutionally relevant.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I would think it might be.

Schenck v. Pro-Choice Network of Western.speaker: Justice Souter
Schenck v. Pro-Choice Network of Western.case_name: Schenck v. Pro-Choice Network of Western New York
Schenck v. Pro-Choice Network of Western.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 16, 1996

context.speaker: Walter E. Dellinger, III
context.text: If you read... if you read the preliminary injunction at pages 183 and--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Mr. Dellinger, may I interrupt you--

context.speaker: Walter E. Dellinger, III
context.text: --Yes.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: --because I think you're going on to another point, and I just want to raise another point along Justice Breyer's lines.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Is your argument that when the State is... or when the court is enforcing, let's say, a trespassing law, in determining what would be an appropriate injunction to enforce that star to preclude threatened violations, it may take into consideration the activities of the victims, and if the activity of the victim may be to obtain medical treatment, then high blood pressure can be taken into account.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Is that basically your argument?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: As a practical matter, though, we do know the answer.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: They'd apply State law, wouldn't they?

context.speaker: Melody L. McCoy
context.text: This tribe has no substantive body of law, that's--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And yet if the tribal court has jurisdiction, that is a real question, isn't it, as to which body of law would be applied, for the very reason that Justice Ginsburg raised.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: They might say, well, we're going to apply tribal law.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: At the present time, tribal law follows State law, but we could develop tribal law, and our general rule will be that we're going to apply tribal law.

context.speaker: Patrick J. Ward
context.text: In using the State highway on this occasion, Mr. Stockert did not give up his rights to due process, equal protection or trial by a jury of his peers.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: So the result would be different if the accident had occurred inside the reservation, on a reservation road, not a road on which the State had a perpetual easement?

context.speaker: Patrick J. Ward
context.text: Not necessarily, Your Honor, not in an incidence involving two nonmembers of the tribe.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: So then you're not relying on, as Justice Souter spoke, this case could be... could be described as a State highway case, and that would be the end of it, but I think you're telling us now that... that even if it occurred on a reservation road, there would not be tribal jurisdiction.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Is that what you're saying?

context.speaker: Patrick J. Ward
context.text: Your Honor, yes.

context.speaker: Patrick J. Ward
context.text: And in those treaties, the tribe has historically recognized the right of safe passage for people passing through the reservation.

context.speaker: Patrick J. Ward
context.text: If... if one looks at those treaties, those treaties... never... if you look at the common notions of the day at the time that those treaties were entered into, these tribes, from the time almost 20 years after Lewis and Clark to this day, realized that there would be rights of way, there would be people passing through, and they would not interfere with the rights of those people passing through.

context.speaker: Patrick J. Ward
context.text: And if--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --some of the same questions that Justice Scalia is raising.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Could Congress authorize this jurisdiction?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Is that question before us?

context.speaker: Patrick J. Ward
context.text: It was... it was legislative, but the sovereignty of a tribe, whether it's legislative or adjudicative, comes from the same place.

context.speaker: Patrick J. Ward
context.text: It comes from whatever retained inherent sovereignty remained after the tribes were incorporated into the United States.

context.speaker: Patrick J. Ward
context.text: And as this Court has recognized in Oliphant and Wheeler, for purposes of criminal jurisdiction, there is no tribal sovereignty, and the tribe could not, as in some of the earlier examples, exercise any criminal jurisdiction over either of the parties here because they were both nonmembers of the tribe.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: But may I go back to a... to an answer... to a question from Justice Kennedy?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: You said, well, even if Congress provided by statute that there would be jurisdiction in the tribal court in... in this case, that there would... there would or could... I'm not sure which you said... still be a due process problem.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Did you mean by that simply that you might still raise a due process challenge to the particular manner in which the... the court offices were appointed or the jurors selected or whatnot?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, can I... is there a law report or something that I can read to find these examples?

context.speaker: Patrick J. Ward
context.text: --There... there are some law review articles on the subject, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Patrick J. Ward
context.text: The best, I think, would be the amicus brief of the Burlington Northern Railroad in this case, and the American Automobile Association--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Mr. Ward, do you agree that if we take what Justice Souter suggested might be a rule of the road here... that is, if it's an interstate highway, it's a State highway, then the State... this case belongs in State court and State law will apply.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But we don't get into any of these other questions that might arise if this accident occurred on a road within the reservation?

context.speaker: Patrick J. Ward
context.text: --That's true.

context.speaker: Patrick J. Ward
context.text: They have access to the courts in the State--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But, Mr. Ward, here's a question of concurrent jurisdiction.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: And isn't this... this kind of case can only come up if the plaintiff... even if a nonmember would have a real close affiliation with the tribe.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: In the cases Justice Breyer was suggesting, it's the plaintiff's choice of forum.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Most non-Indians probably wouldn't go to the tribal court in this kind of accident.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But this non-Indian had a very close relationship with the tribe.

context.speaker: Patrick J. Ward
context.text: Yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Patrick J. Ward
context.text: The only rights reserved to the tribe in the easement were the right to create crossings for purposes of approaches to farms and things like that.

context.speaker: Patrick J. Ward
context.text: Otherwise, the easement gave the State the rights to the surface of the road.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Do you know of any case where a tribe claims exclusive jurisdiction, which I believe is what Justice Breyer was suggesting... claim exclusive jurisdiction as distinguished from concurrent jurisdiction with the State over a tort that happens on a highway or on fee land?

context.speaker: Patrick J. Ward
context.text: I'm not aware of any case from this Court, Your Honor, where the tribe has--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But do you know of any tribe that has asserted exclusive jurisdiction as distinguished from concurrent jurisdiction, where the plaintiff chooses the forum?

context.speaker: Patrick J. Ward
context.text: And this Court decided no, it did not; that it did not retain that regulatory control.

context.speaker: Patrick J. Ward
context.text: And it further decided that that kind of control was not part of the tribe's inherent sovereignty.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Only over non-Indians, you would say, though.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: So, I mean, your highway principle that Justice Souter was discussing with you would only apply to regulation of non-Indians on the highway?

context.speaker: Patrick J. Ward
context.text: Well, Your Honor, this... this Court has never decided whether an easement or an alienation of land would give up the authority over the tribal members.

context.speaker: Patrick J. Ward
context.text: I don't think it goes that far.

Suitum v. Tahoe Regional Planning Agency.speaker: Justice Scalia
Suitum v. Tahoe Regional Planning Agency.case_name: Suitum v. Tahoe Regional Planning Agency
Suitum v. Tahoe Regional Planning Agency.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - FEBRUARY 26, 1997

context.speaker: R. S. Radford
context.text: We want to know that we have a certain claim.

context.speaker: R. S. Radford
context.text: We want to know that the regulations have been applied with certainty so that we can proceed with the adjudication.

context.speaker: R. S. Radford
context.text: We have certainty.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Mr. Radford, could I take you back to the line of questioning that Justice O'Connor began with?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You said that none of these TDR's preexisted the asserted taking here.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: That is, the denial of the building authorization.

Suitum v. Tahoe Regional Planning Agency.speaker: Justice Souter
Suitum v. Tahoe Regional Planning Agency.case_name: Suitum v. Tahoe Regional Planning Agency
Suitum v. Tahoe Regional Planning Agency.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - FEBRUARY 26, 1997

context.speaker: Richard J. Lazarus
context.text: It's different from the present case because of the uniqueness of TDR's.

context.speaker: Richard J. Lazarus
context.text: In a case like that--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: No, but you are creating the uniqueness.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I mean, you are supplying the ingredient which Justice Scalia referred to as being up in the mountains without any comparable sales, and the only thing that is unique is that, in creating the TDR scheme, you have created the problem.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Why should the landowner have to wait because you created something which is difficult to value?

context.speaker: Richard J. Lazarus
context.text: --Well, the landowner shouldn't have to wait if there would be any undue hardship, but what you have here is a question for the court.

Suitum v. Tahoe Regional Planning Agency.speaker: Justice Souter
Suitum v. Tahoe Regional Planning Agency.case_name: Suitum v. Tahoe Regional Planning Agency
Suitum v. Tahoe Regional Planning Agency.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - FEBRUARY 26, 1997

context.speaker: Richard J. Lazarus
context.text: One of the most important things of prudential ripeness is the fitness of the issue for the court to decide, and the court here simply wanted to decide this very important as-applied takings case based on the better evidence possible.

context.speaker: Richard J. Lazarus
context.text: The court--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I can't think of any ripeness case I've ever read, and maybe you can cite one, but I can't think of any ripeness case I've ever read in which a factor like this made a difference.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I mean, because of what Justice Scalia said.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: The agency isn't likely to change.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: They're not going to change anything, and of course it would be a little easier if we had better evidence about what these TDR's are worth, but is there any case which said because you can get better valuation evidence later--

Suitum v. Tahoe Regional Planning Agency.speaker: Justice Breyer
Suitum v. Tahoe Regional Planning Agency.case_name: Suitum v. Tahoe Regional Planning Agency
Suitum v. Tahoe Regional Planning Agency.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - FEBRUARY 26, 1997

context.speaker: Lawrence G. Wallace
context.text: She's seeking a permit to build on this lot.

context.speaker: Lawrence G. Wallace
context.text: She is seeking equitable relief.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: --But you... could you answer Justice O'Connor's question, because I have a distinct feeling perhaps the answer is neither the Government nor the respondent mind if this Court were to say, it's ripe.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: We're not expressing any view on the merits... none... and all she is arguing is that in fact under these circumstances she gets definite rights of TDR's and her property can't be built on.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: She says that constitutes a taking.

Timmons v. Twin Cities Area New Party.speaker: Justice Kennedy
Timmons v. Twin Cities Area New Party.case_name: Timmons v. Twin Cities Area New Party
Timmons v. Twin Cities Area New Party.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 04, 1996

context.speaker: Richard S. Slowes
context.text: In fact, we don't elect parties at the elections, we elect candidates.

context.speaker: Richard S. Slowes
context.text: We use the ballot to decide which of these candidates is going to hold the official office that the election is for.

context.speaker: Richard S. Slowes
context.text: In fact, if Mr. Dawkins were elected on the DFL ballot, or as a DFLer, there's nothing that prevents him from the next day turning around and becoming a Republican.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I'm interested in Justice Stevens' question.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Where we are so far is, it was suggested first by Justice Scalia that it might be important for the State to determine which party garners the most votes, and then you were asked a question, well, couldn't we presume that the preemininent party gets the votes.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I very much doubt that minor parties would agree with such a presumption.

Timmons v. Twin Cities Area New Party.speaker: Justice Kennedy
Timmons v. Twin Cities Area New Party.case_name: Timmons v. Twin Cities Area New Party
Timmons v. Twin Cities Area New Party.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 04, 1996

context.speaker: Richard S. Slowes
context.text: We use the ballot to decide which of these candidates is going to hold the official office that the election is for.

context.speaker: Richard S. Slowes
context.text: In fact, if Mr. Dawkins were elected on the DFL ballot, or as a DFLer, there's nothing that prevents him from the next day turning around and becoming a Republican.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I'm interested in Justice Stevens' question.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Where we are so far is, it was suggested first by Justice Scalia that it might be important for the State to determine which party garners the most votes, and then you were asked a question, well, couldn't we presume that the preemininent party gets the votes.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I very much doubt that minor parties would agree with such a presumption.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And then you said, well, that's not really our interest.

Timmons v. Twin Cities Area New Party.speaker: Justice Kennedy
Timmons v. Twin Cities Area New Party.case_name: Timmons v. Twin Cities Area New Party
Timmons v. Twin Cities Area New Party.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 04, 1996

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And then you said, well, that's not really our interest.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: That's a side thing.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: We're talking about, really, the whole election dynamic.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And then Justice Stevens said, well, what is your particular interest, and I never did get the answer to that.

context.speaker: Richard S. Slowes
context.text: I'm sorry, Justice Kennedy, I--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, you've had a number of questions, but--

Timmons v. Twin Cities Area New Party.speaker: Justice Souter
Timmons v. Twin Cities Area New Party.case_name: Timmons v. Twin Cities Area New Party
Timmons v. Twin Cities Area New Party.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 04, 1996

context.speaker: Richard S. Slowes
context.text: --There is a balancing that has to be done, Justice Scalia.

context.speaker: Richard S. Slowes
context.text: We believe, and this Court has recognized in some cases that, indeed, and that's part of what was animating Storer in some sense, that the State does have an interest, a generalized interest in preserving, in a sense, political stability, and that--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, are you... maybe I misunderstood your argument.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I didn't understand you to be putting any weight on the, in effect the preservation of a major two-party system as such, so I just didn't think... I mean, Justice Scalia has raised a good point, but I didn't think it was the point that you were making.

context.speaker: Richard S. Slowes
context.text: --Your Honor, I didn't make that point, and in honesty I don't make that point strongly.

context.speaker: Richard S. Slowes
context.text: I think that is... I think that is--

Turner Broadcasting System, Inc. v. Fede.speaker: Justice Ginsburg
Turner Broadcasting System, Inc. v. Fede.case_name: Turner Broadcasting System, Inc. v. Federal Communications Commission
Turner Broadcasting System, Inc. v. Fede.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 07, 1996

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: We'd have to know the differential to make a... yeah, to make a--

context.speaker: H. Bartow Farr, III
context.text: That's right.

context.speaker: H. Bartow Farr, III
context.text: So I mean, that's simply a factor of numbers in competition, even without respect to cable.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: --Following up Justice Kennedy's question, from the cable operator's side, is this a diminishing problem to the extent that there is a problem with must-carry as cable, as the channel capacity expands, this becomes less and less of a problem?

context.speaker: H. Bartow Farr, III
context.text: Well, unfortunately, it has not become less and less of a problem to date.

context.speaker: H. Bartow Farr, III
context.text: I think anyone who is familiar with the cable industry at the moment knows that channel space is greatly at a premium within the industry as a whole.

Turner Broadcasting System, Inc. v. Fede.speaker: Justice Souter
Turner Broadcasting System, Inc. v. Fede.case_name: Turner Broadcasting System, Inc. v. Federal Communications Commission
Turner Broadcasting System, Inc. v. Fede.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 07, 1996

context.speaker: H. Bartow Farr, III
context.text: If you look at the cable operators themselves, TCI, which is the largest cable operator, has an interest in something like 20 cable programmers.

context.speaker: H. Bartow Farr, III
context.text: Time Warner, after its merger with Turner, is somewhere around a dozen.

context.speaker: H. Bartow Farr, III
context.text: The others are all... there may be four or five that have interests in about four or five programmers, and the rest the cable operators typically have no interest.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Mr. Farr, may I go back to the subject of Justice Ginsburg's question?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: My recollection is that the figure in the record was that when must-carry came in, about, I think it was 6 percent of cable operators had to drop at least one program in order to comply with must-carry.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: The suggestion was that that figure perhaps is not wholly representative of the significance of must-carry because there was evidence that the cable operators were sort of on their good behavior before that, but in any case we got a figure of about 6 percent.

Turner Broadcasting System, Inc. v. Fede.speaker: Justice Ginsburg
Turner Broadcasting System, Inc. v. Fede.case_name: Turner Broadcasting System, Inc. v. Federal Communications Commission
Turner Broadcasting System, Inc. v. Fede.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 07, 1996

context.speaker: H. Bartow Farr, III
context.text: In fact, I agree that they can promote it in general.

context.speaker: H. Bartow Farr, III
context.text: What I'm saying is, though, that when they come to the question of means, how they are doing it, when they say the means by which we are going to promote it are to limit the speech rights of others, then they're running up against a barrier that the First Amendment imposes.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Mr. Farr, suppose... this is not a hypothetical.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: It comes from Justice O'Connor's opinion last time around... the Government simply said, to the extent that you have unused channels, just to that extent, you must carry, so you can't leave any channels idle, but if you fill them up with cable programmers, whatever, that's okay.

context.speaker: H. Bartow Farr, III
context.text: Obviously, that would be a less restrictive alternative, there's no question about that.

context.speaker: H. Bartow Farr, III
context.text: I think in fairness I should make two points, though.

Turner Broadcasting System, Inc. v. Fede.speaker: Justice Souter
Turner Broadcasting System, Inc. v. Fede.case_name: Turner Broadcasting System, Inc. v. Federal Communications Commission
Turner Broadcasting System, Inc. v. Fede.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 07, 1996

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: You're saying, we will compare the programming, and it will be better programming, I presume, by some governmental judgment.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: You're turning this into a content-based justification, aren't you?

context.speaker: Walter E. Dellinger, III
context.text: --One of the virtues of the must-carry system as compared to what the cable industry suggests as an alternative, that is, of Government subsidies, is the Government doesn't have to make those content-based decisions.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, it doesn't make them on a specific case-by-case basis, but I think the tendency of your answer to Justice Breyer is, when you talk about vibrancy and quality, you are talking about some kind of a content-based standard, and I think what you're... I think what you're saying is that overall, not on a program-by-program basis, but overall, the content is going to be better.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Isn't that what you're saying?

context.speaker: Walter E. Dellinger, III
context.text: It seems to me that one can say that providing this kind... that these over-the-air broadcast channels are not starved financially in the hopes that they're available to the community for the quality programming that is chosen by--

context.speaker: Robert F. Klueger
context.text: It was... the claim was timely filed.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Within 2 years from his death?

context.speaker: Robert F. Klueger
context.text: Your Honor, I apologize--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Well, that's crucial, because you could not answer Justice Breyer's question yes, as you did, making a reading... reading (b)(2)(B) to say 2 years, you know, not including disability time.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You'd have to say not including disability time and also not including any time after death.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You'd have to say, right, at least his heirs have to do it within 2 years.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: I suppose that... I don't know why the death is the critical point.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: It seems to me in most of these doctrines it's when the claimant discovers the cause of action, that if you say, he's... you know, there's an excusable failure to get the facts sooner, so I don't know why the death is critical.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: It seems to me the--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: --It's only critical because of the way Justice Breyer put the question.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: You would have to say no, Justice Breyer, not just disability, but disability--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: --or other excusable reason.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: It seems to me in most of these doctrines it's when the claimant discovers the cause of action, that if you say, he's... you know, there's an excusable failure to get the facts sooner, so I don't know why the death is critical.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: It seems to me the--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: --It's only critical because of the way Justice Breyer put the question.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: You would have to say no, Justice Breyer, not just disability, but disability--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: --or other excusable reason.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Or anything--

context.speaker: Robert F. Klueger
context.text: The Dalm decision dealt with equitable recoupment, and did not--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: --Wasn't the--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: --No, but there's another distinction that you can make.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: You can take the position that Justice Scalia did and say, let's bring everything under the umbrella of equitable adjustment.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And then there are still distinctions between the cases, and the one is, title VII case was dealing with a situation in which the Government is often in the position of a private individual who normally gets the benefit of equitable tolling, whereas in the revenue situation, the Government is in a position peculiar unto itself, so those would be good reasons to say that there's no reason to think that the... that there would be a spillover of equitable considerations from a title VII case to a revenue case, and that seems to me to make more sense of the fact that these two cases came down in the same term, in which it would be very odd to think that one was being undercut by the other so soon.

context.speaker: Robert F. Klueger
context.text: --Well, I don't think that one undercut another.

context.speaker: Robert F. Klueger
context.text: The equities I submit are stronger in this case than they were, for example, in Dalm.

context.speaker: Robert F. Klueger
context.text: In Dalm, the... may I complete?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Finish your answer to Justice Ginsburg's--

context.speaker: Robert F. Klueger
context.text: In Dalm, the taxpayer had the ability to litigate the case.

context.speaker: Robert F. Klueger
context.text: In our case, we never had the ability.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Mr. Estrada, that's certainly a reasonable interpretation, but it's not what the statute says.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Do you think... you say that's a literal reading, or are you just making a very sensible construction of the statute?

context.speaker: Miguel A. Estrada
context.text: --Oh, I think both, Justice Stevens.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Because it says... it's a flat prohibition, as Justice Scalia pointed out.

context.speaker: Miguel A. Estrada
context.text: Well, as I indicated to Justice Scalia, Justice Stevens, it is our view, and we think it's right--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: That it should be read that way.

context.speaker: Miguel A. Estrada
context.text: --Well, and I think... and I really will concede, Justice Stevens, that if all I had were an independent freestanding sentence that began with the term of imprisonment, this might raise a different question.

context.speaker: Miguel A. Estrada
context.text: To just touch upon our... or, our second point is that to the extent the language would bear another reading, and to the extent that you might read the language in isolation as speaking to the duties of State courts imposing sentences under State law, there is a section that is also part of the Gun Control Act, section 927, which is quoted in our brief, in our reply brief in one of the footnotes, which indicates that it was not... in footnote 7 at page 10... which indicates that it was not, in fact, Congress' intention to occupy the field of sentencing for these offenses, and that they did not intend to divest the State courts of the authority that they would ordinarily have.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: It seems to me that your argument here is really being generous to the defendant.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Even if you conceded the point that Justice Stevens and I have been pressing, you would not have to concede the point that therefore the statute does... therefore the statute does not take into account State sentences.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: All you would have to concede is that the Federal... or that the statute controls State courts.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: All you would have to concede is that the statute continues to control only Federal sentencing, but when the Federal sentencing has been made by a State courts action to run concurrently with the State sentence, the Federal sentence must be altered to be... you know, to run sequentially, or, in other words, the sentence that's imposed has to be conditional.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I didn't understand that that included the extra gun enhancement part, but it does.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I see what you're saying.

context.speaker: Miguel A. Estrada
context.text: It does, and that was one of the issues that the Court had before it in the Busic and Simpson cases.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Mr. Estrada, you answered some of the questions from Justice Scalia or Justice Stevens about the scope of the nor shall clause by saying it occurs in a sentence which is addressed to Federal sentences, and that provides the context.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Why should we confine our contextual reference to sentences?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Why don't we approach this case with a... sort of a section-based contextualism, and the principle address of the section, I suppose, is to Federal sentencing and the relationships of Federal sentences, so if we're going to look at context, why don't we look at it more broadly than you would and find that a reason not to apply the any sentence reference to State sentences?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I didn't understand that that included the extra gun enhancement part, but it does.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I see what you're saying.

context.speaker: Miguel A. Estrada
context.text: It does, and that was one of the issues that the Court had before it in the Busic and Simpson cases.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Mr. Estrada, you answered some of the questions from Justice Scalia or Justice Stevens about the scope of the nor shall clause by saying it occurs in a sentence which is addressed to Federal sentences, and that provides the context.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Why should we confine our contextual reference to sentences?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Why don't we approach this case with a... sort of a section-based contextualism, and the principle address of the section, I suppose, is to Federal sentencing and the relationships of Federal sentences, so if we're going to look at context, why don't we look at it more broadly than you would and find that a reason not to apply the any sentence reference to State sentences?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We'll hear argument now in Number 96-667, United States v. Hyde.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: In this case, Justice Kennedy is unable to participate in the oral argument.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: He will, however, hear the tapes of oral argument and participate in the disposition of the case.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Feldman.

context.speaker: James A. Feldman
context.text: It depends on what the agreement says.

context.speaker: James A. Feldman
context.text: There may be an agreement where it's not at all, where the Government says, we will bring to the court, and we're not committing ourselves to telling the court anything in particular.

context.speaker: James A. Feldman
context.text: But in any event, whatever the Government agreed to I think it always has an obligation to the court to inform it of the relevant facts that the court should know in order to pass its judgment.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: --Can you go back for a second to Justice O'Connor's question, because this is another point I'm not certain about from the briefs, and from having read this.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Imagine we're in an (A) type bargain.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: That's a charge bargain.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I just want to know if I'm understanding your point.

context.speaker: Jonathan D. Soglin
context.text: --That's right.

context.speaker: Jonathan D. Soglin
context.text: If you could rephrase it--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, the question that Justice Breyer raised was, if the defendant may withdraw at will under a rule like the Ninth Circuit rule, then the defendant can sit back and wait for a presentence report, which is in fact going to be there before the judge sentences in almost every case, and if the deal is not final by the time he reads the report, he could simply withdraw his plea.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And I thought that you... and the implication being that would be a very strange system for the rules to provide, because that would give the defendant a terrific advantage in discovery, and I thought your argument was, well, the defendant is partially performing simply by standing up and going through the plea colloquy.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: The defendant is giving the Government something which it might use as a lead to further investigation and so on, and so therefore it's perfectly fair for the defendant to get the benefit of the plea agreement if the Government gets the benefit of this partial performance, and I thought that was the ultimate point that you were making.

context.speaker: Jonathan D. Soglin
context.text: The provision for acceptance of the agreement?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: The provisions for withdrawal of the pleas if, in fact, the agreements are not accepted and kept.

context.speaker: Jonathan D. Soglin
context.text: Well, the provision for withdrawal of the plea in Rule 32(e) doesn't describe whether it's talking about a tendered plea, an accepted plea, a plea where both the plea and the agreement have been accepted.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And the answer to that may be, just as Justice Scalia said, a plea is a plea, and once it's there, it's operative unless, in fact, it is subject to one of these withdrawal or reexamination provisions.

context.speaker: Jonathan D. Soglin
context.text: Well, again, the petitioner has conceded that that's not the case, and I think the answer may be in the Mabry case of this Court, where the Court held that the agreement is not binding until accepted by the court, and in that case it was a situation where the Government had made an offer which defendant accepted.

context.speaker: Jonathan D. Soglin
context.text: The Government then attempted to withdraw.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Or better, depending on whether you like it or don't like it.

context.speaker: David N. Yellen
context.text: --Congress has certainly enacted statutes that are more punitive than this.

context.speaker: David N. Yellen
context.text: I agree completely, but--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: But that's... Justice Scalia I think has put his finger on what's really the difficult underlying question here, because he said the fairest reading of the statute, and I suppose what's really at stake is... and sometimes you'll be on one side of this and sometimes the other side.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: What's really at stake is how much authority to give the Sentencing Commission to interpret its authorizing legislation, and you might want to comment on that.

context.speaker: David N. Yellen
context.text: --Yes.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And the effect of the commission's interpretation here is to minimize or to nullify the effect of that discretion which the court has as a result of the prosecutorial discretion.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: That's true, isn't it?

context.speaker: David N. Yellen
context.text: I don't agree with that, Justice Souter--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I think that was the premise of Justice Ginsburg's question--

context.speaker: David N. Yellen
context.text: --Yes.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: --and I make the same assumption.

context.speaker: David N. Yellen
context.text: --the maximum sentence--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: No... answer the question.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I think you're not answering the question.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I want to hear what you say, but before you get there, Justice Ginsburg and I seem to be making in your view just an incorrect assumption about how the law works in fact, and if we are wrong, we need to know that first.

context.speaker: David N. Yellen
context.text: --Yes.

context.speaker: David N. Yellen
context.text: The... I... the way the law works is that when a prosecutor seeks an enhanced maximum it does not automatically enhance the sentence.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Now, I can see taking them all into account or taking none of them into account, but to sort of arbitrarily say we're going to take into account some and not others doesn't seem to me a manner of interpreting the statute, but a matter of writing one.

context.speaker: David N. Yellen
context.text: Well, in fact the commission is there deferring to Congress.

context.speaker: David N. Yellen
context.text: Congress has said drug amounts matter a lot, and it would have been more presumptuous of the commission to say that--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But Congress said prosecutors have the discretion to go after the enhancement, and Mr. Yellen, frankly I don't have a clear answer to my question, and I think Justice Souter has the same problem.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: I can understand you saying, yes, that Judge Stahl was right, it effectively nullifies the enhancement, but that is exactly what the commission was trying to get at, because it wanted two people who committed identical conduct, who had the identical history, to be treated alike, and you can't have both.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: You can't treat two people who are exactly alike in every other respect the same unless you... unless you erase what the prosecutor has done.

context.speaker: David N. Yellen
context.text: No, Justice Souter.

context.speaker: David N. Yellen
context.text: The--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And you could say... is it right you say no because--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: --Let him answer Justice Souter's question.

context.speaker: David N. Yellen
context.text: --The... when the Government files under 851 the authorization is there to impose a 30-year sentence.

context.speaker: David N. Yellen
context.text: The court has that power, and the court will do that if it either exercises its discretion to depart, or if there are aggravating--

context.speaker: David N. Yellen
context.text: The career offender guidelines presents an alternative method of computing the guideline sentence.

context.speaker: David N. Yellen
context.text: For these defendants under Amendment 506 the career offender level is 32 criminal history category 6, okay, which is 210 months to 262 months, but the judge can... is required to compute the guideline range without regard to the career offender guideline, look at the amount of drugs, the weapon, and all of the other factors.

context.speaker: David N. Yellen
context.text: And the way the guidelines were written, in many cases, particularly for career offenders who have long criminal records and are likely to be involved in very serious drug crimes, unlike the respondents in this case, those offenders will very often have guideline ranges that are above the unenhanced statutory minimum.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: But I think you're saying that there are bases other than the exercise of prosecutorial discretion to file the information upon which the court may nonetheless raise the sentence, and Justice Ginsburg's question and mine is, other things being equal, if we look only at the effect that the prosecutor's discretion to go after the person for the enhanced sentence has, that effect on at least the judge's discretion is minimized or eliminated.

context.speaker: David N. Yellen
context.text: And again I respectfully disagree, Justice Souter.

context.speaker: David N. Yellen
context.text: If you're at level 32 and you have no enhancement motion filed under 851 the maximum is 20 years, or 240 months, so you could not even go to the top of the guideline range lawfully, the level 32.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I agree with you that there remain some circumstances where it was important to raise the cap.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: The circumstances where it was important are where you depart, or where the crime at issue is greater than the 20 years under the guideline, and where you want to use the career offender and go all the way up to 262 months.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: You characterize that as a big role for raising the cap to play.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I think Justice Souter was characterizing it as a role for it to play, but not the whole heart of the matter, and is that a fair... is that fair?

context.speaker: David N. Yellen
context.text: --It will... yes.

context.speaker: David N. Yellen
context.text: Longer sentences will be less common under the commission's amendment, absolutely.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: He then forcibly physically orally raped her and told her not to say anything about it.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Now, are you saying that this makes the right more specific?

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: I'm not saying--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Because if you are, then I think your answer to Justice Souter might have been that color of law is necessary for us to consider to make the right more specific.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Now, maybe that's not your position.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: --That's not my position.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: --That's not my position.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: My position is that there are four elements to a 242 offense, of which color of law is one, and violation of a constitutional right made specific is another, wilfulness is a third and, of course, the commission of the acts alleged is a fourth.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: As we understood and as we brought this case to this Court, the issue was the first, the second that I identified, which is, was the right violated here a right that has been made specific, and our point--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And if you win on that you then go back to the court of appeals for further proceedings on color of law, or the... Justice Scalia's articulation of the concept of right guaranteed?

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: --I don't think that it's... I suppose maybe I haven't thought of this closely enough.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: I don't think it's required for us to go back to the court of appeals for any other determinations.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I think the issue is the exertion of State power.

context.speaker: Alfred H. Knight
context.text: I would agree with that, Your Honor, that that is the broad issue.

context.speaker: Alfred H. Knight
context.text: I believe that the case law has so far by this Court been in terms of injuries that occur while in custody.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But you would... would you distinguish the hypothetical Justice Scalia just gave you and the case we have before us?

context.speaker: Alfred H. Knight
context.text: Yes, Your Honor, I would on the basis that I initially suggested, which is that a judge has no authority conferred by the State to assault or restrain or subdue citizens, and therefore--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: May I interrupt you on that question?

context.speaker: Alfred H. Knight
context.text: Well--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: You'd say that isn't colorable.

context.speaker: Alfred H. Knight
context.text: --I would make the distinction that there's a difference between an extortive use of power, or an extortive use of position where you say, I'm strong enough to force you to do this on the one hand, and saying as a judge I have the authority to sentence you to be assaulted by me.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Oh, but I thought you could answer Justice Stevens that that is a more specific right than the right that's involved in this case, i.e., the right to be free from having the judicial officer use the powers and the authority of his office in order to commit a sexual assault.

context.speaker: Alfred H. Knight
context.text: I would agree with that, Your Honor.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But that isn't too... Justice Stevens' hypothesis isn't too far from what actually happened here--

context.speaker: Alfred H. Knight
context.text: --I would make the distinction that there's a difference between an extortive use of power, or an extortive use of position where you say, I'm strong enough to force you to do this on the one hand, and saying as a judge I have the authority to sentence you to be assaulted by me.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Oh, but I thought you could answer Justice Stevens that that is a more specific right than the right that's involved in this case, i.e., the right to be free from having the judicial officer use the powers and the authority of his office in order to commit a sexual assault.

context.speaker: Alfred H. Knight
context.text: I would agree with that, Your Honor.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But that isn't too... Justice Stevens' hypothesis isn't too far from what actually happened here--

context.speaker: Alfred H. Knight
context.text: Oh, I--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: --with the case of the oral rape.

context.speaker: Alfred H. Knight
context.text: --which is a conversational statement, as a threat.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But they weren't asked to, anyway.

context.speaker: Alfred H. Knight
context.text: They were not asked to anyway.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: But on your theory, as I understand it in your response to Justice Breyer and to the Chief Justice, as I understand it you're drawing a distinction something like this.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: You're saying that the official was acting under color of law if, in effect, he abuses the authority which the State law ostensibly gives him as distinguished from simply using influence which incidentally comes to him because he's a State official.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Is that the way you draw the line, roughly?

context.speaker: Alfred H. Knight
context.text: People won't listen to me if I report him.

context.speaker: Alfred H. Knight
context.text: It's the sort of reaction that you could have to any prominent citizen, and certainly if that's the test, then any assault by almost any public official or public employee could be subjected to that kind of analysis.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --Let's take color of law out of it.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Let's take Justice Stevens' hypothetical.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The judge orders the person into their... into his chambers by herself and commits an aggravated sexual assault.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Is there a specific right of bodily integrity that the judge has violated in the exercise of his office by an abuse of his authority?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: In that case, I suppose the judge was not on either your test or Mr. Waxman's test exercising that authority that would bring him under color of law.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I thought that was the example, though.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Wasn't that sort of the same example?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I thought that was the example that Justice Ginsburg gave, the same kind of thing, a judge who didn't shoot him but just jumped out of his chamber and--

context.speaker: Alfred H. Knight
context.text: In the course of being transferred--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: --Yes.

context.speaker: Alfred H. Knight
context.text: I mean, they were dealing in quite specific deprivations in that case--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: --Isn't that part of Screws dealing with the under color of law question?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Which is just what Justice Souter said?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Of course--

context.speaker: Alfred H. Knight
context.text: --I'm sorry?
Yes.

context.speaker: Alfred H. Knight
context.text: But I'm not sure it was a fiction in terms of the facts, because there was evidence that the deputy had said, we're going to get this guy, and they arrested him under some pretext and killed him before he could be tried, so I think there were facts from which a jury could conclude that in a factual sense they really were depriv... they really did intend to deprive him of legal process and kill him before he could be found innocent, but I mean, that's... as I read the case, that's what was going on.

context.speaker: Alfred H. Knight
context.text: And I do think that the concern of all seven of the justices that... well, seven of the nine, was that this statute might be so vague as to be almost subject to due process objection on its face, and I think the intent was to construe it very narrowly to require very specific constitutional violations and intent factually to violate those rights.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Depending on just how far we go with specificity, may I at least come back to consider a distinction raised by Justice Ginsburg's question?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Your answer was very probably under Screws that that, in fact, would not qualify as a violation.

context.speaker: Alfred H. Knight
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Depending on just how far we go with specificity, may I at least come back to consider a distinction raised by Justice Ginsburg's question?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Your answer was very probably under Screws that that, in fact, would not qualify as a violation.

context.speaker: Alfred H. Knight
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: But as I understood it under Justice Ginsburg's hypothetical the person who was subject to the sexual assault would have been subject to the judge's judicial jurisdiction later on.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Doesn't that affect the answer, and for that reason shouldn't the answer... shouldn't your answer have been different?

context.speaker: Alfred H. Knight
context.text: Well, if there were facts from which a jury could find an intent to deprive her of a trial by jury and to punish her by some other means, or to... whatever.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, Mr. Waxman, though, you're not... qualified immunity is a civil concept, really.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Certainly you might want a more demanding standard in the area of the criminal law, it seems to me.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: Well, for sure you would, and the way the standard is made more demanding, Mr. Chief Justice, is by the requirement of a showing that the defendant acted with a bad purpose, with an intent to violate the law.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Yes, but as Justice Kennedy says there's a certain fiction about all of that.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: Well, I'm not sure that I really understand what the fiction is.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: The... it is true that in Screws the... under Screws there is an obligation to identify in the indictment the specific right violated and the manner in which it was violated.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: You're saying there must be a disclosure and consent.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: To satisfy the common law rule that a trustee may not use the property that's been entrusted with him, there would have to be consent.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: To satisfy the requirement of the Securities Act that there be no deception, there would only have to be disclosure.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: I thought that was what you answered Justice Scalia when he asked the question.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Yes, that's what I thought, too.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Why isn't the client entrusted just as totally when he entrusts money as when he entrusts information?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I don't under... I guess my problem is--

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: He does, Justice Souter.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: --the same as Justice Scalia's.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I don't... if we're starting with a breach of trust, I don't see why a breach of trust with respect to a fact which is communicated gives rise to a disclosure obligation when a breach of trust with respect to some other thing of value, e.g., the contents of the trust account, does not.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: I perhaps was not clear in answering Justice Scalia, Justice Souter.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: When you take the money out of the accounts you can go to the racetrack, or whatever--

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: That's exactly right, and because of that difference, three can be no doubt that this kind of misappropriation of property is in connection with the purchase or sale of securities.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: Other kinds of misappropriation of property may or may not, but this is a unique form of fraud, unique to the securities markets, in fact, because the only way in which respondent could have profited through this information is by either trading on it or by tipping somebody else to enable their trades.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: --With respect to the tip, I wasn't quite sure of your answer to Justice O'Connor when she brought up the child.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Were you responding to her word inadvertent, because if this parent tipped off the child and told the child to purchase the security, surely there would be--

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: John D. French
context.text: I don't believe the Congress is attempting to regulate the relationships between lawyers and their firms, which are regulated by codes of professional responsibility, or husbands and wives, or fathers and sons, which is the context in which these misappropriation cases come up.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, is it wrong for me to proceed through the statute and the relevant... and 10(b) 5 by asking first, is there fraud?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Second, is it in connection with the sale of securities?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And it seems to me that in the case that Justice Stevens put to you, where the principal partner working for Grand Met starts trading on the inside information, that there is fraud in the sense of deception.

context.speaker: John D. French
context.text: It is possible--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Now... now, maybe that's right, maybe that's wrong under your view, and I'd like to hear why.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, but it says somewhat more than that.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: It defines what materiality is a few sentence... a few paragraphs before.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: That is true.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: So a knowledgeable jury, as I think Justice Ginsburg is suggesting, would say, well, materiality is important in this case, and it's been established.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: I think--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Suppose in this case the judge said, I instruct you as a matter of law that this is material.

context.speaker: James R. Wyrsch
