context.text: --Because if the concepts are different, and if, in fact, the statement made about, you know, the Yankee example that was given there earlier, if that, in fact... does the Government have the opportunity in that instance to prosecute?

context.speaker: James R. Wyrsch
context.text: Absolutely.

context.speaker: James R. Wyrsch
context.text: If this Court says, well, it'll never bring that, which is the Government's response--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: My actual point is the same as Justice Scalia's on that one.

context.speaker: James R. Wyrsch
context.text: --Well, I understand that, but I still say that if the concepts are different no one should be subject to harsh penalties, which is what many of the courts of appeals have said.

context.speaker: James R. Wyrsch
context.text: No one should be subject to the penalty for 26, 31 months if he had a bad intent but it was immaterial to the bank's decision, and that's why the courts have said we need to read a materiality element into the statute.

context.speaker: James R. Wyrsch
context.text: I think it can be construed probably more as statutory construction, but in one of these cases, and I believe it was the Williams case, Mr. Chief Justice, they expressly referred to Coke and Blackstone in the common law, and they said at common law materiality was, in fact, an element.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: But I--

context.speaker: James R. Wyrsch
context.text: So I think it was both, at least under that Williams case.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: --Do I remember correctly that you had earlier said, I think it was in response to a question of Justice Scalia, earlier said that none of the 10 had in fact been construed to require materiality?

context.speaker: James R. Wyrsch
context.text: I think one of the 10 under the Kay case had been construed--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Not to require.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The opinion of the Court in No. 95-1228, United States against Wells, will be announced by Justice Souter.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: This case comes to us on writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: A federal grand jury indicted the respondents, Wells and Steele on charges of violating and conspiring to violate Section 1014 of Title 18 of the U.S. Code which prohibits making certain false statements to an FDIC insured bank.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: We find no reason to justify departing from the text and reading materiality element into the statute.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Respondents have made two other arguments which relate to the jury instruction and the indictment.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Because the Respondents did not raise these issues in the brief they submitted to the Eighth Circuit and because the Court of Appeals did not address them in its opinion, we remand the case to allow the Court of Appeals to consider whether the respondents properly raised those issues and address them if it is appropriate.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Justice Stevens has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: --you would have no problem with that?

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: --I think that's right.

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: I would be an action/inaction advocate, although I do think, if it were demonstrable, as I think it's true in New York, that someone who, for example, slashed her wrists and said, no action has been taken yet, don't put the IV in me, if New York says to her, sorry, we're going do it anyway and overrides her bodily integrity in order to prevent what it calls suicide, but then tells someone else who is in the process of dying and is 10 or 11 days from death, for you we are not going to worry about the intent that you have--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But, Mr. Tribe, the whole solution now you've given us, I think, in your answer to Justice Scalia, New York could say and be perfectly compatible with equal protection, as you've just described it, person who is terminally ill, you've got to make the choice now before we give you the life support, you have a right to refuse it, but once you've accepted it, you have no right to have it taken out.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: So understand that, and New York does that, then these... this equal protection problem disappears; is that right?

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: --No, I don't think so, Justice Ginsburg.

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: You sedate them either before taking them off a respirator because we are told that asphyxiation is one of the most terrifying and excruciating deaths, or you keep them sedated as they starve and dehydrate and their families see them disintegrate.

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: Because that's all that's available to them.

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: It is the Kafkaesque but entirely logical result of the principles that the states haven't really adopted but have fallen into.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, Mr. Tribe, you say they've fallen into it and you referred in answering Justice Breyer a moment ago to the state laboratories operating with the lights out.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Isn't it fair to say that the issue that we are dealing with is a really serious legislative issue, is fairly recent.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: 20 years ago we weren't even reading about this.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Isn't it fair to say that the issue that we are dealing with is a really serious legislative issue, is fairly recent.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: 20 years ago we weren't even reading about this.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: So that the fact may be and the metaphor may be right, that the lights have been out, but the effort to put the lights on is fairly recent.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And doesn't... doesn't that sort of put some punch behind Justice Breyer's question?

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: Well, I thought it had a lot of punch to begin with.

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: But I guess the problem is, you know, most of us... these legislatures are operating in the dark and we hope that they will take into account everyone's interests as they work.

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: I think they have... the lights are bright here.

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: When I say the dark, I mean this: Doctors, like Dr. Quill, who, when he explained what he was doing in the case of someone who thought it would be dehumanizing to be terminally sedated, so he publicly explained in an article called Diane, that he was actually going to leave her with some lethal medications, he was investigated by the grand jury.

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: When doctors do a lot of what they do in upping the level of the morphine and actually using more benzodiazepine than is needed to make sure the person is comfortable but to make sure the person dies sooner, they're not going to talk to others about it because they might be prosecuted because of the lines that are drawn.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But the New York report, and perhaps this will get you to the autonomy interest and it bridges what Justice Breyer and Justice Souter suggested, that we're just beginning to get a public awareness and to find out much more about these things.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The New York report, it seems to me, is a Brandeis brief for the proposition that the autonomy that you suggest, that you wish to protect, or that you wish to create, is illusory, it's chimerical, that there will be less autonomy, less autonomy, by the unanimous judgment of the members of that task force, if you allow the option that you choose.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: In fact, you will be introducing fear into medical care facilities.

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: I think they have... the lights are bright here.

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: When I say the dark, I mean this: Doctors, like Dr. Quill, who, when he explained what he was doing in the case of someone who thought it would be dehumanizing to be terminally sedated, so he publicly explained in an article called Diane, that he was actually going to leave her with some lethal medications, he was investigated by the grand jury.

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: When doctors do a lot of what they do in upping the level of the morphine and actually using more benzodiazepine than is needed to make sure the person is comfortable but to make sure the person dies sooner, they're not going to talk to others about it because they might be prosecuted because of the lines that are drawn.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But the New York report, and perhaps this will get you to the autonomy interest and it bridges what Justice Breyer and Justice Souter suggested, that we're just beginning to get a public awareness and to find out much more about these things.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The New York report, it seems to me, is a Brandeis brief for the proposition that the autonomy that you suggest, that you wish to protect, or that you wish to create, is illusory, it's chimerical, that there will be less autonomy, less autonomy, by the unanimous judgment of the members of that task force, if you allow the option that you choose.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: In fact, you will be introducing fear into medical care facilities.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: What I'm saying is that the... if anyone reads that report as you have, as I have, and thinks about what happens in the hospital wards when terminal sedation is given, when the morphine drip is increased, when the person is asleep and it's said that they wanted the respirator disconnected but there are no required witnesses, that's pretty scary.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And what I suggest is that the New York legislature, which initially outlawed all physician-assisted suicide, not by identifying physicians, but by just saying if A helps B commit suicide, it's a crime, now confronts a rather different regime, a regime that says near the end of life, whether or not the intent of somebody is deliberately to die, if certain techniques are used, combination of morphine and barbiturates, a surgical removal of something implanted, we don't call that suicide and actually we don't regulate it very much.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But, on the other side, if the patient is prescribed, at the patient's request, a lethal drug, we make that absolutely forbidden.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: That combination which has not been chosen by the legislature, when Mr. Vacco held up that report and said, this is the choice of people of New York and I wondered what his answer was to Justice Ginsburg's question, who is the we, New York in its legislature did nothing in response that to that report.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: That is, they didn't change the law, but that was inaction.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The line, it's like Thompson v. Oklahoma.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: That combination which has not been chosen by the legislature, when Mr. Vacco held up that report and said, this is the choice of people of New York and I wondered what his answer was to Justice Ginsburg's question, who is the we, New York in its legislature did nothing in response that to that report.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: That is, they didn't change the law, but that was inaction.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The line, it's like Thompson v. Oklahoma.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: When Oklahoma passed some laws that had the unfortunate consequence of exposing 15-year-olds to execution and, Justice O'Connor, you concluded that you didn't have to reach the ultimate merits of whether that was unconstitutional, because that was really a question that didn't have to be decided.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: It was at least Constitutionally dubious as I suggest the rationality of this line is at least Constitutionally dubious.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: That was a concurring both that in the end sent the thing back to Oklahoma and said if you really need to execute 15-year-olds, tell us that.

Walters v. Metropolitan Educational Ente.speaker: Justice Ginsburg
Walters v. Metropolitan Educational Ente.case_name: Walters v. Metropolitan Educational Enterprises, Inc.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You're talking about rational force and not authoritative effect, which is what Chevron talks about?

context.speaker: Constantine John Gekas
context.text: --Well, I'm saying... I'm saying that if the... if the test is the Skidmore test, then it's... this regulation satisfies it, because it has rational force, internally coherent, sensibly based on the statutory language.

context.speaker: Constantine John Gekas
context.text: And there is also some unanimity of opinion... perhaps not entirely unanimous, because of the Seventh Circuit and the other cases that go against it, but there is... two-thirds of the people looking at this... the Congress--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Mr.... Mr. Gekas, may I interrupt just to ask if I understood your answer to Justice O'Connor correctly?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: You were saying that your interpretation... let's forget about deference... of this statute coincides in... with that of the EEOC?

context.speaker: Constantine John Gekas
context.text: --Yes.

Walters v. Metropolitan Educational Ente.speaker: Justice Ginsburg
Walters v. Metropolitan Educational Ente.case_name: Walters v. Metropolitan Educational Enterprises, Inc.
Walters v. Metropolitan Educational Ente.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 06, 1996

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: --the one that they put forward--

context.speaker: Constantine John Gekas
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: --is also the one that you put forward?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But there's one thing that you also said in your response to Justice O'Connor that puzzled me, because I thought both your interpretation and the EEOC's required that somebody be a current employee.

context.speaker: Constantine John Gekas
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: So someone... the computer had to take their name off the payroll.

Walters v. Metropolitan Educational Ente.speaker: Justice Souter
Walters v. Metropolitan Educational Ente.case_name: Walters v. Metropolitan Educational Enterprises, Inc.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: It's... it's another marginal case.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: That's a classic example of the seasonal employee, but, on your theory, he would be a... a continuing employee.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: --If I were... if... I... I think a very creditable argument could be made in that instance, if I were litigating a case, that because Congress meant to exclude seasonal businesses, there was not an employment relationship during the intervening 11 months.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, then... then what is the distinction you're drawing between Justice O'Connor's once a month... one day a month, and... and the one month a year?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Is it... is it a concept of... of seasonality as opposed to what, periodicity or something like that?

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: Yes, I think... I think applying Federal law, construing the definition of employer as this Court will interpret it, this... a... a court... or the EEOC would have to determine whether there was in fact a real, ongoing employment relationship.

Walters v. Metropolitan Educational Ente.speaker: Justice Kennedy
Walters v. Metropolitan Educational Ente.case_name: Walters v. Metropolitan Educational Enterprises, Inc.
Walters v. Metropolitan Educational Ente.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 06, 1996

context.speaker: Patrick J. Falahee, Jr.
context.text: Well, while... while an... an employer is required to maintain certain information for tax purposes, particularly to generate W-2 forms at the end of the year, I think the... the answer to... to Your Honor's question would really depend on what type of a payroll service was... was being utilized.

context.speaker: Patrick J. Falahee, Jr.
context.text: I think that could probably differ from case to case, depending upon... upon the method of maintaining the payroll.

context.speaker: Patrick J. Falahee, Jr.
context.text: And even with respect to an automated payroll system, I suggest that, depending on the way that system works, there could be different outcomes.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: While... while I have you, in connection with Justice Stevens's question... because I was thinking of the same thing when the Solicitor General was arguing... suppose you had an employer that worked a 10-hour day, 4 days a week.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Those... and there were 15 employees on each of those days, and they were all the same employees... they... they would be covered under the Act, would they not?

context.speaker: Patrick J. Falahee, Jr.
context.text: Under... under our approach, yes.

Walters v. Metropolitan Educational Ente.speaker: Justice Ginsburg
Walters v. Metropolitan Educational Ente.case_name: Walters v. Metropolitan Educational Enterprises, Inc.
Walters v. Metropolitan Educational Ente.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 06, 1996

context.speaker: Patrick J. Falahee, Jr.
context.text: In other words, is... does a working day happen?

context.speaker: Patrick J. Falahee, Jr.
context.text: Is there a working day when an employer does not conduct its full operations?

context.speaker: Patrick J. Falahee, Jr.
context.text: And I believe there... there have been some lower court cases recognizing that, in... in... in hypotheticals similar to Your Honor's, that fifth day would not be counted as a working day, to avoid precisely that result.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But, Mr. Falahee, I'm confused by your answer to Justice Kennedy's question, because I thought that it would be the other way on your method.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: That is, take someone's 5-day week... regular 5-day week... but this person works 10 hours a day, 4 days a week.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: I thought, under your method, that person would not count as an employee, because that person is... is not employed for each working day?

Walters v. Metropolitan Educational Ente.speaker: Justice Stevens
Walters v. Metropolitan Educational Ente.case_name: Walters v. Metropolitan Educational Enterprises, Inc.
Walters v. Metropolitan Educational Ente.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 06, 1996

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: I thought you agreed with me, they don't have to be the same 15... you have a different 15 every day?

Walters v. Metropolitan Educational Ente.speaker: Justice Stevens
Walters v. Metropolitan Educational Ente.case_name: Walters v. Metropolitan Educational Enterprises, Inc.
Walters v. Metropolitan Educational Ente.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 06, 1996

context.speaker: Patrick J. Falahee, Jr.
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Yeah, okay.

context.speaker: Patrick J. Falahee, Jr.
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: But I think Justice Ginsburg was--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: --But my example was... was--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: --assuming the contrary.

Walters v. Metropolitan Educational Ente.speaker: Justice Stevens

context.speaker: Patrick J. Falahee, Jr.
context.text: I think... I think it would really depend on what the... what the language of the Christmas bonus policy was, Your Honor.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Well, the bonus was you... you get a dollar a day for every day you're on the payroll, even though you didn't work certain days.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Under your compensation test, it'd seem to me he'd be an employee.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: That's different from showing up at work, because you... I think you agreed with Justice Scalia, your test is not presence, because you take people on sick leave and so forth.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: But if your test is compensation, it seems to me that any element of compensation that would accrue to a person on the payroll at the end of the year or for... for any... any benefit whatsoever, would make that person an employee.

context.speaker: Patrick J. Falahee, Jr.
context.text: No, Your Honor.

Walters v. Metropolitan Educational Ente.speaker: Justice Ginsburg
Walters v. Metropolitan Educational Ente.case_name: Walters v. Metropolitan Educational Enterprises, Inc.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: And there are these various ways.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg

context.speaker: Patrick J. Falahee, Jr.
context.text: --One of the other difficulties, Your Honor, with... with the principle of deference... there... there are several other problems--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Well, wholly apart from deference.

context.speaker: Patrick J. Falahee, Jr.
context.text: --Under a weekly payroll system, yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Patrick J. Falahee, Jr.
context.text: Yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Patrick J. Falahee, Jr.
context.text: I... I think... I think what we're focusing, though... what we're focusing on, though, here is a daily payroll, in terms of measuring the size of the employer's work force on a particular day.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Do you think it's plausible to assume, if we're going to look to legislative history, that Senator Dirksen intended employers... and the Government, for that matter, but particularly employers... to have to go through the super-complicated calculation that your method would provide, as opposed to the much simpler method that the EEOC and your opposing counsel propose?

context.speaker: Richard G. Taranto

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Why is it that Graver should be limited?

context.speaker: David E. Schmit
context.text: --Not necessarily.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: In fact, you... if you had, you would have said you had experimented at these lower levels, presumably.

context.speaker: David E. Schmit
context.text: For whatever reason, it wasn't in the patent.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But you can answer Justice Stevens question yes, that you put in 6 because you knew it would work at that level, and you weren't sure it would work below, and still not surrender your position.

context.speaker: David E. Schmit
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Can you go back for a second to Justice O'Connor's question, and you were talking about synonyms.

Warner-Jenkinson Company, Inc. v. Hilton.case_name: Warner-Jenkinson Company, Inc. v. Hilton Davis Chemical Company

context.speaker: David E. Schmit

context.speaker: David E. Schmit

context.text: Can you go back for a second to Justice O'Connor's question, and you were talking about synonyms.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I'm trying to understand how the doctrine of equivalents works.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Suppose that I have invented five chemicals, A, B, C, D, E, and you put them together and it grows hair, for example.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: William L. Williams
context.text: Let me be perfectly clear on that.

context.speaker: William L. Williams
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: You indicated in your response to Justice Ginsburg that, if we assumed a liberty interest but nevertheless found that the very substantial arguments you have made outweighed it, so that the Washington laws would remain in effect, that this would somehow be confining to legislators and regulators?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I wasn't quite sure that I followed that.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I understand the doctrinal significance of this suggestion that was made.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Ms. Tucker, may I ask you just to qualify one thing.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: You said formed over a lifetime.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: That's surely not part of your calculus, it could be someone who never thought a moment about this but is in terrible agony and would fit your terminal illness category.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: And I thought that the question Justice Souter was asking you was isn't it possible that such a person could at one time, even for a period of days, say I want to die, I want to die, and didn't get the assistance, lives on, and says I'm glad that I didn't do that, just like mistakes are made about people who commit crimes, isn't there the possibility of a person saying, gee, I really thought I wanted it yesterday, but today I don't?

context.speaker: Kathryn L. Tucker
context.text: --I think that's possible, Justice Ginsburg.

context.speaker: Kathryn L. Tucker
context.text: I do think that it would be permissible for the state in an abundance of concern in that regard to impose a waiting period.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I mean, if you're right about that scientific analysis, it's contrary to what the majority feels.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: And why shouldn't we follow the majority?

context.speaker: Kathryn L. Tucker
context.text: We also have the problem, Your Honor, of the quite well-established and understood underground practice of physician aid in dying and that that is available primarily to the educated and the affluent who can access a physician to provide in that assistance.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: May I go back to the reference in your answer to Justice O'Connor to the political process not working.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: It seems to me that in the prior cases in which we have spoken of the political process being imperfect, it has been imperfect for exactly the reasons suggested by her question.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And that is, there were certain groups who simply did not get a representative fair shake for whatever reason.

context.speaker: Kathryn L. Tucker
context.text: I don't think so much that you are compelled to pursue medical treatment.

context.speaker: Kathryn L. Tucker
context.text: But I think that if you are--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But you're telling us what the law of the State of Washington is.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And I thought you told Justice Ginsburg and us that in Washington there is no right to refuse medical treatment except under some very narrow conditions.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: This may be true with comatose people or people in temporary shock.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But I assume that Justice Ginsburg meant... and we're interested here, our whole discussion... is about those who are competent and have a voluntary choice.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But you're telling us what the law of the State of Washington is.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And I thought you told Justice Ginsburg and us that in Washington there is no right to refuse medical treatment except under some very narrow conditions.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: This may be true with comatose people or people in temporary shock.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But I assume that Justice Ginsburg meant... and we're interested here, our whole discussion... is about those who are competent and have a voluntary choice.

context.speaker: Kathryn L. Tucker
context.text: --I was pointing out that in the State of Washington the right to direct the withdrawal of treatment is limited, tightly, to those who are terminally ill.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: You mean as a result of death, you mean withdrawal that will result in death?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Now, it may discourage people from voting in State elections who find it easier to register for Federal only, but that's the Congress' fault for applying this new system only to Federal elections.

context.speaker: Brenda Wright
context.text: --We argue, Your Honor, that because of the decision in Allen v. State Board of Elections it's clear that even if a change, a particular change is mandated by the Voting Rights Act itself, it is subject to preclearance requirements.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Your argument goes considerably further than Allen, which itself went to me to the extreme of construing this statute.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: May I ask, Ms. Wright, I just want to be sure, I didn't think the questions that Justice O'Connor put to you is presented by this case.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We aren't concerned with whether or not the Attorney General would have had a duty to preclear if there had been a submission, are we?

context.speaker: Brenda Wright
context.text: No.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: But it might be important to other members of this Court to know just how far the Attorney General's position goes.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: It certainly is important to me.

context.speaker: Brenda Wright
context.text: Yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And in that respect, may I rephrase Justice O'Connor's question?

context.speaker: Brenda Wright
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: It isn't your position that as a practical matter... as a practical matter, the State must ask for preclearance of its former voting procedures.

context.speaker: Robert E. Sanders
context.text: No.

context.speaker: Robert E. Sanders
context.text: My position hasn't changed.

context.speaker: Robert E. Sanders
context.text: I just... I didn't want... I... the fact that they were precleared seemed to me to--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Yes, but your argument that they were precleared, if I understood you before Justice Ginsburg asked you some other questions, was that the February 16 letter in effect ratified the prior preclearance.

context.speaker: Robert E. Sanders
context.text: --That's correct.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: That's surely not a fair reading of that letter, which is asking... which is telling you in so many words there's been no preclearance.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You think it's an argument, but it's a bad argument is what you're saying.

context.speaker: Robert E. Sanders
context.text: --That's correct.

context.speaker: Robert E. Sanders
context.text: Thank you, Your Honor.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: But didn't you also... didn't you also in this argument just a moment ago in responding to Justice O'Connor refer to the need to submit something about the forms?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: You used the word form.

context.speaker: Robert E. Sanders
context.text: Right.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I mean, what would you suggest we do?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I imagine what would happen is you'd have to preclear those, and they'd come in and argue that in light of the dual system you have to do something that's virtually impossible.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I don't know what they're going to argue, but they're going to argue that that dual system is highly relevant, and you'll argue it isn't.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: All right, and... so what in your opinion, if we... just what Justice O'Connor asked, I think.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: What is your opinion if we disagree with you that it has been cleared, and we think it hasn't been cleared yet, what should we do?

context.speaker: Robert E. Sanders
context.text: Well, I think at most of course you should just simply remand it.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: You can't go out at night.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: So there are, it seems to me, all sorts of options that the parole officer has, short of revocation.

context.speaker: Sandra D. Howard
context.text: --There may be additional options, depending upon--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: So then that distinction between your pre-parolee respondent here and the parolee in the standard parole case doesn't seem to hold up in your answer to Justice Stevens.

context.speaker: Sandra D. Howard
context.text: --Well, the distinction, I believe, is the fact that these... the things that I were mentioning to Justice Stevens show that this inmate, people on pre-parole are continuing to serve their sentence under the Department of Corrections.

context.speaker: Sandra D. Howard
context.text: With a parole program, yes, the parole officer could put additional burdens on a parolee if it was in... if it was within the rules and conditions which were originally imposed upon him.

context.speaker: Sandra D. Howard
context.text: Not automatically, but they may be given pre-parole--

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: They wouldn't consider, you think, whether they're going to be a threat on release?

context.speaker: Sandra D. Howard
context.text: --They certainly may consider that, and... but I... but they are not required to consider that.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: May I ask another question along Justice O'Connor's line?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Supposing the prison is extremely crowded.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Is it permissible for the parole board to take that fact into consideration in deciding whether to grant someone parole that might not... could be right on the margin?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: It just means if you don't live up to the expectations you will be pulled back.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: It doesn't mean you can't be for other reasons, necessarily.

context.speaker: Margaret Winter
context.text: Well, you see--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But you're sort of compelled to argue, aren't you... don't you really have to answer yes to the question Justice Kennedy was asking?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: If... if this could be revoked for any reason whatever, what good would a hearing be?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I mean, you usually don't have a... you usually have a hearing to find out whether a particular legal requirement was complied with or not.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I'm not asking about procedure.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: This is... are you talking... when you say court of appeals, are you talking about the Tenth Circuit or the--

context.speaker: Margaret Winter
context.text: --No, the--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: --Court of Criminal Appeals that Justice Breyer is talking about?

context.speaker: Margaret Winter
context.text: --Court of Criminal Appeals.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Yes.
